You will reach Bastar's capital Jagdalpur in the late afternoon to check into a resort. Here you will meet our local guide who will show you around during your stay in Jagdalpur.

Jagdalpur A few days in the capable hands of our local guide will give you a chance to tap the tribal and natural delights of this area. You will travel with him out of Jagdalpur into the country of the Bison Horn Maria and Dhurwa tribes. You will see a performance of their spectacular local dance and get a good look at village life, costumes, ornaments and customs. You will visit villages and tribal markets and see the Chitrakote Waterfall on the Indravati River. In the evenings there will be a further opportunity to explore Jagdalpur's absorbing city markets. You will also have time to visit Kanger Valley National Park, an hour or so south of Jagdalpur, where there are stalactite and stalagmite formations in the Kutumsar and Kailash Caves. However the real glory of Kanger is that it retains something of the intensity of the forests that once covered this entire region - the natural habitat of leopard, tiger, sambhar, bison and the musical hill myna, Bastar's most famous bird.

Jagdapur – Goudaguda A three-hour drive takes you over the border to Goudaguda in Orrisa where an Australian ex-pat has built his home. His principles are very much in line with our responsible travel policy. Anxious about the damage done by ‘human safaris’, he encourages visitors to spend time in the area, exploring this lovely landscape on foot wherever possible, walking with the local tribal women who work for him. His guest house was built by local craftsmen and women and he continues to provide employment not just within his home but in the whole area, by assisting local people in the marketing of their traditional crafts to Indian and foreign tourists.

Goudaguda At Goudaguda you will have the opportunity to visit one of the many weekly markets or "haats". Enjoy the sights, sounds and aromas as local tribal people barter, buy and sell their produce and stock. Many handicrafts are available from colourful saris, handmade textiles in traditional patterns and earthy tones to exclusive jewellery pieces. Walk the cross country route with the locals from Goudaguda and surrounding villages to the Kakiriguma market (3 klm) held every Monday under a canopy of old mango trees. If you are not in the mood for touring you can simply explore the village and surrounding countryside with some of the local tribal girls as your guides who can also give you an insight to daily village life here in Goudaguda. You can also relax and enjoy the scenery and village sounds or simply spend the day with the potters and make your own.

Goudaguda - Visakhapatnam Spend the morning at Goudaguda then take the lunchtime train through the beautiful Araku Valley to Visakhapatnam. Reaching Visakhapatnam at 8.40pm you will be met and taken to the airport for your onward flight the following day.

tourName: Classic Southern India holiday
placesVisited: Chennai, Mahabalipuram, Kanchipuram, Mysore, Bandipur National Park, Ooty, Coonoor, Nilgiri Mountain Railway, Cochin, Alleppey, Varkala
generalInfo: Avoid the classic tourist route to discover the tribal cultures and serene landscapes of South India. Guided by one of our much-loved Indian tour leaders, we head inland to explore forested hills, cruise tranquil backwaters, and tour fragrant coffee, tea and spice plantations. Also experience the best of India’s welcoming hospitality, feasting on delicious local dishes and staying in a range of Premium accommodations, including an unforgettable night on a houseboat.

dayInfo.description: Arriving at Bangalore International Airport, head towards the exit of the terminal building, where you are met and transferred (approximately 3hr 30min) to Mysore. Around 6pm, we gather as a group to get to know each other and learn more about the adventures ahead over a welcome meeting. In the evening, we visit Mysore Palace, one of the largest in India, to see it illuminated by more than 100,000 bulbs – a dazzling opening to our adventure. That’s followed by dinner with a local family. Want more time in Bangalore? Secure pre-tour hotel nights through your sales representative. Superior accommodation: Regenta Central Javaji

Discover the highlights of Mysore today, beginning with an exploration of Mysore Palace. We also visit other city landmarks, including St Philomena’s Cathedral, which was designed to resemble Cologne Cathedral in Germany. After, we head into the Chamundi Hills to visit two Hindu temples: the golden Chamundeshwari Temple and Nandi Temple, home to a giant 350-year-old bull statue. Visit Rajendra Art Gallery in the afternoon, which exhibits works by Indian painter Raja Ravi Varma and traditional paintings in the Mysore style. Superior accommodation: Regenta Central Javaji

Drive (three hours) this morning to the remote hill station of Coorg, where tiny springs and coffee, tea and spice estates are spread across the misty slopes. Along the way, we stop in Bylakuppe, the largest Tibetan settlement outside of Tibet, to see the intricate carvings at the Golden Temple. Having completed our journey to Coorg, we join a local guide on a walk through sprawling coffee fields to learn about the history and art of producing coffee. We also learn about the evolution of spice plantations and see how spices are produced, from planting to packaging. Premium accommodation: Coorg Wilderness Resort & Spa

If you’re an early riser, consider one of the complimentary activities offered by the hotel. The Twitchers Trek is an exploration of the surrounding woods led by the in-house naturalist with the chance to see some of the 350-odd bird species that call Coorg home. Or, for a bright start to the morning, join the 30-minute yoga session. After breakfast, head out to meet a Kodava family, descendants of an ancient warrior clan. Your hosts welcome you into their century-old British-style bungalow and teach you how to make pandi, a typical Coorgi curry made with pork and spices on a wood-fired oven. As you cook, learn about the history of the Kodava clan and their martial legacy. Later, dress up in traditional Coorgi attire: full warrior regalia for men and a uniquely draped saree for women. Sit down with your hosts to enjoy your pandi along with a variety of other dishes and home-brewed wines. Good food and great conversations make the experience one to cherish. After lunch, set off on an exploration of the sights in and around Coorg. Begin at Madikeri Fort, first built in the 17th century by Mudduraja, before being reconstructed in granite by Tipu Sultan, a ruler known as the Tiger of Mysore. Later, the British added elements, including a clock tower and porch. Other landmarks we visit include a palace inspired by an English lodge, temples, and Indo-Saracenic-style tombs dedicated to the Kodava royalty and elites. Premium accommodation: Coorg Wilderness Resort & Spa

We drive (6 hours) to Wayanad this morning, a hilly region of Kerala known for its natural beauty. The remainder of the day is at leisure. There is the option of cycling an 8mi (12km) trail across the rural landscapes of Kalpetta, the district capital. Along the way, you can visit the local temples, pepper and coffee estates, lemongrass plantations and a tribal village. Alternatively, enjoy the hotel facilities, strolling through the plantations or taking a dip in the pool. If you fancy a pre-dinner treat, join a chef-led complimentary cooking demonstration. You’ll be guided through the preparation of typical dishes, before sampling a few of the delicious creations. Just let your tour leader know you’d like to join on arrival, so they can book you in (minimum four people required). Premium accommodation: Vythiri Resort Upgrade to a Tree House room today – speak to your sales representative for more details.

Enjoy a scenic 3mi (5km) walk in the Sugandhagiri range today, which should take around 2hr 30min. Our trail immediately plunges into a tea estate, winding along with beautiful views of the Sugandhagiri mountains and excellent landscape photography opportunities. Continue along the forest edge before entering coffee plantations. This area is great for birding with a diverse range of species. The trail then emerges back into the tea estate and we return to the starting point. The remainder of the day is at leisure. If you’re keen to continue exploring the local flora and fauna, join the hotel naturalist for a guided nature walk through the rainforest and the coffee and pepper plantations. Just book through your tour leader or at reception. Premium accommodation: Vythiri Resort Upgrade to a Tree House room today – speak to your sales representative for more details.

Today we transfer (four hours) to Ooty in the Nilgiri Mountains, a one-time summer retreat for the British which is dotted with tea gardens, waterfalls and colonial architecture. In the afternoon, we visit St Stephen’s Church, constructed by the British in the 19th century to coincide with the birthday of King George IV. Later, enjoy leisure time perusing the produce in the local vegetable market before heading back to the hotel. Premium accommodation: Taj Savoy

Today we enjoy a classic Ooty experience, riding a steam train – known locally as the toy train – through the Nilgiri Mountains to Coonoor. Our picturesque one-hour adventure takes us on the 100-year-old Nilgiri Mountain Railway, through the spectacular forested slopes and tea estates of the Nilgiri Mountains. After, we return to Ooty to explore the Government Botanical Garden, which has vibrant displays planted in English-style terraced beds. Then enjoy lunch at the Fernhills Palace, a one-time royal residence resembling a Swiss chalet; perched at one of the highest points in Ooty, this resort has an amazing view of the Nilgiris. We eat in the restaurant, which was once a dance room for entertaining guests. After, we visit Toda village, home to the Toda tribe, where we interact with the community, visit their hut-style homes, known as dogles, and watch a shawl-making demonstration. Premium accommodation: Taj Savoy

Today, we drive (three hours) from Ooty to Coimbatore to take the train to the old port city of Kochi (approximately 4hr 30min). Riding the rails, we pass through villages and towns with a chance to see daily life in full flow. A light packed lunch is also provided. Kochi is the ideal place to learn about Kerala’s unique global exchange, both economic and cultural. While the camel caravans on the Silk Road plodded through the Thar Desert in India’s distant northwest, Spice Route traders looking for black pepper reached Kerala on treacherous sea voyages. Premium accommodation: Fragrant Nature Hotel

Embark on a cultural tour, learning about the lifestyles, dress, food, traditions and religious beliefs of the communities who call the Fort Kochi neighbourhood their home. The experience includes trying delicacies that have made their way to the city from other parts of India and the world. After, we take a sightseeing tour of the city, taking in the adjacent historic neighborhoods of Fort Kochi and Mattancherry. In Fort Kochi, we visit: St Francis Church, where Portuguese explorer Vasco da Gama was first buried after his death in 1524; Santa Cruz Cathedral, originally used as a warehouse by the British; and the fishing nets lining the harbor entrance, which were introduced by the Chinese in the late-14th century. In Mattancherry, we visit Mattancherry Palace, built by the Portuguese in the mid-1500s in a traditional Keralan style, and Jew Town, once home to a Jewish community and now a great place to peruse antique shops and warehouses. You can also visit Thomas Chettan in the Little Queen Embroidery shop to learn about hand lace work, a dying art using bobbin lace. There is the option in the late afternoon to see a performance showcasing the dance styles of Kathakali, Mohiniyattam, and Bharatanatyam, plus the ancient martial art of Kalaripayattu. Premium accommodation: Fragrant Nature

We transfer (two hours) to Alleppey this morning, famous for its serpentine network of backwaters and thriving coir (coconut fibre) industry. Explore the Coir Museum on arrival to learn about the coir-manufacturing process and see articles and artifacts made from coir. Also stroll around the local market and town of Alleppey before we board our houseboat at midday and begin our cruise along the Kerala backwaters. The houseboat cruise is one of the trip highlights – these enchanting boats, built of anjili (wild jack) wood and bamboo, transported goods for hundreds of years. Now they have been decorated and made into comfortable cruise boats. As our boat meanders through tropical vegetation, we can see prolific bird life and gain a different perspective on the village. The cruise takes us along shallow, palm-fringed canals where coconut fibre, coconut meat, and cashews are loaded onto dugout canoes. In the evening, the boat is anchored by the bank and we watch the sun set over the paddy fields. Premium accommodation: Houseboat

Today we travel (1hr 30min) to the village of Kumarakom on Vembanad Lake. We have the rest of the morning free for optional activities such as an Ayurvedic massage (paid for locally). This afternoon, we head out on a village walk. The journey begins in a shikhara boat, cruising to the banks of Manjira village. Through our local village guide and the community, we learn about many of their practices and products, including the art of climbing a coconut tree and coconut leaf weaving. We also see a skilled fisherman cast his net and enjoy a stroll by the green paddies. For a light refreshment, try a freshly cut coconut before learning about (and sampling) fresh Kerala toddy, a specialty of the area. Premium accommodation: Coconut Lagoon

Choose your own adventure today. Options include exploring the Kottayam Heritage Trail (book through your tour leader), discovering a bygone time when a royal capital flourished along the banks of the Meenachi River. You’re joined by a storyteller, who takes you through the highlights of Old Kottayam, including unique geographical features, heritage buildings and centuries-old places of worship. There are also several other options, including a sunset cruise and dance performance, butterfly garden visit, Ayurvedic massage and kayaking (all payable at the hotel). Premium accommodation: Coconut Lagoon
The adventure ends today. Begin your return journey home or, if you’d like a bit more time to explore Kerala, speak to your sales representative about extending your stay.

tourName: Community based holiday in Indian Himalayas
generalInfo:
Welcome! You can customise this tour or add excursions before and after. The tour is safe and comfortable for women travelers, couples, families, and senior citizens.

While sending the request, do remember to leave your contact number. A 15-minute call helps us understand your needs better and speed up the process of sending the right tour plan.

When to visit: From October to November and February to June.

This holiday is in the Kumaon region of Uttarakhand in northern India. It will be a great fit if you like -

1. Community-based experiences led by women's self-help groups. Living in cosy and rustic homestays and hands-on immersion in Himalayan rural life.

2. Wildlife and birding walks with an ornithologist and a wildlife expert. It is perfect if you like conversations on Himalayan ecology, tigers, butterflies and native flowers and herbs.

3. Experiencing the fruit farms of the region, especially between April and May. We have peaches, apricots, plums, pears, and a variety of local wild fruits.

4. Visiting traditional houses made with sustainable architecture and materials. The doors and windows carved in ancient Likhai craft are interesting for those who like traditional architecture and crafts.

5. Interacting with the weavers, bamboo workers, and wood carvers, and trying it hands-on.

6. Eating locally grown organic vegetables cooked using traditional methods.
--

About Us: We are a team from diverse backgrounds in writing, photography, and social and corporate sectors. Our award-winning holidays have a direct social, economic, and cultural impact on the communities. When you contact us, we help you choose the right holiday according to your likes and dislikes. Hope to host you in India soon.

dayInfo.description: We pick you up from Kathgodam railway station and drive to Bhimtal. Your stay for the next few days is with a local family on an organic farm. Some of the interesting things to do here are – 1) Guided village walks which give you a glimpse of the traditional houses including the abandoned ones due to outward migration from the state. Understand how the village idol (Kul Devta) is worshipped and about other traditions. 2) Spend a morning working hands-on in vegetable farms by the river or help the family with the cattle. Bring back the vegetables for lunch if it is the harvesting season. 3) If you are enthusiastic about local cuisine, we can involve you in preparing a meal where you can learn about a local item such as curry, dry vegetables, or an Indian sauce (Chutney). 4) If you decide to extend a day, you can visit Nainital and spend time exploring the markets and lakeside on your own. During this time, you stay in a traditional stone or wooden home for a unique experience.

Your next few days are with a women-led cooperative in the Pithoragarh district. We urge you to take this as a slow travel experience as you drive toward the Tibet and Nepal borders along pristine glacier-fed rivers. This experience is for you if you are interested in – 1) Living with and experiencing rural life with women’s self-help groups that are into wood carving, carpet weaving, and juice making. 2) Learning about the way village communities operate and live with the forest and wildlife. This includes protecting the forest while using it for their daily needs of wood and fodder. 3) Hands-on learning of wood carving and weaving. Other than this, we recommend that you take these few days as they come and not have a day-by-day plan. We would normally involve you in daily activities in the villages from taking care of animals to food collection and more.

Drive down to Almora for the next few days. Almora is a charming hill town and an army cantonment where you can spend the first evening exploring the markets on your own. Thereafter, you can either spend a leisurely day or add more experiences to your kitty. 1) Half-day walking safari of Binsar wildlife sanctuary with an ornithologist who will take your knowledge and experience of flora and fauna to the next level. In the sanctuary, you can expect to see over 200 species of birds and mammals such as the Leopard, Musk Deer, Jungle cat, Wild boar, Black bear, Red fox, macaque, flying squirrel and grey baboon. Return by the afternoon for free time. 2) Take a day trip to the Jageshwar group of Shaivite temples through the stunning oak forests.

After an exciting journey into the Himalayan hinterlands, it is time to relax by the river at Jim Corbett national park. Depending on your interest, we can adjust the number of days in the national park. While the national park is known for Tigers, our full-day tour will take your experience far beyond as we discuss the other plant and animal species, and the regional flora and herbs. Your stay will be in a sustainably built home for a truly relaxing end to this experience. On Day 12, we either drop you to the nearest railway station or drive you to Delhi for onward journey.

tourName: Cultural and rural tour of East India
generalInfo:
Dear future traveller :)

Welcome! We are happy to see that you are interested in this tour. It can be customized according to your preference. We understand that you may have choices which we may not have mentioned in the itinerary. But it can always be included the way you want and according to your budget.
**
Best time: All around the year except July - September.
**
This culturally immersive holiday in the Eastern states of India (Sikkim, Bengal and Assam) will take you to the remote villages of Limbu, Lepcha, Mishing and Bhutanese tribes. Some of the unique things you can experience in this holiday are -

1. We do storytelling rather than sightseeing for you. It gives you a much deeper connect because you come to know about the people, their language, food, music, beliefs and the history
2. You live with families for a more personal experience in Sikkim, Assam and Bengal. You may notice the stark difference in cultures, family structure, and beliefs within such a small area of India as you travel from Bengal to Sikkim
3. You can participate in hands on activities like farming with the family, learning few tips on making carpets, and cooking local cuisine
4. Sikkim is the first state in India to follow 100% organic farming. You will be living first at the base of Kanchenjunga mountain, and then near Maenam wildlife sanctuary
5. Experience the unique Vaishnavite culture of Assam through the eyes of locals. You may see 2-3 generations of priests performing rituals in morning and evening and their daily chores in monasteries. You can also experience the daily life of Mishing tribe which involves fishing, farming, weaving in their homes, making masks or baskets out of bamboo
6. We involve you in dances and songs that are done by locals as an immersive experience. You can interact with the artist, know their story and even learn few steps
7. During the two days in Kolkata, you may have diverse experiences like seeing how street food is made, jewelers at work, remains of the colonial architecture, priests in temples doing evening prayers, traditional rickshaw pullers, or women shopping in shops of old Kolkata. It is not just a sightseeing tour, but an immersive storytelling experience on Bengali culture
8. India is a vast country with so many dimensions to a single region. Your tour is designed to be executed at a steady medium pace, so that you can stop and absorb the life of locals without rushing through it

About us - We come from diverse background of travel writing, photography, social sector and corporate experience. We are well travelled in India, and understand the villages, its people, and the grass root issues of our country well. Therefore the trips are designed to directly provide environmental, economic and social benefit to the local community. Hope to see you in India soon.

dayInfo.description: Arrive directly in Kolkata and check-in with your Bengali hosts. Being in India is an intense experience. Spend the next two days experiencing the Bengali culture and British colonial history of Kolkata. Explore the various rustic, religious, culinary and colonial stories of Kolkata. Explore with us the streets and those obscure food joints of old Kolkata which are not to be missed if a traveler really wants to experience the culture like a local. Through our storytelling, you not only see the place and taste the food, but also live its story and history. || Highlights: a) Culinary trail, b) Colonial architectural remains in old Kolkata, c) Bengali temples and spiritual expedition, d) Bengali cooking experience and more

Today we take early morning flight from Kolkata to Bagdogra. Travel by road to Sikkim to spend next few days with Bhutanese family. Bhutanese people are migrants from Bhutan before Sikkim merged into India. Although it is a small community, but it holds position of great importance among the Sikkimese. Over the next few days, experience the Bhutanese cooking, dances and folk songs, hikes to Maenam wildlife sanctuary which is home of deer, fox and rare red Panda. Know about the traditional tribal religions, and participate in daily chores of the Bhutanese people which include farming, butter making and local crafts. || Highlights: a) Experience with Bhutanese family, b) Bhutanese dance and music, c) Hiking and wildlife, d) Storytelling on local tribes and religions, e) Wellness experience and body healing, f) community work towards local crafts and more

Drive down to your next destination to live with Limbu tribal family. On the way we will stop at the beautiful Temi tea gardens. West Sikkim is home of Limbu, Lepcha and Nepali people. Spend time in the lap of mighty Kangchenjunga Mountain with us knowing the local folk tales. See traditional ways of organic farming and bee keeping. Know about how traditional animists live in harmony with Buddhism and visit some of these tribal families in their houses. || Highlights: a) traditional cooking experience, b) hands on organic farming, c) introduction to the Buddhist monasteries d) hiking in forest with visit to lakes of spiritual value including Khecheperi lake, e) storytelling on tribal customs of the village, and on Limbu and Lepcha tribes, f) know about indigenous religions
Road trip back to Bagdogra with onward flight to Guwahati. Overnight stay will be in Guwahati

We depart for Kaziranga national park by road. || Highlights: a) go for elephant safari in habitats of Indian Rhino and water buffalo, b) experience the jeep safari with focus on birding, their nesting patterns, c) take a boat ride in Brahmaputra river and see the landscape of rural Assam, and life of locals, d) know how Kaziranga national park has done work in conservation of Rhino and Elephants

Today we depart for Majuli Island by boat. It is the largest river island in the world that is threatened by erosion due to annual flooding. It is the home to Vaishnavism (sect of Hinduism that worships lord Vishnu), and has numerous folktales around its Mising tribes, villages and monasteries. || Highlights: a) storytelling on Vaishnavism, b) visit the Vaishnavite monasteries and participate in one of the traditional ceremonies, c) village walk with local tribes, d) exposure to local handicrafts including weaving, mask making and basket making

Drop to Jorhat airport after breakfast for return journey to Kolkata by flight (we are taking flights only where distances are too large to be done by train in time), and international flight to home country.

tourName: Cultural and rural tour of North East India
placesVisited: Exploring the states of West Bengal and Meghalaya, Kolkata, Shillong, capital of Meghalaya, Mawphlang, in the East Khasi Hills, Two days staying with the Khasi people, Community day learning about weaving, Explore the sacred forests around Cherrapunjee, Stay in homestays with welcoming families, Nature walks and farmers’ markets
generalInfo:
Have you ever seen a bridge that was alive before? Living root bridges – made from the intertwined roots of rubber trees – are common in Meghalaya state in Norther East India. And bridging the gaps between interesting cultures is common in this fascinating tour.

This tailor made tour can be changed to suit you, but why not start in Kolkata – touring the city by its history, its cuisine, its artisan markets or its temples? As you’ll be travelling without a group, you have the freedom to choose what most interests you about Bengali culture in West Bengal.

Next you’ll move to Meghalaya, getting to know the state first by the markets of its capital, Shillong, and then by its nature: the East Khasi Hills and the sacred forests of Cherrapunjee, spanned by living root bridges and full of walking trails, waterfalls and caves.

This trip is fantastic for immersing you in a different culture to your own, thanks to its careful use of community based tourism. Many tribes in the state of Meghalaya operate in a very rare matrilineal society, meaning that women have a dominant role, inherit the property, and pass down their names.

There are plenty of opportunities for hands-on experiences, whether you want to learn to weave, or participate in agricultural activities on the small farms, or shop for food in the markets – but there’s also time spent simply meeting people and speaking to them about their lives.

On your route you’ll be staying with families in homestays. Living with a family, you’ll get to know the rhythms of day-to-day life. The families rotate their hosting duties, so that the profit, and the effort, is shared. Ten percent of your trip fee goes direct to the community.

dayInfo.description: Fly into Kolkata and check-in with your Bengali hosts where you begin to experience the Indian hospitality yet have your privacy. The first day is available for relaxing, recovering from the jetlag, and warming up to the city. Spend the next day with us on the city tour. Depending on your preference, you can choose a tour of Bengali veg and non-veg food, colonial history, artisan's markets, and Bengali temples.

Take early morning flight from Kolkata to spend the next two days in Shillong, the vibrant capital city of Meghalaya. Your stay will be in a charming yet comfortable home to kickstart your experience on a high note. Meghalaya is one of the most developed states of North East, yet its people are very close to their land and culture. It is inhabited by Khasi, Garo and Jaintia tribes. Highlights of the next two days include visiting farmer's markets, tasting traditional Khasi cuisine, city tours, and museums. We will take you to the areas inhabited by locals where you can get a sense of their daily life. Shillong is the only big city in Meghalaya, and many people from nearby villages come here in their traditional attire to trade their goods on daily basis. It is worth spending some time doing the photography and interacting with them. Spend the evenings in one of the beautiful cafes of the city.

We move further towards the vast pastures of Mawphlang and the sacred forests. Our base for the next few days will be Sohra. Over the next 3 days, explore the sacred forests and perhaps go for a longer David Scott's walking trail. If you are not into long walking trails, we explore the numerous stunning waterfalls and caves in the region. We also visit the numerous living root bridges, an icon of Meghalaya that exist nowhere else on the planet. If you love adventure, there is also an option to trek and go for caving in 4x4 vehicles and rafts.

We spend the next two days away from the main civilization with the indigenous animist people of Meghalaya. These people still follow the native animist traditions before Christianity. The two days comprise of living in traditional Khasi huts with village walks and community interactions understanding their folk tales. If you visit in the month of November, you also get to see some of their beautiful festivals and participate in them with the village.
We drive back to Shillong for an overnight stay. The evening will be at leisure where you can explore the city on your own or just relax.

Spend a day with the community that practices ethical weaving. Learn how they source and extract natural dyes from the forests. See the process of manual spinning, dyeing, and weaving followed by a traditional lunch with the community.
Departure to the airport. Or you can extend this holiday with a wildlife experience in Assam.

tourName: Cultural and rural tour of Rajasthan
generalInfo:
If you are dreaming of something more than just ticking off tourist spots, this journey through western India might be just what you are looking for. It is designed for travellers like you—curious, thoughtful, and keen to experience India in a way that feels real, not rushed.

Over the course of the trip, you shall explore Rajasthan’s incredible contrasts: from the stillness of rural villages to the grandeur of ancient forts, from intimate food tastings to hands-on textile sessions with master artisans. You will meet locals, hear stories that do not make it into guidebooks.

Best time to visit: September to April

There is no rushed sightseeing or changing hands between agents. Just you, exploring at your own rhythm, supported by someone who truly knows and cares about this land.

Stay in heritage homes with local families or charming, eco-conscious properties. It's not luxury for the sake of it, but comfort that is rooted in people, place, and purpose.

We travel responsibly, working with local communities, supporting artisans, and creating space for real conversations. You'll meet Rajasthan’s tribal groups, learn traditional crafts, and get a feel for life that’s often unseen by tourists.

There is no fixed itinerary. What you see below is a sample draft. We will shape it around your interests before you book.

You won’t be passed from one contact to another. Someone from our small, experienced team will be with you from start to finish. We come from backgrounds in travel writing and photography, and we have spent years on the road here ourselves.

No hidden costs. Just clear planning, honest advice, and a warm welcome.

Over the years, we've crafted meaningful, story-rich travel experiences across India. With backgrounds in writing, photography, and corporate life, we know the country deeply. We're transparent about costs—no surprises. And we’d love to help you explore India in a way that’s thoughtful, personal, and truly memorable.

dayInfo.description: Begin your bespoke journey in Jaipur, the gateway to Rajasthan's timeless charm, and move onward to the enchanting Shahpura village. Your stay here offers a rare glimpse into an authentic, unhurried village lifestyle. Over the next two days, immerse yourself in vibrant culture with curated village walks, savoring the picturesque surroundings and captivating stories of local life. Discover exquisite craftsmanship at the bustling local markets, renowned for their intricate pottery and artisanal leather goods - each piece a testament to Rajasthan's artistic legacy. Experience sophisticated culinary delights with a farm-to-table feast crafted from the freshest locally sourced ingredients that blend luxury with authenticity.

Enjoy a three-night stay in Jaipur at a luxurious heritage hotel that perfectly blends history with comfort. Explore the city’s lively street and craft markets, famous for leather goods, glazed pottery, intricate jewelry, and vibrant textiles. Take a guided culinary tour to savour authentic local vegetarian dishes and discover the rich flavours of the Pink City. Experience Jaipur’s architectural wonders with private visits to the iconic Amber Fort, City Palace, and other historic landmarks of Rajasthan’s former capital. For textile enthusiasts, indulge in an exclusive hands-on workshop to create your own unique fabric designs inspired by Jaipur’s centuries-old artisan traditions. This thoughtfully curated Jaipur itinerary offers a rich mix of luxury, culture, and immersive experiences, ideal for discerning travellers seeking an authentic Rajasthan adventure.

Spend two nights in a beautifully preserved 17th-century mansion in Bundi, a hidden gem in Rajasthan. Wander through vibrant lanes ideal for street photography and visit Bundi Palace, famous for its exquisite organic miniature paintings. Connect with skilled local artisans in exclusive workshops covering traditional painting, blacksmithing, and silversmithing. Explore ancient villages and Mesolithic-era cave dwellings, steeped in history. Meet the Kalbeliya and Bhil tribes to experience Rajasthan’s rich tribal heritage firsthand. For nature lovers, Bundi offers peaceful birdwatching and wildlife spotting in a serene rural setting. This authentic Rajasthan escape is perfect for cultural travellers from the UK, US, and Australia seeking an immersive, off-the-beaten-track journey.

Discover the charm of Udaipur with a three-night stay at a lakeside heritage hotel, perfectly blending comfort and tradition. This relaxed itinerary offers a balance of guided tours and leisure time for personal exploration. Begin with a guided sunrise walk through Udaipur’s bustling old town, exploring vibrant spice, textile, flower, and vegetable markets—ideal for street photography and cultural immersion. Spend your free time visiting the magnificent Udaipur City Palace and the scenic hilltop Sajjangarh Fort. Enjoy fine dining at rustic lakeside restaurants serving authentic Rajasthani cuisine paired with breathtaking views. Your time spent in Udaipur combines curated experiences with the freedom to discover at your own pace—perfect for those seeking a genuine, immersive Rajasthan adventure.

Discover the enchanting village of Ghanerao, where historic havelis tell stories of Rajasthan’s rich past. On the way, visit the stunning Ranakpur Jain Temple, a masterpiece of intricate architecture. During your stay, embark on an exclusive jeep safari through leopard territory, offering a rare chance to see Rajasthan’s elusive wildlife in its natural habitat. Immerse yourself in local culture with a visit to a nearby nomadic community, gaining insight into their traditional way of life. This carefully crafted village experience combines adventure, culture, and community-based tourism in off-the-beaten-path Rajasthan.

Continue your journey to Chanoud, a peaceful village where you enjoy warm Rajasthani hospitality while exploring the tranquil countryside on a private, guided walk. Visit serene temples, a village school, and artisan shops showcasing traditional crafts still practiced today. This intimate experience offers a rare chance to connect deeply with rural life and appreciate the simplicity and charm of Rajasthan’s heartland.

Continue your journey to Jodhpur with the choice to stay in the vibrant city or immerse yourself in village life with a nearby tribal community. Over two days, discover the heritage-rich Blue City by visiting local homes and experiencing everyday life firsthand. For a unique cultural touch, meet skilled artisan potters or set off on a thrilling desert adventure in Osian. If time allows, consider extending your trip to Jaisalmer, a stunning desert city known for its historic forts, rich culture, and breathtaking landscapes. As they say, time is never enough to visit India.
Departure: We drop you to the airport or railway station for onward journey.

tourName: Delhi to Darjeeling by rail tour
generalInfo: This 18-day India by Rail tour takes you through Delhi, Varanasi, and West Bengal, blending history, spirituality, and cultural experiences. Highlights include exploring Dilli Haat INA, a vibrant market showcasing Indian handicrafts and cuisine, and an evening cooking demonstration and dinner, where you’ll learn to prepare authentic local dishes. Explore Old Delhi by cycle or battery rickshaw, visit the stunning Fatehpuri Mosque, and experience the spiritual atmosphere of Gurudwara Bangla Sahib. Discover architectural marvels like Humayun’s Tomb, Qutub Minar, and India Gate. In Varanasi, witness the mesmerising Evening Aarti Ceremony on the Ganga Ghat—a truly unforgettable experience. Glide along the River Ganges at sunrise on a peaceful boat ride, taking in the soul-stirring atmosphere of Varanasi. Visit key landmarks like Bharat Mata Mandir, Banaras Hindu University, and the sacred Kashi Vishwanath Temple. Explore the Weavers’ Colony, where skilled artisans create intricate Banarasi silk. In Kolkata, admire the elegant Marble Palace, explore the artisan hub of Kumartuli, and browse the famous College Street Book Market. Enjoy a nostalgic tram ride from College Street to Esplanade, soaking in the city’s old-world charm, before unwinding at the iconic Indian Coffee House. In Murshidabad, explore the grandeur of the Hazarduari Palace Museum, the historic Imambara, and the mighty Jahankosha Cannon. Visit the stunning Nashipur Rajbati and the ancient Katra Mosque, before indulging in an authentic Shehrwali cuisine dinner, known for its rich vegetarian delicacies. In Murshidabad, explore the grandeur of the Hazarduari Palace Museum, the historic Imambara, and the mighty Jahankosha Cannon. Visit the stunning Nashipur Rajbati and the ancient Katra Mosque, before indulging in an authentic Shehrwali cuisine dinner, known for its rich vegetarian delicacies. With a mix of heritage sites, local traditions, and unforgettable experiences, this journey offers a true taste of India.

dayInfo.description: Depart the UK.
Arrival in Delhi. Transfer to accommodation. Two nights in Delhi.
Morning Sightseeing - Old Delhi. Afternoon Sightseeing - New Delhi.

Transfer to Delhi railway station. Train Delhi – Varanasi. Depart 06:00 arrive Varanasi 14:00 [Doesn’t operate on Thursdays]. Light snacks and lunch on board. Transfer to hotel. Evening boat-ride on river Ganges for Aarti.
Sunrise boat ride on river Ganges. After breakfast, visit Bharat Mata Temple, BHU; Kashi-Vishwanath Temple & weavers colony. Rest of the day at leisure.

Early morning village excursion on the outskirts of the city. Return to hotel for breakfast. After breakfast excursion to Sarnath. Afternoon at leisure. Evening train to Kolkata. Depart Varanasi 20:48 arrive Howrah 08:05 [Arrives next day]
Arrive and transfer to hotel. Afternoon Sightseeing - North Kolkata. Tram ride from College Street to Esplanade [If trams are operational].

Morning heritage walk of Dalhousie Square. After breakfast visit St. Paul’s Cathedral, Victoria Memorial, Alipore Jail Museum [both closed on Monday] and Fort William [from outside]. Lunch at Bomti’s Residence. [cost included] Late afternoon boat cruise on river Hooghly.

Morning visit Flower Market and Mullick Ghat. After breakfast take a ride on India's first under water metro from Esplanade to Howrah railway station. Visit the railway station, Rail Museum (closed on Thursday) and Weavers Studio. Lunch at Trincas. [On direct basis] After lunch visit Indian Museum (closed on Monday).
Train to Azimganj. Depart 07:50 arrive Aziimganj 12:00 (Doesn't operate Saturdays and Sundays). Afternoon Pottery; shola art & kantha stitching session.
Morning visit to Hazarduari Palace; Imambara; Jahankosha Canon; Nashipur Rajbati & Katra Mosque. Afternoon pottery; shola art & kantha stitching session. Evening Shehrwali-cuisine dinner.
Full day visit to Tantipara & Islampor. [Approx. 5-6 hrs experience]. Evening tea by the river.
Morning at leisure. Late Afternoon drive to Malda [Approx. 3 hrs]. Train to New Jalpaiguri. Depart 19:35 arrive at New Jalpaiguri 22:55. (Lunch included and packed dinner).
After breakfast take the toy-train from New Jalpaiguri to Darjeeling. Depart New Jalpaiguri 10:00 and arrive at Darjeeling 17:30. Transfer to hotel.
Sunrise visit to Tiger Hill. After breakfast visit Himalayan Institute of Mountaineering [Closed on Thursdays]. The Mall Road & local market.
A short joy ride on the steam-engine toy train, followed by Ghoom Monastery. Lunch at a tea estate with a visit to a tea factory and tea tasting.
After breakfast drive from Darjeeling to New Jalpaiguri [approx. 3 hrs]. Connect with a train to Howrah. Depart 15:05 arrive at Kolkata at 22:35. (Packed dinner on own). Transfer to hotel.
Transfer to International airport for your flight home.

tourName: Delhi to Kathmandu holiday
generalInfo:
Journey through North India to Nepal, witnessing sacred sites and cultural highlights. From the majestic beauty of the Taj Mahal to the pink glow of Jaipur, the tranquil waters of the Ganges and the holy majesty of Varanasi, this full-on tour takes in North India's icons. Destined for Nepal, we explore the temples, bazaars, and nature of the Himalayan beauty, too.

Indian icons - Watch the sun rise over the marble dome of the Taj Mahal and witness the pink beauty of Jaipur.
Sail down the Ganges - Drift down the Ganges, camping on its banks, before entering Varanasi on its sacred waters.
Explore Nepal - Uncover majestic Nepal, searching for the one-horned rhino and uncovering the Royal Palace.
2026 - We have made some changes, please refer to the updated itinerary for 2026

dayInfo.title: Join tour in Delhi - city tour of New Delhi
dayInfo.description: : Our tour starts in New Delhi, India's bustling capital, where old meets new and you can catch glimpses of a bygone era at every turn. For those arriving in time, our tour leader will meet you in the hotel reception at 1.30pm for a welcome meeting followed by an afternoon city tour. We'll visit Qutab Minar, the tallest stone tower in India and Humayun's Tomb dating from the Mughal Dynasty. We also drive past the imposing India Gate (war memorial arch), the Parliament buildings and the Rashtrapati Bhawan, the President's residence. If you'd like an airport transfer today, you'll need to arrive into New Delhi's Indira Gandhi International Airport (DEL), which is around a 40-minute drive from the hotel. If you'd like to join the city tour, you need to arrive at the hotel by 1.30pm. If you're booking your own flights, we recommend giving yourself at least one hour to clear the airport and 45 minutes to transfer to the hotel. The latest your flight should arrive is 12pm. If you miss the welcome meeting, the tour leader will catch you up as soon as possible.

dayInfo.title: Explore Old Delhi's spice market and take train to Jaipur
dayInfo.description: : Compared to New Delhi, the Old City is much closer to the image conjured up by Rudyard Kipling. This morning, a local guide will show us around Old Delhi by metro and on foot, culminating with a jamboree of deafening barter at Chandni Chowk Bazaar. You will also get the chance to visit the Sheesh Ganj Sahib, a historic Sikh place of worship near to the Chandni Chowk Bazaar. Later in the afternoon, we'll transfer to New Delhi station for the train journey to Jaipur, arriving in the evening. Sometimes called the 'Pink City', Jaipur was first painted terracotta pink by Maharajah Sawai Ram Singh to celebrate the visit of Prince Albert in 1853.

dayInfo.title: Visit Jaipur's Amber Fort and City Palace Museum
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we'll visit the once mighty Rajput capital of Amber (traditionally known as Amber Fort) and its fortress. Lying at the mouth of a rocky mountain gorge, overlooking Maotha Lake, the fort is a stunning creation of white marble and red sandstone that combines Hindu and Muslim ornamentation, including the mirrored halls of the Sheesh Mahal. It was from these towering walls that the Kachchawahas ruled over their kingdom for seven centuries, until its importance was eclipsed by nearby Jaipur. We'll also take in the unique Hawa Mahal, the famous Palace of the Winds, whose extraordinary façade of red and pink sandstone towers five stories above the city streets. Built at the end of the 18th century, its 935 windows were designed to allow the women of the harem to gaze out on the city scene below without themselves being seen, the openings also create a refreshing breeze (hawa), which kept the palace cool in the hot summer months. We'll spend some time exploring the lavish and well-preserved City Palace. Here, we'll find a fine collection of textiles, costumes, and armoury. Later this afternoon, we'll visit the extraordinary Jantar Mantar - a star-gazing observatory built by Jai Singh, the great Maharajah-astronomer.

dayInfo.title: Jeep safari in Ranthambore National Park
dayInfo.description: : Leaving Jaipur, we'll take the train to Sawai Modhopur, the gateway to Ranthambore National Park. One of the best of India's 'Project Tiger' conservation projects, Ranthambore was once the private reserve of the Maharajahs of Jaipur and covers nearly 400 square kilometres of lush jungle, turquoise lakes and ancient temples that provide a haven for crocodiles, leopards, tigers and 300 species of birds. During the dry season from September to May, when water is scarce, the animals stay close to the lakes and rivers, giving us the ideal opportunity to spot these elusive animals. We'll take a game drive into the park this afternoon.

dayInfo.title: Morning safari at Ranthambore and continue to Agra
dayInfo.description: : This morning we have an early start as we try our luck again at spotting the elusive Royal Bengal Tiger. We'll then return to the hotel for breakfast before we catch our train to Agra. Arriving in Agra, we'll take an hour transfer to our hotel. Tomorrow we're up bright and early to explore what is considered one of the most beautiful buildings in the world.

dayInfo.title: Visit the Taj Mahal and afternoon at leisure
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we'll have an early start to see the sun rise over the marble dome of the Taj Mahal. Built by the emperor Shah Jahan to honour the memory of his beloved wife Mumtaz, the building took 22 years to complete and was once described by Rudyard Kipling as 'the embodiment of all things pure'. Built from marble and decorated with the most exquisite inlay work, the Taj Mahal required the labour of 20,000 men and is estimated to have cost something in the region of 3 million rupees (around $70 million today). Once we've witnessed the majesty of the Taj Mahal, we'll journey on to Delhi. This afternoon, we'll visit the Agra Fort. Built by Akbar the Great, the fort stands in an imposing position on a bend in the Yamuna River with views of the Taj Mahal further along its banks. The rest of the afternoon is free. You might want to revisit the Taj Mahal at sunset, or head to the Itimad-ud-Daulah (Baby Taj).

dayInfo.title: Morning train to Allahabad. Sail to Varanasi
dayInfo.description: : We are up bright and early this morning as we head to the train station in time for our train to Allahabad. After arriving late morning, we'll journey by road for approximately three to four hours to the sacred River Ganges. Once we reach the water, we'll start our boat trip downstream. The next two days will give a unique glimpse at rural life in India and a welcome chance to relax and unwind. We'll float peacefully through the Gangetic plain to Varanasi, passing villages and ornate temples, fields of wheat and rice paddies, and stunning sunsets. The traditional wooden boats take up to four passengers plus two crew, who have all grown up living and working on or around the river. We'll make regular comfort breaks by the side of the river and there will be a 'support boat' which doubles as the kitchen following closely behind, with a chef on board preparing your lunch and dinner. You can also buy drinks onboard. For our overnight stop, we'll camp on a sandbank in the middle of the Ganges in two-man tents. The location we use varies according to local conditions, but wherever we stop you'll be able to relax over dinner and stargaze before bed. Our wild camping is a simple but unique experience - facilities are basic and toilets are set up in a single pop-up tent.

dayInfo.title: Arrive in Varanasi
dayInfo.description: : Today we'll continue our journey down river to the holy city of Varanasi where we'll disembark at Asi Ghat and transfer to our hotel. Varanasi (Benares) has been the centre of Hinduism since the dawn of history, its age is contemporary with Babylon and Thebes. Often known as 'Kashi' (City of Light) by Hindus it attracts over a million pilgrims each year - many of whom come to spend their last years here in the holy city. This evening, you can return to the ghats to witness the evening aarti ceremony when the Ganga is venerated with a display of light and sound.

dayInfo.title: Explore Varanasi and Sarnath
dayInfo.description: : This morning we'll take an early morning boat trip along the Ganges to see the Hindu devout bathing in its sacred waters. We'll then pay a visit to nearby Sarnath. Having gained enlightenment at Bodh Gaya Buddha came to Sarnath to preach his first sermon. The city was at its peak in the 5th century, when it was a respected centre of religious activity, learning and art. Muslim invaders destroyed much of the city and today remains of several monasteries and stupas can be seen. The afternoon is free to explore Varanasi's labyrinth of streets, bazaars and temples at your own pace. In the evening, there might be the option to take in a classical musical performance.

dayInfo.title: Journey to Lumbini
dayInfo.description: : We have a long yet interesting journey today (around 8 hours), as we head north across the Gangetic Plains villages to the Nepalese border at Sonauli. First, we'll take a train from Varanasi to the town of Gorphpur. This is the furthest we can travel by train, so we'll switch to a bus and drive the remaining distance to Sonauli. We'll walk through customs and immigration into Nepal and meet our Nepalese bus which will transfer us to Lumbini to spend the night.

dayInfo.title: Explore Buddha's birthplace
dayInfo.description: : We'll start our day with a rickshaw sightseeing tour of Lumbini accompanied by a local guide. We'll have the opportunity to visit the birthplace of the Buddha, the Peace Lamp. and the Monastery of Peace pagoda. From here, we'll drive (approximately seven hours) through the Terai, the narrow-forested lowland strip that stretches the full width of the southern border of Nepal. We'll stop in Butwal en route so we can pick up some lunch and then aim to arrive at Chitwan in the late afternoon. The oldest and best known of the national parks in Nepal, Chitwan consists of swamp, tall elephant grass and dense forest, and is a natural habitat for tiger, the rare one-horned Indian rhino, leopard, and sloth bear to name but a few. Once we arrive at the park, we'll take a short afternoon village walk close to the park to orient ourselves.

dayInfo.title: Search for wild rhino in Chitwan National Park
dayInfo.description: : Once a private hunting ground, Chitwan is now a National Park, with thick tree cover and tall elephant grass sheltering a wealth of animals, most famously the one-horned rhino. Today we'll be kept busy with plenty of activities available, including jeep safaris to search out the rhino, bird watching, jungle walks and canoe trips along the Rapti River. The river trip will be dependent on the water level. Floating silently down the Rapti River allows us to spot many varieties of water birds and other wildlife. On a nature walk in the company of trained native naturalists, you can walk along trails in the less densely forested parts of the park. An early morning bird-watching walk near the river will reveal many of the 450 bird species that can be found in the park, especially kingfisher. A trained naturalist will help us get the most out of these excursions.

dayInfo.title: Morning birdwatching and drive to Pokhara
dayInfo.description: : After a final early morning walk through the park, we'll leave for Pokhara. The drive will take around eight hours depending on the traffic, and we'll take a packed lunch to have along the way. We pass through the bustling town of Naryanghat Bazaar, then head north beside the River Trisuli to the 'wild west' town of Mugling at the confluence of the Marsyandi and Trisuli rivers, before reaching our final destination for today. Pokhara is a relaxed town situated on the banks of Lake Phewa Tal and set beneath the Annapurna Range. The afternoon is left free to wander through the town, to pick up some souvenirs at the many Tibetan handicraft stalls or just relax by the lakeside after the journey.

dayInfo.title: Walk to the Peace Pagoda
dayInfo.description: : After breakfast this morning we'll stretch our legs walking up through small villages to the Japanese Peace Pagoda. This lookout point offers views across to the Annapurna Range and back down to the town of Pokhara. After enjoying the views, we'll walk back following a different path and stop to visit the Tibetan Tashiling Monastery. The afternoon is free to relax in Pokhara, where it's possible to take short walks around the lake. There's also the option to visit the Mountain Museum, an interesting museum dedicated to the history of Himalayan Mountaineering.

dayInfo.title: Drive to Kathmandu
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we'll drive to Kathmandu (approximately ten hours away). We'll retrace our route back to Mugling, then continue heading east. Once we reach Naubise the road starts to climb and reaches a pass on the Kathmandu valley rim via a series of breathtaking zigzags before descending to the city. We might have the chance to take an optional trip to the Manakamana temple near Kurintar, time permitting.

dayInfo.title: Walking tour in Kathmandu
dayInfo.description: : This morning, we'll have a walking tour of this historic city, visiting the bazaar and temples of old Kathmandu, accompanied by a local Nepali guide. Much of the day-to-day life of Kathmandu takes place in the local bazaar: a fascinating mixture of people selling spices; potters spinning their wheels; rickshaw wallahs honking their horns and the ever-present sacred cow wandering amongst it all. We'll end up in Durbar Square at the heart of the city. In the afternoon we'll plan to visit the temple of Pashupatinath on the banks of the Bagmati River, the holiest Hindu shrine in Nepal, and also to visit Bodnath, the largest stupa in the country and a destination for Buddhist pilgrims from all over Nepal.

dayInfo.title: Trip ends Kathmandu
dayInfo.description: : Our tour ends at our hotel in Kathmandu.

tourName: Delhi to Kathmandu tour
placesVisited: Delhi, Agra, Orchha, Allahabad and Anand Bhavan, Ganges boat trip, Varanasi, Lumbini, Chitwan National Park and safaris, Kathmandu
generalInfo:
Spend 15 days travelling from India to Nepal overland, beginning in Delhi and ending in Kathmandu, taking in the sacred sites, holy cities and Mughal architecture of India, before heading into Nepal to discover wildlife in its wetland reserves, and soak up the hustle and bustle of its capital.

Begin your journey in Delhi. Explore on foot and by cycle rickshaw, seeing ancient temples standing against vibrant billboards advertising Bollywood films. Travel on to Agra, one of the prettiest cities in the world and home to the beautiful Red Fort, then to temple-filled Orchha. You will also take a sunrise sail along the Ganges, camping by its shores overnight. Of course, a visit to the Taj Mahal and the holy city of Varanasi are essential, too, before arriving in Nepal. Here, visit sacred Lumbini and its Maya Devi Temple, the site where Lord Buddha is thought to have been born. Then you have the chance to come face-to-face with black-horned rhinos in Chitwan National Park before exploring the crowded temples, markets and bazaars of Kathmandu.

You’ll be travelling in a small group (max 12 people) with a tour leader and staying in a range of accommodation, including hotels, lodges and guesthouses, with a night camping and an overnight sleeper train. Travel is via a mix of transport, from auto rickshaw and canoe, through to jeep, van and private vehicle. You’ll meet pilgrims, villagers, holy men and shopkeepers, getting to know people and customs as you go. For those wanting to travel by land between these two very different neighbours, this is the perfect journey.

dayInfo.title: Delhi.
dayInfo.description: Namaste! Welcome to India. Your adventure begins in Delhi – India’s busy capital city, known for its street food, bazaars, museums and galleries. Meet your local leader and fellow travellers at a welcome meeting at 1 pm today. After, follow your leader as they show you through the streets of Old Delhi before you hop in a rickshaw for a different view. During your excursion, you’ll visit the Jama Masjid – Delhi's oldest mosque and one of its most impressive buildings – and the Sheeshganj Gurudwara (Sikh Temple) to learn about the Sikh religion. This evening is yours to take in the energy of Delhi and get ready for the adventure ahead, perhaps over a tasty Indian meal with your group members.

dayInfo.title: Agra.
dayInfo.description: This morning, depart Delhi via train to Agra – home to India’s most iconic building, the Taj Mahal. This 17th-century palace was built in the style of Mughal architecture and surrounded by trimmed English gardens. You’ll get your chance to see it up close on a rickshaw tour across Agra, whizzing past the city’s many important sites and busy chowks (marketplaces). Later this afternoon, visit Akbar's Mausoleum – a red sandstone and marble tomb built to honour one of the great Mughal emperors, Akbar. Inlaid with intricate patterns, both inside and out, the tomb is another of Agra’s impressively striking monuments.

dayInfo.title: Agra – Lalitpur – Chanderi.
dayInfo.description: Today, you’ll get a chance to see the beauty of the Agra Fort up close on a tour with a local guide. Considered one of the most impressive forts in India, over time, the Agra Fort has been used as a military base, a palace and a prison. Later today, hop on a train to Lalitpur – a private transfer will then pick you up from the station and take you to your hotel in Chanderi. The rest of the evening is free to relax.

dayInfo.title: Chanderi.
dayInfo.description: Get to know Chanderi on a guided tour with your leader this morning. With a history stretching back to the 11th century and a strategic location between the Bundelkhand and Malwa borders, the city is full old palace, forts, mosques, temples and mausoleums. Take a wander around the cobbled streets of Old Town, learn about the significance of the grand Badal Mahal Gate and visit Jama Masjid – a 15th century mosque dating back to the Mughal era. The rest of the day is free to unwind or explore at your own pace – your leader can offer tips on things to do.

dayInfo.title: Chanderi – Orchha – Allahabad (overnight train).
dayInfo.description: Take a private transfer to the town of Orchha. Located on the banks of the Betwa River, Orchha was once a hunting area that became a site of 16th-century palaces and temples. Maybe grab some lunch, then head to Orchha Palace for a guided tour. Built by Bir Sing Deo for his friend Jehangir, the great Mughal ruler, the palace is an important landmark here. While inside, look out for the grand Iwans (domes) that were built large enough to allow the movement of war elephants. You’ll also have access to day rooms to freshen up. For dinner, you’ll dive into the region’s flavours at a cooking demonstration and feast on your creations. Then, it’s time to hop aboard an overnight train to Allahabad – the starting point for your Ganges boat journey.

dayInfo.title: River Ganges.
dayInfo.description: Arrive in Allahabad this morning. You’ll have access to day rooms to freshen up after the journey before making your way to the Ganges for a cruise on a small riverboat. The Ganges is very important in India, not just because it’s sacred in Hinduism but also because it connects millions of people to their livelihoods. A support crew will be on hand as you cruise the waterway, passing villages and watching life along the banks. When you arrive at your campsite, sit back and relax, or you might like to read a book or play some cricket. End the day watching the sunset over a vegetarian meal prepared by the boatmen.

dayInfo.title: Varanasi.
dayInfo.description: Leaving your boats at Chunar, transfer by private vehicle to Varanasi – one of the holiest cities in India. Varanasi is the ultimate destination for Hindu pilgrims who travel far and wide to step foot in this spiritual city. Your leader will take you on a walking tour of the Old City, passing temples and shrines, stopping to watch as rituals are performed. This evening, see the spirituality of this city in motion at the sunset candle flower ceremony. The daily ritual involves people sitting a small candle on a leaf which is then placed on the water, accompanied by chanting, songs and fire performances.

dayInfo.title: Varanasi.
dayInfo.description: This morning you might like to wake up early to watch the sunrise by the river and take in the many sights along the ghats. At lunchtime, you'll jump on a rickshaw for a tasting tour through the vibrant streets to some of the city's most iconic eateries. Dig into a range of savory and sweet snacks like chaat, samosas, jalebi and lassi while getting a glimpse into Varanasi’s rich culinary heritage. You have free time for the rest of the day – and there are many ways to soak up your time here! You could wander the laneways behind the ghats, shop for local silk or even take a yoga class. If you have time, perhaps visit the nearby Sarnath – one of the four main Buddhist pilgrimage destinations. Sarnath is where Buddha preached his message of the path to enlightenment and features stupas (Buddhist shrines) and museums to explore.

dayInfo.title: India/Nepal border crossing – Lumbini.
dayInfo.description: Today, wave goodbye to India and say namaste to Nepal, as you cross the border at Gorakhpur. This will be a longer journey, so maybe get stuck into a good book or your favourite podcast. When you arrive in Nepal, take a private bus to your hotel in Lumbini – the birthplace of Gautama Buddha, the founder of Buddhism, and one of his four holy places of pilgrimage. Later today, travel to the Lumbini Heritage Park, home to the Ashoka Pillars, where you’ll hop on cycle rickshaws to the Maya Devi Temple – the actual site where Lord Buddha is thought to have been born.

dayInfo.title: Amaltari Community.
dayInfo.description: Today, your journey continues as you travel by private vehicle through the Terai to the Amaltari Madhyavarti village homestay – your stay for the night. A well-known Indigenous group in Nepal, the Tharu community who live here are known for their distinctive culture and lifestyle. When you arrive, have lunch in the community with your group, get to know some of the locals and then enjoy some free time to freshen up. After, you’ll head out on a 4WD drive to the lake to enjoy some afternoon tea. Learn about village life in the community over dinner tonight and sit down for a home-cooked, traditional meal made by the locals.

dayInfo.title: Chitwan National Park.
dayInfo.description: Start your day with a guided walk around the Tharu community with one of its members. Your local guide will show your group the Indigenous architectural styles, as well as the farms and produce used to feed and economically sustain the community. Along the way, you might learn a little more about life here as they share their customs, values and stories with you. After, say goodbye to your hosts, and head for your lodge in Chitwan National Park via Twenty Thousand Lakes (Bis Hajaar Tal) – Nepal’s second-largest natural wetland and a great introduction to the wildlife of Chitwan. Look out for migratory birds, crocodiles, and, if you’re lucky, an Indian rhino.

dayInfo.title: Chitwan National Park.
dayInfo.description: After breakfast, take a walk to the Rapti River, where you’ll be taken on a boat or jeep safari through the national park. Keep your eyes on the sky for the many brilliantly coloured birds of the area. Then, sit down for a picnic lunch by the river. Keep your eyes peeled for gharials – this fish-eating crocodile has long been hunted for the supposed aphrodisiac qualities of its snout. Learn more about them when you drop by the crocodile breeding centre. Once back at your accommodation, there’ll be time to relax or to take part in optional activities offered by the park. Tonight, you’ll be treated to a cultural performance by the local Tharu community.

dayInfo.title: Kathmandu.
dayInfo.description: Today, you'll travel by bus from Chitwan to Nepal's capital – Kathmandu. Try to grab a window seat for this trip, as the views are not to be missed. Look out over Nepal’s rural landscape of rice terraces, mountain-side villages and flowing rivers – all with the backdrop of the Himalayan mountain range. Arrive in the city and get your bearings, maybe with a walk through the narrow streets to the traditional architecture of Durbar Square. Or stop for a shop at the markets and bazaars. While in Nepal, make sure you sample the local favourite food - momo (Nepali dumplings). Ask your trip leader for a place to grab dinner.

dayInfo.title: Kathmandu.
dayInfo.description: Today you’ll head out to Kathmandu's most important Buddhist shrine – the ancient Swayambhunath Temple, known to tourists as the Monkey Temple. The sleepy, all-seeing Buddha eyes that stare out from the top have become the quintessential symbol of Nepal. You’ll also join the pilgrims at Bodhnath Stupa – the largest stupa in Nepal and one of the holiest Tibetan Buddhist temples. Then, visit Pashupatinath – the most famous Hindu temple in the country – located on the banks of the holy Bagmati River. Here you will see Hindu holy men (sadhus) meditating and pilgrims bathing. The rest of the day is free for you to enjoy Kathmandu. One way to spend your time is to take a scenic flight through the mountains – great if you’re not able to take on a trek.

dayInfo.title: Kathmandu.
dayInfo.description: There are no activities planned for your last day, and you can depart the accommodation at any time. If you would like to stay an extra couple of days, and it's recommended that you do, just get in touch with your booking agent ahead of time. If you do extend your stay, maybe check out the great range of Urban Adventures – like the Kathmandu: Rickshaw Night Explorer tour.

tourName: Diwali festival holiday in India
generalInfo: This special small group holiday offers fascinating insights into life in the foothills together with the opportunity to join in with traditional celebrations. Experience the bright colours, music and dancing as the festivals of Diwali is celebrated in the Binsar Wildlife Sanctuary. Stay in charming mountain villages, enjoy some wonderful walks and experience the traditional, joyous festival celebrations. Perfect for single travellers or couples who wish to travel in company.

dayInfo.description: Meet and welcome at 12pm at Delhi guesthouse. The afternoon is yours to meet the group or explore the city at your leisure. Night in Delhi hotel
An early morning train takes you to Kathgodam, from where you have a road transfer (4 hrs) to Khali Estate for dinner and overnight stay in twin room garden bungalow.
From Khali enjoy a trip to the nearby town of Almora to explore the markets, alive with colour for the festival. Spend a second night at Khali.

Meet your guide who accompanies you for the rest of your stay. From Khali head through the pine-forest to experience the individual character and warm hospitality of the Binsar villages. You stay in four of the five villages and in one of them for two nights, and enjoy some wonderful walking with splendid views. You stay in simple twin rooms in the village guesthouses with breakfast, picnic lunch and dinner. You walk between villages in the company of your local guide with your luggage carried by village porters. Get to know the communities and experience the traditional festival celebrations.
Walk back to Khali Estate for another night stay.
A road transfer (4 hrs) takes you to Kathgodam to catch the day train to Delhi. Overnight Delhi guesthouse.
Transfer to Delhi airport for flight home

tourName: East India national parks wildlife tour
generalInfo:
Three diverse national parks and wildlife habitats in Singalila, Kaziranga and Sunderban

- An adventure that showcases habitats ranging from the high Himalayas, to bio-diverse floodplains to rich mangrove forests at sea level

- Enjoy diverse ways of exploring including walking, jeep safaris and boat excursions

- Search for elusive mammals like Red Panda, Indian One-horned Rhino, Royal Bengal Tiger, Asiatic Elephants, Wild Buffaloes, Hoolock Gibbons and many more


- Witness the diverse birdlife of Eastern India ranging from high mountains to estuaries

- Be guided by experts in each location who know the landscape and its wildlife intimately

The Wild Wonders of East India journey takes you to some of the most fascinating wildlife habitats of the Eastern part of India. The wildlife sojourn starts at one of the most special Eastern Himalayan Landscapes, the Singalila National Park. This is the best place in India to see the elusive firefox or Red Panda. The Red Panda is a mammal native to Eastern Himalayas and Southwest China. The Red Panda has been classified as Endangered by the IUCN because its wild population is estimated at less than 10,000 mature individuals living in the wild. Singalila is one of its last strong holds and it is also the best place in India to see this elusive and rare mammal. Red Pandas are best found at an altitude ranging from 2,500 meters to 4,000 meters, and this part of the journey will be conducted at this altitude.

After a 5 nights quest to search for the elusive Red Panda the journey continues to Kaziranga National Park, a UNESCO world heritage site which was declared a tiger reserve in 2006. Kaziranga is a paradise for megafauna. It is stronghold for the endangered Indian One Horned Rhino with over 2,600 (2/3 of the global population) residing in its grassland and floodplain habitat. Apart from rhinos, it is home to many mammal species, including tigers, elephants, Asiatic wild buffalo, leopard, bears, swamp deer, hog deer, hoolock gibbons, smooth coated otters and a high diversity of birds.

The next and final stop on this journey is another UNESCO world heritage site and the largest mangrove forest in the world, the Sunderban Tiger Reserve. Nestled in the delta of the Ganges, Brahmaputra, and Meghna rivers, this intricate landscape is home to the elusive Royal Bengal tiger, as well as a wealth of other wildlife including saltwater crocodiles, wild boars, and a myriad of bird species. Visitors can embark on thrilling boat safaris that weave through the forest’s dense, tidal channels, offering glimpses of the rare flora and fauna in their natural habitat. A journey through the Sundarbans is not just a chance to witness its unparalleled biodiversity but also an opportunity to engage with the rich cultural tapestry and traditions of the communities living in harmony with this wild, ever-changing landscape.

dayInfo.description: Arrival at Delhi International airport Transfer to hotel and day at leisure Raddison Blu Plaza, Delhi Airport and relaxation.
Check out early in the morning, catch a flight from Delhi International Airport to Bagdogra, and then drive for 2 hours and 30 minutes onwards to Manebhanjan Overnight stay at Shikhar Tarry Homestay.

Wake up and departure to the entry point of the National Park at Manebhanjen, guests will change to their 4X4 vehicle and enter the park to sight the elusive Red Panda. Our team of expert trackers would have gone out searching for Red Panda early in the morning. As the trackers find Red Panda, guests will be taken to the spot. Along with our expert naturalist, guests can also participate in tracking the elusive Red Panda using established trails in the park. Singalila is home to several species of birds and guests can also engage themselves with bird watching, while the trackers are out looking for Red Panda. Lunch will be served on the field or at the lodge, depending on the wildlife activities that we decide to do. Dinner and overnight at Manebhajen

Wake up and departure to the entry point of the National Park at Manebhanjen, guests will change to their 4X4 vehicle and enter the park to sight the elusive Red Panda. Our team of expert trackers would have gone out searching for Red Panda early in the morning. As the trackers find Red Panda, guests will be taken to the spot. Along with our expert naturalist, guests can also participate in tracking the elusive Red Panda using established trails in the park. Singalila is home to several species of birds and guests can also engage themselves with bird watching, while the trackers are out looking for Red Panda. Lunch will be served on the field or at the lodge, depending on the wildlife activities that we decide to do. Dinner and overnight at Manebhajen

Post early breakfast at your homestay in Manebhanjen, proceed for half day birding and wildlife viewing. Hot lunch to be served at the homestay After an unforgettable adventure spotting the elusive Red Pandas, it's time to bid adieu to Manebhanjan and head to Siliguri post lunch. Arrival in Siliguri by the evening and check in to the Courtyard by Marriot, Siliguri.

After a hot breakfast at your hotel, an airport transfer will be arranged to Siliguri airport. You will take a flight from Siliguri to Guwahati, where a vehicle will be waiting upon your arrival. From Guwahati drive 5 hours on a picturesque road to Kaziranga National Park and check into Infinity Resort, Kaziranga. Evening at leisure.

Today post breakfast you will be doing 6 game drives over 3 days guest will go out and explore the park in 4X4 jeeps. Kaziranga is a heaven for large mammals. The one-horned rhino is the star attraction. Asiatic elephants roam in big herds and Asiatic wild buffaloes find this landscape as one of their last refuges. Tigers are plenty in Kaziranga, but because of the tall elephant grasses not always easy to see. Eastern swamp deer, spotted deer, sambar deer and hog deer are some of the prey species found here. Smooth coated otters are sometimes seen in the swamps and water bodies and a plethora of birdlife can be seen on drives. If lucky, the fishing cat, could be a prize catch. Guests finish their drive and come back to the lodge by 10.30 AM. Post lunch another game drive will be arranged with similar chances of sightings. Based on the guest suitability Sagar will take a session on photography either in the day time or just before dinner. Dinner and overnight at Infinity Kaziranga.

After Morning breakfast, you will be departing to Guwahati 5 Hrs drive from Kaziranga for your onward journey to board a flight to Kolkata. Upon your arrival in Kolkatta airport, a vehicle will take you towards the Godkhali Jetty approach to Sunderban. You will drive couple of hours through scenic landscape to reach the jetty. At the jetty board the boat and onwards to Sunderban Tiger Camp. Arrival and evening at leisure A short introductory session and short briefing session from the naturalist about the forest, the flora and fauna, and the special habitat of the swamp tigers along with bird watching and photography on the way to resort.

Sunrise to Sunset Boat Safari Early Morning Departure from Waxpol Ghat (timing will be notified a day before by the Group Leader approx. time is 5.30 am-6.00 am). Breakfast and Lunch will be served hot and fresh on the boat itself during the safari as the main species for this trip is the Swamp Tiger, we will search for pug marks on mud banks and depending on our findings and information from our well-equipped tracking team; we will set the cruise route for every day. It is important to note that this route may or may not change every day, as we will be concentrating on recent tiger movements and possible movement paths. Apart from tracking the big cat, we will also be on the lookout for other birds and mammals. Throughout the day we will cruise through several creeks, rivers and rivulets. After the safari the guests will return to the resort for dinner and an overnight stay.
Early Morning Departure from Waxpol Ghat after checkout. "Depart from Sunderbans to Kolkata Airport, and then proceed to Delhi for an international flight.

tourName: Family holiday to India, sightseeing and safari
generalInfo:
This family holiday to India is a superb mix of both sightseeing and safari, all organised for you as it is a small group, fully guided tour with other like minded families. So all you need to do is sit back and enjoy the colours, culture and cuisine of northern India.

A ten day trip, with seven nights in hotels and two in small lodges, you will be travelling with 3-5 other families, to some of the region’s natural and cultural highlights. Starting in Delhi, with plenty of time to explore the Old City, we head to Agra and the Taj Mahal.
