Accommodation: Hotel 7 Apple (or similar) Upgrade to a room overlooking the Jal Mahal today - speak to your sales representative for more details

Enjoy a full day exploring Jaipur, the capital of Rajasthan and one of the most attractive and colourful cities in India. Rise early, heading out for a dawn walking tour as the pink city begins to wake. Visiting different chowkris (blocks) within the walled city, we can see the local people start their day and watch the rituals that take place in early morning flower and vegetable markets. Visiting a small temple, we witness a morning aarti, a moving Hindu ceremony accompanied by singing, ringing bells and incense. We can also interact with different artisan communities, while also sampling local food and drink. Returning to the hotel for breakfast and time to refresh, we head out again mid-morning. First, we visit the hilltop Amer Fort, which was built by Kachwaha dynasty ruler Man Singh and acted as the seat of the dynasty before the capital was shifted to Jaipur. A highlight is the Sheesh Mahal (Hall of Mirrors), which is adorned with more than a million pieces of hand-cut mirror and glass, intricately arranged to reflect light throughout the space. Later, we visit one of the most intriguing sites in India, Jantar Mantar (Jaipur Observatory), an assembly of immense marble-and-brass astronomical instruments in a pleasant garden. We also see the Hawa Mahal (Palace of the Winds), a five-storey landmark built of pink sandstone, which allowed the women of the royal household to observe street festivities without being noticed. Finally, we can end the day exploring the local market within the walled city – admiring the local dhurries (woven rugs), carpets, printed cloth, semi-precious stones and leatherwear. Accommodation: Hotel 7 Apple (or similar) Upgrade to a room overlooking the Jal Mahal today - speak to your sales representative for more details

Return to Delhi after breakfast, aiming to arrive at our hotel in the late afternoon. Typically, the group gathers for a final meal this evening, a chance to relax and recount the whirlwind week and memories created with new-found friends. Accommodation: Iris Park (or similar)

The adventure ends in Delhi today. Begin your return journey home or, if you’d like a bit more time to explore this magnificent city, speak to your sales representative about extending your stay. You can combine this trip with our Highlights of Kerala adventure, allowing you to see a completely different side to India.

tourName: Golden Triangle with Ranthambore group tour
generalInfo:
Combine India’s celebrated Golden Triangle with time in Ranthambore National Park on this 10-day small group tour. Take a cycle rickshaw ride in Old Delhi and explore its famous monuments and buildings, including the Red Fort Qutab Minnar and Humayun’s Tomb.

In Agra, visit the legendary Taj Mahal at sunrise and then explore Agra Fort. Next, you have the chance to spot tigers in Ranthambore National Park on three game drives. Visit the 8th Century old Stepwell.

You’ll get to know beautiful Jaipur, too, on a full city tour, visiting the Amber Fort, City Palace and Hawa Mahal. In the evening, explore the local markets, bursting with colourful textiles, jewellery and furniture.

During this tour, all breakfasts and dinners are included and in Ranthambore all meals are provided. Transport is in an air-conditioned coach and an accompanying English-speaking guides will escort you throughout the tour. All excursions and entry fees to monuments, as detailed in the itinerary below, are included.

Places to visit include: • Jama Masjid • Cycle Rickshaw ride in Old Delhi. • Visit to Asia's Largest Spice Market • Red Fort (from Outside) • Humayun’s Tomb • Qutub Minar • Drive Past Kartavya path & Janpath. Overnight at the Hotel. Hotel: Eros Hotel

Afternoon sightseeing tour of Agra visiting Agra Fort & Mehtab Bagh to see the Taj Mahal from the other side of the river during sunset. Rest of the day is free at leisure. Overnight at the hotel. Upon arrival in Jaipur, check-in at the hotel. Spend the evening at leisure. Overnight at the hotel. Hotel: Hilton

Jaipur - After breakfast, enjoy a full day city tour of Jaipur. Places to visit include: • Amber Fort • City Palace • Jantar Mantar • Hawa Mahal (From outside only). In the evening explore the colorful local markets of Jaipur. Hotel: Hilton

Jaipur - After breakfast, your day is free at leisure. We have a wide range of activities which we can organise for you for this free day on your request with supplement cost, such as: Art & Antiquities Walk, Block Printing, Bagru, Bazaars, Craft & Cusines, Blue Pottery Excursion, cooking demonstrations along with meal with the local family and so on. Hotel: Hilton

tourName: Golden Triangle with Udaipur & Shahpura holiday
generalInfo:
Delhi, Agra and Jaipur are classics for a reason, but it can be tricky to approach the famous ‘Golden Triangle’ without getting caught up in the crowd. Our spin on India’s classic route celebrates these iconic destinations – with a few unexpected twists.

This itinerary is our answer to that problem, giving you India’s most iconic destinations in the best possible light. That means the most interesting heritage accommodation, the most engaging local guides, and the most immersive cultural experiences – combined with a couple of lesser-known destinations to give you a taste of what lies beyond.

Trip highlights:
- Get beyond the usual tourist trail with our exceptional local guides, on tours of Delhi, Agra, Amber, Jaipur and Udaipur
- See sunrise at the Taj Mahal, arguably the world’s most beautiful building
- Have a go at Rajasthani cooking at a local family home in Udaipur, and turn your hand to elephant poo paper-making at a workshop in Jaipur.

What's great:
- This trip is for first-time visitors who want to get beneath the surface of India’s most famous destinations
- We’ve cherry-picked accommodation and experiences to show you these popular destinations from a variety of perspectives
- We’ve included a couple of our favourite spots outside of the Golden Triangle to give you a break from the crowds, and a taste of what lies beyond India’s hotspots
- You’ll have the best local guides with you to uncover the culture and history of each destination
- We’ve included a couple of hands-on cultural experiences, and there are plenty of opportunities to add more if you choose
- The pace is fairly leisurely, with three nights in most destinations, to give you plenty of time to explore.

Dietary requirements:
Our tailor-made itineraries are designed as flexible suggestions. If a hotel or accommodation on the proposed route is unable to meet specific dietary requirements, we can replace it with a suitable alternative. In cases where no alternatives are available in a particular destination, we will discuss other options directly with the client to ensure their needs are met.

All itineraries can be adapted to cater for vegetarian and vegan diets, as well as other dietary preferences or restrictions. While the range of options may vary by region, we will always work to ensure that clients are accommodated as comfortably as possible.

dayInfo.description: DELHI: Kicking off your India experience in Delhi is a baptism of fire in the best possible way. One of the world’s oldest and most chaotic cities, Delhi has layers upon layers of culture and history. It’s vast, and it can be totally bamboozling to the uninitiated. Luckily, that’s not going to be you. The key to getting the most out of Delhi is to experience it with a local — and not just any local, someone who really knows how this place ticks. From the British colonial buildings and peaceful gardens of New Delhi to the grand mosques and bazaars of Old Delhi, our outstanding local guides will get you beyond the usual tourist sites and under the skin of India’s capital. Highlights Mingle with local people as you volunteer in the community kitchen at Delhi’s most important Sikh temple Go for a rickshaw ride through the hectic alleys and markets of Chandni Chowk Enjoy top quality guiding, and add in a nighttime food walk to taste the very best of Delhi’s world-class street-food scene.

AGRA: Agra is famous for one thing and one thing only: the Taj Mahal. But this oft-overlooked city has much more to it than ‘just’ the world’s most beautiful building. Start by stepping into the world of the Mughals at Agra Fort, a World Heritage Site in its own right, where the imprisoned Emperor Akbar spent his final years looking out towards his prized creation. Then, drop into the Sheroes Hangout, where acid attack survivors have found family and purpose running a successful café. Agra has plenty to keep you entertained at nightfall, from sunsets over the Yamuna River to live concerts, bar-hopping, bowling, and (of course) the Taj Mahal in all its glory. Highlights Rise early to visit the Taj Mahal at dawn, when it glows orange in the sunrise Meet the inspirational women who run Sheroes Café Explore Agra’s lively nightlife, either under your own steam or with one of our expert guides.

JAIPUR: The third point of the Golden Triangle, the ‘pink city’ of Jaipur is one of our favourite places in India. You could spend a lifetime here – but with just three days, we’ve had to be judicious. Start with a tour of Amber Fort, pre-Jaipur bastion of the Kachwaha Rajputs, heading from there into the hidden alleys, temples and stepwells of old Amber town. Rise before dawn to catch the city at its most serene and glowing, gliding through the streets in a rickshaw as it comes to life, then explore the eccentric legacy of Jaipur’s founding father as you visit Jai Singh’s City Palace and Observatory. As always, our local guides are what make these experiences really special. Highlights See the iconic facade of Hawa Mahal glow pink in the light of sunrise, then visit a local temple for aarti prayers Learn why Jaipur is India’s city of crafts as you explore the bazaars of Old Jaipur Enjoy some of Jaipur’s alternative delights, including an elephant poo paper-making workshop and a laughter yoga session.

SHAHPURA: Shahpura is where we diverge from the Golden Triangle entirely and head off-piste into the Rajasthani countryside, to the home of the former maharajas of Shahpura. Surrounded by pasture and lakes, it’s the perfect respite from the clamour of Delhi, Agra and Jaipur: think candlelit dinners in the garden, excursions to Bhil minority villages, and plenty of time to relax by the pool and soak up your surroundings (which are truly lovely). The former royal family still live onsite, often mingling with guests, and there’s a wonderful range of in-house experiences to enjoy, from yoga and acupressure to boating, cycle rides and a visit to a local fort. Highlights Slow the pace after your three city stays with some time in the beautiful Rajasthani countryside Explore villages, forts and farmland rarely visited by tourists, guided by your wonderful hosts at Shahpura Bagh Relax by the pool and enjoy the luxuriant surroundings at one of our favourite experiential hotels.

UDAIPUR: Your final destination is Udaipur, and it just might be the highlight of your trip. This chilled-out, lakeside city has bags of charm, as you’ll find out with the help of one of our brilliant local guides. They’ll introduce you to artisans keeping traditional crafts alive, show you were to find the best street food, take you down narrow lanes to hidden delights, and tell you the stories that bring the culture and history of Udaipur to life. Best of all, you’ll be staying at yet another beautiful heritage property right on the lake, eating your meals by the water with views of the city’s bathing ghats and ‘floating’ palaces. Udaipur is a magical place to conclude your adventure. Highlights Visit the home of a local family for a cooking lesson, and attend an aarti prayer ceremony Explore City Palace, one of Rajasthan’s biggest and most spectacular, with our expert local guide Stay at an 18th century converted haveli (palace) on the shores of Lake Pichola.

tourName: Golden Triangle with Uttar Pradesh holiday
generalInfo:
The Golden Triangle circuit comprising of Delhi, Agra and Jaipur is one of the most visited regions of India. Various UNESCO Sites like Taj Mahal, Fatehpur Sikri, Agra Fort, Qutub Minar, Monuments of Jaipur etc. are the highlights. Apart from these standard highlights, this tour includes awesome bespoke experiences like village visits, local interactions, Yoga sessions and much more. The visit to Golden Triangle is clubbed with a visit to Varanasi and Lucknow - known for Ganges, Culture, Food and Art.

Some of the important experiences include:

1. Visit the UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Delhi and experience the imperial and Mughal architecture
2. Visit one of the 7 wonders of the world Taj Mahal and discover the magic of white marble during sunrise at Agra
3. Enjoy Yoga session at a special place facing Taj Mahal in Agra
4. Go on a Mughal Heritage Kachhpura Village Walk tour in Agra- an eye-opening experience
5. Enjoy Guided tour of the Pink City i.e. Jaipur – a UNESCO World heritage city – experiences its forts, palaces, markets and culture.
6. Early morning mesmerizing sunrise boat ride.
7. Evening Ganga Aarti ceremony in Varanasi.
8. Experience heritage and culture of Lucknow on a sightseeing tour

dayInfo.description: Arrive at New Delhi International Airport. Receive a warm welcome from our representative and get transferred to the hotel. On arrival complete the check-in formalities and enjoy the rest of the day at leisure.

• After breakfast, proceed for a sightseeing tour of the city with your guide. • Drive past or if you wish you may visit Red Fort • Drive past or if you wish you may take a stop at Raj Ghat – the cremation site of Mahatma Gandhi. • Visit Agrasen ki Baoli (ancient water reservoir) • Visit Jama Masjid • Visit Chandni Chowk – ‘the Moonlight Square and enjoy a Cycle Rickshaw Ride which takes you through the narrow streets of the Chandni Chowk. • Visit Lakshmi Narayan Temple • Drive Past India Gate – The All India War Memorial • Also pass by the Rashtrapati Bhavan (formerly the viceroy's residence) and the Parliament House. • Enjoy a special lunch at a local restaurant. • Visit Humayun's Tomb • Visit Qutub Minar - A UNESCO World Heritage Site.

After a hearty breakfast, travel to Agra (222Km, 5-hour drive). On arrival meet our representative and check into the hotel. Enjoy the rest of the day at leisure. In the evening enjoy a Special Dinner at Taj Facing Rooftop Restaurant.

Early morning visit Taj Mahal during Sunrise (As fuel-based vehicles are not permitted in the vicinity of the Taj Mahal, you will head to the Taj Mahal gate by a Battery operated Bus. (Friday Closed). • After breakfast, visit Agra Fort - An Epitome of the Mughal Dynasty • Visit Itmad-Ud-Daulah’s Tomb • Late afternoon go for Mughal Heritage Kachhpura Village walk with high tea OPTIONAL TOURS: •Mohabbat the Taj Show- You can watch the famous Mohabbat the Taj show, presented by the Sanskritik Natyashala. It is a series of play depicting the saga of love.

Early Morning, Enjoy the Taj Mahal Facing Yoga Session. After breakfast, check out from the hotel and travel to Jaipur (240Km, 5-hour drive). En-route visit Fatehpur Sikri - A city predominantly made of red sandstone and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. On arrival meet our representative and check into the hotel and enjoy the rest of the day at leisure.

After breakfast, proceed for full day Jaipur sightseeing tour with your Guide. •Visit Amber Fort – One of the most magnificent palaces in India. (The Fort is perched on a hill, so to reach there; you may enjoy a Jeep ride in Amber fort. •Visit Jantar Mantar – largest stone astronomical observatory in the world. •Visit to City Palace and Museum– Built by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh during the years 1729 to 1732. •Photo Stop at Hawa Mahal – built by Maharaja Sawai Pratap Singh in the year 1799. •In the evening enjoy Heena Painting on Hands and Feet.

After breakfast, check out from the hotel and get transferred to Jaipur Airport and fly to Varanasi. On arrival receive a warm welcome from our representative and get transferred to the hotel. Complete the check-in formalities and rest for a while. Later, go on a guided Bengali Tola Walk and experience the local culture of Varanasi. After the walk attend the Aarti Ceremony of River Ganges at the Ghat (place near river).
Early morning, take a Boat Ride at river Ganges and feel the spirituality in the air. After breakfast, visit the, • Vishwanath Temple • Half Day tour of Varanasi • Visit the Sarnath Temple

After breakfast, check out from the hotel and get transferred to the Varanasi Railway Station and board the train for Lucknow. On arrival receive a warm welcome by our representative and get transferred to the hotel. Complete the check-in formalities and enjoy the rest of the day at leisure.
After breakfast, go for a sightseeing tour of Lucknow with your guide. • Visit Rumi Darwaza • Visit Chota Imambara • Visit Bada Imambara • Visit Janeshwar Mishra Park • Also visit Chattar Manzil
After breakfast, check out from the hotel and get transferred to the Lucknow Airport and fly to New Delhi International Airport to board your flight for your hometown.

tourName: Grand tour of India
generalInfo:
Dive into the rich, vibrant and diverse culture of India with our
17-day adventure tour.Covering both the north and the west of
the country, this adventure has it all. Explore India’s iconic major
landmarks, World Heritage ancient ruins, glorious Goan beaches
and abundance of delicious food. From bustling cities to rural
villages, our Adventure Leaders take you off-the-beaten-track as
you explore all that India has to offer.

Included in all tours:

An epic Adventure Leader, aka a local legend, to turn your trip into the adventure of a lifetime.
All local transport within India, including flights between Jodhpur, Mumbai, and Goa.
Accommodation (including hostels, Thar Desert camping, & three overnight trains).
Meals provided: 1 breakfast, 1 lunch (included with cooking experience, which may shift to dinner based on local timing), & 2 dinners.

Accommodation style:

In true backpacking style, our accommodation is in shared, mixed-gender dorm rooms as standard on this tour. But if you’d prefer a little extra comfort and your own space to relax after an action-packed day, room upgrades are available. Please request this on booking.

Included in all Dragon Trip tours:

Pre-departure briefing (Delhi)
Hindi language lesson (Delhi)
Old Delhi tour (Delhi)
Sis Ganj Sikh Temple in Old Delhi (Delhi)
Akshardham Temple (Delhi)
Ghat Boat Tour incl. Ganga Aarti Ceremony (Varanasi)
Taj Mahal at sunrise (Agra)
Nagargarh Fort at sunset (Jaipur)
Food Court Tour (Jaipur)
Monkey Temple (Jaipur)
Camel Safari & Camping (Thar Desert)
Walking Tour of Blue City (Jodhpur)
Indian Cooking Experience (Jodhpur)
Mumbai Orientation Walk (Mumbai)

dayInfo.description: Delhi: Welcome to New Delhi – the start of an unforgettable 17-day adventure across India! Once you’ve checked in, we’ll kick things off with a pre-departure briefing, where you’ll meet your Adventure Leader and fellow travellers, get the lowdown on the itinerary, cover health and safety tips, and pick up everything you need to make the most of the journey ahead. Next, get ready for a fun Hindi language session! Your Adventure Leader will teach you some essential phrases that will come in handy throughout the trip – perfect for connecting with locals, ordering tasty street food, or haggling in the markets like a pro. In the afternoon, we’ll explore the magic of Old Delhi on a guided walking tour. Wander through buzzing backstreets, colourful markets, and historic temples, sample incredible street food, and soak up the city’s lively atmosphere. This is your chance to experience a side of Delhi that most visitors miss. (Tip: comfortable shoes are a must!) To finish the day, step inside Sis Ganj Sahib Gurudwara, an important Sikh temple in Old Delhi. Take a moment to enjoy the serene and spiritual surroundings, connect with the welcoming community, and reflect on your first day of adventure in India – a truly memorable introduction to the country.

Delhi: Start your morning in Lodhi Garden, the city’s green oasis, where you can join a friendly game of Ultimate Frisbee. Jump in, meet some locals, and get moving, or simply cheer from the sidelines and soak up the atmosphere. If culture is more your vibe, opt to visit Humayun’s Tomb, a stunning UNESCO World Heritage site that served as inspiration for the Taj Mahal. Wander the gardens and marvel at the intricate Mughal architecture – it’s a fascinating glimpse into Delhi’s rich history. For lunch, we’ll head to Khan Market, a hub of cool cafés, international eats, and boutique shops. It’s the perfect spot to relax, refuel, and get ready for the afternoon’s adventures. Next, immerse yourself in the colours and chaos of Delhi Haat, an open-air market brimming with handicrafts from across India. From vibrant textiles to handcrafted jewellery, it’s the ideal place to practice your bargaining skills and pick up a one-of-a-kind souvenir. As the day winds down, we’ll visit the breathtaking Akshardham Temple. This enormous, intricately carved complex is a feast for the eyes, blending spiritual calm with jaw-dropping architecture – a truly unforgettable Delhi highlight. Finally, we’ll gather as a group to board an overnight train to Varanasi, ready for the next chapter of your Indian adventure.

Varanasi: We roll into Varanasi in the morning and hop on private transport straight to the hostel. Take some time to freshen up, unpack, and relax before diving into the day’s adventures. In the afternoon, culture lovers can explore Sarnath, a world-renowned Buddhist site steeped in history. This is where the Buddha gave his first teachings after enlightenment, and the energy of the place, layered with centuries of Hindu heritage, is truly unforgettable. As evening falls, prepare for one of the most magical experiences in Varanasi: a boat ride along the Ghats of the Ganges. Drift past the riverside steps where locals bathe, worship, and carry out daily rituals. Witness the intensity of the Burning Ghat, and end the journey with the Ganga Aarti, a mesmerizing ceremony of fire, chants, and devotion that lights up the river in a way you’ll never forget.

Varanasi-Agra: Kick off the morning on the Ganges with an optional Sunrise Boat Tour. Watch Varanasi come to life as the sun casts its glow over the river, witness morning rituals unfold on the Ghats, and if you like, grab a famous Tulsi Chai or some local street snacks on the way back – a perfect way to start the day! Next, wander through the vibrant old markets of Varanasi and make your way to the legendary Blue Lassi Shop. Sip their creamy, colourful lassis while soaking up the sights, sounds, and colours of the Kashi Vishwanath Corridor – a true feast for the senses you’ll remember long after you leave. In the afternoon, it’s time to trade the river for the rails and journey to Agra. Depending on availability, hop on the afternoon or overnight train. Once in Agra, check in and recharge – tomorrow we’ll visit one of the world’s most iconic landmarks.

Agra: Start the morning with a stroll for breakfast to Bread & Mine Café, a charming spot that supports the deaf community. Whether you’re a coffee lover or just want a meaningful start to your day, it’s a great way to fuel up before exploring. In the afternoon, join an optional tea session with your Adventure Leader. Listen to inspiring stories about India, ask questions, and, if you’re lucky, meet some locals for first-hand insights into life here. It’s a relaxed, personal way to connect with the culture and people around you. Next, enjoy free time to explore Agra at your own pace. Wander through the towering Agra Fort and the elegant Baby Taj, soaking in the history, architecture, and stories that make these sites unforgettable. In the evening, regroup with your travel crew for dinner and drinks at Salt Café, one of Agra’s top spots for good food, great vibes, and the perfect place to toast another epic day of adventure.

Jaipur: Rise early for a bucket-list moment: a sunrise visit to the Taj Mahal, one of the seven wonders of the world. Watch as the marble monument glows in the first light of day, and enjoy the 20–30 minute walk there as the city slowly wakes, building anticipation for one of the world’s most breathtaking sights. After soaking in the Taj, hop into your private transfer for the journey to Jaipur. Stop for breakfast along the way, then enjoy a scenic 5–6 hour drive with just a couple of short breaks – perfect for stretching, grabbing a snack, and watching the landscape change as you roll through the heart of India. Once in Jaipur, check in and get settled at your accommodation. Then, it’s time for another unforgettable experience: Nahargarh Fort at sunset. Explore the fort’s historic interiors, then climb to the rooftop to see sweeping views of the Pink City glowing in golden light – the perfect way to cap off a day full of iconic sights and stunning scenery.

Jaipur: Are you an early riser? If so, start your day with an optional balloon safari, an unforgettable chance to watch the sun rise over Jaipur as you drift gently above the city. Prefer a slower start? No problem – wake up at your own pace and enjoy breakfast before heading out to the spectacular Amber Fort, built entirely from yellow and pink sandstone. Wander through its ornate halls, courtyards, and ramparts while soaking in the history and architecture. This afternoon is yours to explore Jaipur your way. Visit the opulent City Palace and the iconic Hawa Mahal, marvel at the astronomical instruments of Jantar Mantar, or dive into the bustling energy of Bapu Bazaar for souvenirs, textiles, and local crafts. As evening falls, regroup with your Adventure Leader for a Food Court Tour, a true foodie’s dream. Sample Jaipur’s best-loved local treats, discover hidden culinary gems, and get a taste of the city’s vibrant food scene. Night owls can cap off the day with a night out in Jaipur – whether it’s hitting a lively club or enjoying drinks with the group, soak up the city’s buzzing nightlife before heading back to rest.

Jaisalmer: Rise early for a truly memorable start to the day with a visit to the Monkey Temple (Galtaji). This vibrant Hindu pilgrimage site is set against stunning landscapes, showcases fascinating architecture, and – of course – is home to a lively troop of monkeys that add an extra spark of energy to your morning! After your temple visit, the rest of the morning is yours to enjoy. Take it slow with breakfast and some downtime, explore the bustling streets of the Pink City, or head to Patrika Gate, a visual delight known for its intricate Rajasthani patterns – perfect for photos and soaking up Jaipur’s colours. In the afternoon, we’ll transfer to Jaipur station and hop on the train to Jaisalmer, the next highlight of your India adventure. Settle in, watch the landscape roll by, and get ready for the golden deserts that await you!

Jaisalmer: Arrive in Jaisalmer this morning and head to your local hostel to rest, freshen up, and enjoy a hearty breakfast. Once fuelled up, it’s time to explore the city’s crown jewel: Jaisalmer Fort. Towering up to 250 feet in places and with parts dating back to the mid-1600s, this golden sandstone fortress is a marvel of history and architecture – perfect for wandering its winding streets and snapping unforgettable photos. Next, choose to visit Gadsisar Lake, a serene spot just outside the city, where you can take in the calm waters, spot temples and shrines along the edges, and enjoy panoramic views of the surrounding desert. But there’s no time to linger too long, because your first Dragon Moment awaits – a magical journey into the Thar Desert. Hop into a jeep and head deep into the sand dunes, where a camel trek will carry you to your desert camp. As the sun dips below the horizon, enjoy a delicious dinner al fresco before settling into your comfortable beds. Tonight, fall asleep under a blanket of stars – an experience you’ll never forget!

Jodhpur: Wake up to a desert sunrise that paints the dunes in shades of gold and pink – an unforgettable way to start the day. After a simple breakfast and packing up your camp, it’s time to head back to Jaisalmer and prepare for your private transfer to Jodhpur. Upon arrival, check in to your next hostel and drop off your bags, then join your Adventure Leader for a guided tour of the Blue City. Wander through its iconic streets, marvel at the Clock Tower, and explore the fascinating Toorji Ka Jhalra, an ancient stepwell that’s as beautiful as it is historic. In the evening, soak up the city’s vibes with your group – grab a drink near the stepwell, watch the sunset over the blue-painted buildings, and reflect on another epic day of your India adventure.

Jodhpur: Today is all about indulgence and adventure! Start your morning with a hands-on Indian Cooking Experience, where you’ll learn to prepare classic Rajasthani dishes, taste your creations, and pick up culinary secrets to impress friends and family back home. It’s a true Dragon Moment – fun, interactive, and delicious! For those craving an adrenaline rush, there’s the optional Flying Fox Zipline adventure. Race across six thrilling stations, soar high above the city and its fort, and take in breathtaking panoramic views of Jodhpur spread out beneath you. Whether you’re keeping your feet on the ground or flying high, it’s a day packed with culture, flavours, and unforgettable experiences, perfectly blending relaxation and excitement in the Blue City.

Mumbai: Late morning, it’s time to fly to Mumbai, the bustling heart of India’s west coast! Once you land, your Adventure Leader will whisk you to your accommodation to drop off your bags and freshen up. In the afternoon, get ready to explore the city on a guided tour. Marvel at the iconic Gateway of India, stroll along the shimmering Marine Drive – also known as the Queen’s Necklace – and soak in the sights, sounds, and energy of this vibrant metropolis. As evening falls, it’s all yours to enjoy. Head to the Colaba District for dinner, drinks, or a wander through its lively streets. For a truly special view, seek out one of the city’s rooftop bars and watch Mumbai sparkle beneath the sunset.

Mumbai: Start the morning with an optional Dharavi Slum Tour, a chance to see a side of Mumbai that’s far beyond the usual clichés. Witness the energy, industry, and community spirit of one of Asia’s largest slums, and gain a deeper understanding of the creativity and resilience of its residents. In the afternoon, head to Dhobi Ghat Mahalaxmi, the world’s largest open-air laundry. Watch as workers wash, beat, and dry clothes using time-honoured techniques – a chaotic, fascinating spectacle that captures Mumbai’s industrious spirit. As evening falls, wrap up your adventure Bollywood-style with an optional Movie Night. Enjoy the dazzling dance numbers, epic stories, and vibrant energy of India’s world-famous film industry – the perfect way to celebrate your journey in the city where Bollywood was born.

Mumbai-Goa: Kick off the morning with a visit to the famous Siddhivinayak Temple, dedicated to Lord Ganesha. This iconic temple offers a fascinating glimpse into Mumbai’s spiritual heart and a chance to witness local devotion up close. Before your flight, enjoy some free time – perhaps grab breakfast at a café you haven’t tried yet, or wander through a bustling local market to soak up the city one last time. Next, it’s time to fly south to Goa. On arrival, transfer to your accommodation, check in, and unwind. Spend the evening embracing Goa’s laid-back vibe – stroll along the beach, catch a sunset, or simply relax and feel the shift from Mumbai’s bustling energy to Goa’s chilled rhythm.

Goa: Start the morning with breakfast at 3102bce, a uniquely designed hotel in Vagator. Their fresh buffet and seriously cool setting make it the perfect spot to fuel up for a day of adventure or relaxation. The rest of the day is yours to explore Goa at your own pace. Lounge on the beaches, hop between iconic beach shacks, or track down some of the region’s legendary local dishes – from fresh seafood to traditional Goan fare, there’s something for everyone. As the evening approaches, elevate your dining experience with the optional Fly Dining Experience. Strap in and enjoy dinner and drinks 50 meters above the ground, taking in sweeping coastal views and making for a truly unforgettable night.

Goa: Today is all about doing Goa your way, with plenty of optional activities for every kind of traveller. Start your morning with an optional trip to Panjim City, where colourful Portuguese-inspired streets, bustling markets, and laid-back charm offer a taste of Goa’s unique culture. In the afternoon, it’s time to soak up the beaches! Explore the lively stretches of Calangute and Baga, then swap the crowds for the tranquil vibes of Mandrem and Morjim – perfect spots to relax, swim, or simply watch the waves roll in. For those chasing adventure, try the Kayaking Experience, paddling through calm waters for 1–2 hours and seeing Goa from a fresh, waterside perspective. As the sun begins to set, take a leisurely stroll along Coconut Road in Arpora, one of North Goa’s most iconic spots and a backdrop for countless Bollywood films – a perfect way to wrap up your day in paradise.
Goa: Today marks the end of your amazing tour across India! You’ll bid farewell to your group, ready to head home.?

tourName: Gujarat 14 day tour in India
generalInfo:
Gujarat is birthplace of Mahatma Gandhi, Father of Nation. He started the satyagraha movement (holding onto truth, or truth force, is a particular form of nonviolent resistance) from here and his Salt March here. Besides this, Gujarat hold many treasures, join us to explore them !! It is rich in architecture which exhibits from its majestic forts, mansions and stepwells ; tribal villages from where you get India's finest textile (traditional weaving, embroidery, dye and print) ; national parks and sanctuaries rich in unique wildlife, including migratory birds, wild asses and Asiatic lions ; many pilgrimage sites for Jain and Hindus. Former Portuguese colony Diu is ideal for lovers of sand and sea..

Highlights
- Architectural marvels of Ahmedabad
- World Heritage Walled city, Ahmedabad
- Sidhpur, famous for old havelies and mansions
- Rani ki Vav, stepwell building of 11th century
- Patola sari weaver family
- Modhera sun temple
- Little Rann Of Kutch “salty desert” house for The Wild Ass
- Artisan of Banni villages.
- Gondal city, ruled by a family of car enthusiasts
- Gir National Park, natural habitat of Asiatic Lions (exclusive jeep)
- Somnath temple, dedicated to lord Shiva
- Diu, a Portuguese colony
- Palitana, Abode of Gods
- Lothal, site for Indus valley civilization

Important to note :
1. Best time to visit this region is between October to March.
Prices would increase if travel is happening around Diwali festival and around Christmas and New Year..
2. This tour starts and end in Gujarat state of India. It starts from Bhuj and ends in Ahmedabad. Both these cities are connected by flight to Delhi and Mumbai. Depending upon the port of your arrival and departure, we will add pre and post travel arrangements. However, you can combine this tour with other cities as well.
3. If you want to shorten this tour, it is possible to adapt as per your requirement. Incase you wish to explore textile richness of this region, you can consult Textile tour of Gujarat.
4. Gujarat is a Dry state. Foreigner has to obtain a permit at liquor shop to consume liquor. They need to present their passport copy, visa copy, air ticket and boarding pass along with stay letter from hotel. Even after getting permit, guest has to consume liquor in their room only.
5. Instead of walking uphill to Palitana, if you want, you can also opt for hiring Palanquin for which cost will be extra (around BGP 100 per person extra).

Closing of monuments / sanctuary :
Little Rann of Kutch - 15th June to 15th Oct Every Year
Aina Museum, Bhuj - Thursday & National Holidays
Kutch Museum, Bhuj - Wednesday & 02nd and 4th Saturday
Darbarhall Museum, Junagadh - Wednesday & 02nd and 04th Saturday & all Public Holidays"
Ashoka Edicts, Junagadh : Wednesday & National Holidays
Sasangir – 15th June to 15th Oct Every Year
Lothal - Friday & National Holidays
NGOs would remain closed on Sundays and during National Holidays and would need prior permission to visit.

dayInfo.description: Arrive Ahmedabad Arrive Ahmedabad, Gujarat’s major city and famous for its incredible architecture, ranging from centuries-old mosques and mausoleums to contemporary design. Transfer to hotel for check-in. Afternoon start your half day tour of Ahmedabad. Visit to 2-storeyed Hathee Singh Jain Temple, built in 1850 in white marble temple and named after a rich merchant named Seth Hathee Singh. The courtyard of this temple is surrounded by 52 small shrines dedicated to various spiritual teachers (Tirthankars) of Jain religion. The major attraction of this temple is a 78ft high Mahavir Stambha (tower). Continue your tour with visit to the symbol of architectural beauty in Ahmedabad, Sidi Saiyyed’s Mosque, built by an army general of the last Sultan of Gujarat. Built it in 1573 is renowned for its floral designs covering the whole structure and intricately-carved latticework on windows. The “Tree of Life” depicting a tree with intertwined branches displaying fine lace filigree work is the prime highlight of this mosque. End your day with visit to the Sabarmati Ashram that was relocated in 1917 on the banks of Sabarmati River. It was the residence of Mahatma Gandhi - the Father of the Nation and his wife for about 12 years. It features a gallery of life-size oil paintings and photo enlargements depicting the major life events of Mahatma Gandhi. Depending on the time in hand, you may visit SEWA (Self Employed Women's Association) which works towards full employment and self reliance among women.

In Ahmedabad After early breakfast, enjoy 2 hours walking tour in the UNESCO World Heritage walled city of Ahmedabad. This walk passes through a streets & ancient living units (pols) located deep inside this walled city; covering not just the architecture, but scientific manifestations like well thought-of rain harvesting system, drainage system, bird feeders, public wells, and religious institutions It is an opportunity to visit exquisite places of historical & heritage value.. Later in the day visit Calico Museum (closed on Wednesday and all public holidays, needs prior permission) for its finest collection of textiles, cloths, furniture, crafts in the country. Proceed to Adalaj village to visit a 5-story deep step well named as Adalaj Stepwell. It was built in 1499 by the Muslim king Mohammed Begda for Queen Rani Roopba, wife of Veer Singh, the Vaghela chieftain. These step-wells once provided basic water needs for drinking, washing and bathing. End your day with visit to Akshardham Temple, a Swaminarayan temple complex. The complex displays millennia of traditional Hindu and Indian culture, spirituality, and architecture.

Ahmedabad - Region of Little Rann of Kutch (approx 5h drive) Morning drive to visit Sidhpur also known as “Kashi (Varanasi) of the west. We stop to see the wonderful European-styled architecture old Havelis and mansions, some over 100 years old. The facades are rich in variety and aesthetic expression with intricate details in wood. Continue to Patan to visit Rani Ki Vav, the “Queen’s stepwell” built by the Queen Udaymati during 11th Century. This extravagant stepwell consists of a multi-storey pavilion, a well and a large tank for surplus water. A walk down the stairs takes you past hundreds of delicate carvings and statues. The walls are covered with carvings of Parvati, Shiva, Vishnu, and other gods. Patan is also famous for Patola Saris, each sari takes an average of six months to weave. Salvi family is one of the two families who has continued this traditional art of double ikat style. Continue to Modhera to visit Sun Temple (dedicated to Surya, sun god) that dates back to early 11th centaury, was built by King Bhimdev I. This grand sandstone temple is filled with elaborate carvings. A step tank in front of the temple has 108 shrines that lead down to the water. Continue drive to the region of Little Rann of Kutch that spreads over 5000 sq km.

In Region of Little Rann of Kutch In the morning enjoy jeep safari at Little Rann Of Kutch. Rann means “salty desert” and while driving through the Little Rann of Kutch, a salty desert is all you see. The Little Rann contains one of the country’s largest wildlife reserves, The Wild Ass Sanctuary, where the topography varies from large marshlands to brown-grey patches of soil with a few small thorny shrubs. The Wild Ass Sanctuary is one of the few places to stop the Ghudkar or Khur or Indian wild ass as well as wolves, blackbuck and chinkara. There’s also a huge bird population from October to March (this is one of the few areas in India where flamingos breed in the wild). In the evening enjoy village safari to visit the settlements and villages along the Rann of Kutch. Note : The Little Rann gets flooded and inaccessible during the monsoon (June to August). The period from September to March is cool and is the best time to visit and spot migratory birds. The sanctuary is open during the summer months of April and May but the weather is quite hot.

Region of Little Rann of Kutch - Bhuj (approx 5h drive) Morning drive to Bhuj. In 2001 a massive earthquake left Bhuj almost completely destroyed. Today the city has been largely rebuilt, though it lost much of its historic architecture and some of the palaces retain the scars of that fateful day. Bhuj is an ideal springboard for visits to the surrounding villages Afternoon visit darbargodh, or palace complex in the walled city of Bhuj. The walled city of Bhuj was the capital of the princely state of Kutch in the Gujarat. The darbargodh, or palace complex, within the city was begun by the princes of Kutch in 1548 and was added to over several centuries, reflecting the artistic and cultural development of the city and principality. The darbargadh's most significant interiors and structures date from the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, such as the last palace, Prag Mahal, which was built in red sandstone and white marble in 1868 under the direction of British architects. The oldest portions of the palace were vacated in the nineteenth century and, following independence, the palace complex became a privately owned museum. Major earthquake of January 2001 seriously damaged the darbargadh. Buildings collapsed and floors caved in; intricate architectural details and window screens were destroyed and structural cracks developed throughout the complex. The Indian National Trust for Arts and Cultural Heritage (INTACH) immediately identified the Bhuj Darbargadh for emergency restoration. Visit Aina Museum (Closed on Thursday & Public holidays) and Parag Mahal.

Around Bhuj to visit Banni villages Morning proceed to explore Banni villages (permit needed) spread around 2617 sq kms and includes around 48 villages. Visit to artisan villages like Hodka, Ludiya, Dhordo which are famous for different types of intricate embroideries, embroideries with mirror work, wood carving and beautiful mud houses. Lunch during visit Kala Raksha Trust. It is a grassroots social enterprise, dedicated to the preservation of traditional arts. It comprises of artisans, community members, and experts in the fields of art, design and museums.

Bhuj / Gondal (approx 5h drive) Morning drive to Gondal with enroute stop at local market of Anjar, one of the oldest towns in Kutch. Gondal was ruled by a family of car enthusiasts whose royal passion resulted in a fine collection of automobiles which are now part of a museum in the palace premises. Gondal like its neighbors has some visually exciting palaces and living spaces; some like the Riverside Palace commissioned in 1875 by Bhagwatsinghji is now a Heritage Hotel. A building worth visiting is the old Darbargadh a 17th century structure which reputedly cost Rupees Nine Lakhs thus earning the name as ‘Navlakha Palace’. The palace is built on series of arches delicately carved and inscribed in stone with a magnificent spiral staircase leading all the way to the top.

Gondal - Sasangir (approx 3h drive) Morning drive to Sasangir with enroute stop at the city of Junagarh to visit Uperkot Fort. Fort Uparkot, was built by Chandragupta of the Mauryan empire around 320 BC, and archaeological evidence confirms this, showing that Uparkot has been inhabited continuously since the 3rd century BC. Hence the name Junagadh, which means “ancient fort.” Under the Mauryans, Junagadh was a regional capital, and Emperor Ashoka had stone edicts placed there, still visible today. At the time of Independence Nawab of Junagarh opted to accede to Pakistan but its people overwhelmingly favored joining India. Afternoon safari to Gir National Park (Park is close from 16th June to 15th October every year) spread over 1450 sq kms, is the home to some 300 Asiatic Lions and is the only place in the world outside African continent where lion can be seen in its natural habitat. Gir is not just about lions but it is rich in other flora and fauna.

Sasangir - Somnath - Diu (approx 3h drive) Morning safari to Gir National Park (Park is close from 16th June to 15th October every year). Drive to Diu with enroute stop at Somanth to visit temple dedicated to lord Shiva. Later continue to Diu, a beautiful blend of sun, sand and sea. Diu was a Portuguese colony until 1961, now it is a Union Territory. It was an important trading post and naval base from where the rulers controlled the shopping routes in the northern part of the Arabian sea between 14-16th centuries.

In Diu Early morning drive to visit Vanakbara fishing village, a fascinating village. In the afternoon visit Diu. Visit St Paul’s church dedicated to Lady of Immaculate Conception. The main façade of church is perhaps the most elaborate of all Portuguese churches in India. Continue your sightseeing with visit to Diu Fort, an imposing structure with a magnificent view of sea.
Diu - Palitana (approx 4h drive) Morning free in Diu. Later drive to Palitana.

In Palitana Early morning, you may visit to join the pilgrims to climb the hills of Palitana known as the Abode of Gods. It is covered with 863 Jain temples spanning a period of over 900 years. The climb will take around 2hours each way.

Palitana - Lothal - Ahmedabad (approx 5h drive) Morning drive to Lothal (closed on Fridays and Public holidays), one of the most prominent cities of ancient Indus valley civilization. It was discovered in 1954 and excavation spanned from 1955 to 1960. Continue to Ahmedabad.
Ahmedabad - Fly out Morning transfer to airport to connect flight to Mumbai. Afternoon free in Mumbai to visit local market. Connect flight to next destination.

tourName: Gujarat and Mumbai highlights tour
generalInfo:
A mesmerising 14-day trip to the incredible state of Gujarat on the western coast of India and to The City of Dreams - Mumbai!
Your Journey in Gujarat begins in Ahmedabad, a UNESCO world heritage city and takes you to visit the culturally rich areas of Palanpur and Dasada, to the haven of craft tradition in Kutch. Then you will explore the wildlife destinations Velavadar and Little rann of Kutch. Explore Gujarat through its enthralling diversity of culture, rich textiles, traditional practices and abundant wildlife. Your journey continues with 3 exciting and authentic days in Mumbai, exploring a Dharavi slum walk, the Marine Drive and Colaba causeway, the UNESCO Elephanta Caves and the Khotachiwadi village. Then discover the laundry men at Dhobi Ghaat and the Dabba walla and finish your journey with souvenir shopping at the local Lalbaug Bazaar.

Inclusives:
- Stay in Hotels on double/twin sharing basis, all meals (B,L,D) and dedicated driver with A/c SUV car
- All activities, park entrances and monument entry fees
- Dedicated expert resource person (guide) with in depth knowledge of the subjects accompanying the guests
- Assistance on arrivals and Departure
- All taxes
- Farewell gift

dayInfo.description: Arrive at Ahmedabad - Arrival assistance at Ahmedabad International airport - Check in at Hotel - Briefing about entire program by representative/tour guide - Rest: Arrive at Ahmedabad International Airport. After clearing customs and immigrations you will be met by company representative awaiting with your transport. Check in at Hotel and relax. Meet your representative/tour guide after some time for orientation to the program with introduction to the culture of Gujarat, its rich craft and textile history and wildlife. Assisted Currency exchange if needed Rest of the day at leisure. Overnight at Ahmedabad.

Ahmedabad. Breakfast at Hotel - Visit Sidi Saiyid’s Mosque and a city walk - Visit Gandhi Ashram and Adalaj Stepwell: After Breakfast, proceed to the city walk and tuk tuk ride in old Ahmedabad, a UNESCO world heritage city. Ahmedabad is known for some of its unique Indo-Islamic buildings of the Medieval Period showing a unique synthesis of Hindu, Jain and Islamic artistic elements. The old city is a labyrinth of about 700 neighbourhoods known as Pols; a dense cluster of multi-storeyed homes built with the sense of community, security and minimizing harsh sunlight. Each Pol is built with the idea of privacy inside the main gate and interaction with other pols and bazaars on the outside. Post lunch, visit the Sabarmati ashram and discuss about life of Mahatma Gandhi, his principles and the independence movement of India. Sabarmati Ashram was one of the residences of Mahatma Gandhi from where he led the movement of independence. Even today, the ashram inspires many to follow on his footsteps of truth, democracy and self-dependence. The ashram runs a museum dedicated to his ideals and promotes the Khadi cotton movement. Visit Adalaj Stepwell, a 15th century monument and talk about water architecture and its importance on silk and spice routes on India. The Adalaj stepwell was integral to the semi-arid village as source of water for washing, bathing and drinking. Built in sandstone, the stepwells are 5 storeys deep with intricate carvings, beautiful oriel windows and spacious trabeat style of architecture. Overnight at Ahmedabad.

Ahmedabad – Lothal – Velavadar – Ahmedabad [295 km/6 hrs approx. with 2 stop] Breakfast at Hotel - Visit Lothal, an Indus valley site - Safari in Velavadar National Park - Drive to Ahmedabad: Early morning, depart for Lothal, an indus valley civilization site. Visit Lothal, one of the most prominent cities of the ancient Indus valley civilisation dating from 3700 BCE. Lothal's dock—the world's earliest known - connected the city to an ancient course of the Sabarmati river on the trade route between Harappan cities in Sindh and the peninsula of Saurashtra when the surrounding Kutch desert of today was a part of the Arabian Sea. It was a vital and thriving trade centre in ancient times, with its trade of beads, gems and valuable ornaments. Lunch at Velavadar. Post lunch, proceed for a safari in Blackbuck National Park. Enjoy a drive in the park which resembles African Savannah. See hundreds of blackbucks with chances to sighting Wolf and Hyena. Arrive at Ahmedabad by evening. Overnight at Ahmedabad.

Ahmedabad – Palanpur [By Surface: 164 km/3.5 Hrs drive approx.] Breakfast at Hotel - Visit Huteesinh Jain Temple - Drive to Araavali Hills - Check in and rest: Spend a relaxed morning breakfast. Post breakfast, visit the Huteesingh Jain Temple, a remarkable monument of Jain religion constructed in the time of drought to help the people. Talk about Jainism, the deities and the ornate pillars of temple, the stone screens and the inlay work. Depart for Palanpur (3.5 hours’ drive) post lunch. Check in by evening and rest. Palanpur is a remote and unexplored destination home to various tribes and pastoral communities. Nestled in the heart of the Araavali hills, the oldest mountain range in the world, Palanpur has an ancient system of coexistence between humans and wildlife. The people worship Bhakhar, Mountain god that blesses them with fertile lands. Overnight at Palanpur.

Palanpur. Breakfast at Hotel - Visit villages of Garasiya tribe and rabari community - Visit the village market and worship place - Folk Dance of Garasia tribe: The Garasia and Bhil tribals follow unique religious beliefs; they worship mountains and goddesses. The tradition of offering clay horses to god as a vehicle of their wishes and prayers is kept alive in their communities. The people of the Rabari community of north Gujarat are semi nomadic and live in large families. Visit nearby villages to meet the communities. The village markets are one of the most interesting sites. The people bring their fresh produce, poultry and other eclectic items. In the evening, visit their temple to learn about their belief system, customs and totem horses. Post dinner, enjoy the traditional dance by the Garasia community. Overnight at Palanpur.

Palanpur – Patan – Little Rann of Kutch [160 km/3.5 Hrs approx. with 1 break] Breakfast at Hotel - Drive to Little Rann of Kutch - Visit Queen’s Stepwells and Patola weaving at Patan - Visit to Modhera sun temple: Post breakfast, check out and depart for Little Rann of Kutch. En route, visit Patan Stepwell, a UNESCO world heritage site. The stepwell of Patan is a 11th century Solanki architecture monument with exquisite architecture and carvings unparalleled to any other wells. Adorned by deities, dancers and celestial beings, this unique monument served the city of patan as a place to fetch water and socialize as well as an inverted temple. The kings of former kingdom of Patan were patrons of arts. Hence, Patan became home to beautiful Patola sarees. The exquisitely intricate warp and weft work of patola sarees are considered a paragon of artwork throughout the world. Browse through its rich history and the links it had to the textiles of South East Asia. Lunch at Patan. Post lunch, visit the Modhera Sun Temple. The 11th century Sun temple of Modhera is made in maru gurjara style of architecture. The entire temple is adorned with mythological human figurines, gods, dancers, etc. Check in at Dasada by evening and relax for the day. Overnight at Dasada.

Little Rann of Kutch. Breakfast at Hotel - Wildlife Safari in Little Rann of Kutch - Visit to village on camel cart - Folk dance of Mir tribe: Post breakfast, go for a wildlife safari. The sanctuary is the last refuge for Indian Wild Ass or Khur. The wetlands near the sanctuary are the wintering ground for hords of migratory birds like Greater and lesser flamingo, pelicans, ducks, etc. Visit the salt pan workers in the sanctuary that produces about 65% of India’s salt. In the evening, go to a village safari in a camel cart to enjoy the village area. Interact with the nomadic tribe Mir and see their bead work. Meet women from semi nomadic Vagadia Rabari community to see their embroidery and talk about their lifestyle. Post dinner, enjoy the folk dance by nomadic Mir community. Overnight at Dasada.

Little Rann of Kutch – Bhuj [270 km/5.5 Hrs approx.] Breakfast at Hotel - Drive to Bhuj - Meet the Block printers and Weavers - Visit to LLDC museum: Post breakfast, depart for Bhuj. Arrive by Lunch time and check in. Visit Ajrakhpur, home to ajrakh or block printing textile work. Ajrakh is a unique block printing work from Kutch and Rajasthan in India. Traditionally, the ajrakh work is done using natural dyes, chiefly indigo and madder, on cotton and silk. It is made by Khatri community and is distinguished by its color - blue with red – and its complex geometric & floral patterns. Ajrakh printing, using natural dyes is one of the oldest techniques of resist printing in India and is one of the most complex and sophisticated methods of printing. Visit the weavers of Bhujodi and learn about their traditions of Vankar community, their signature weaves and the process of weaving. Visit the Living and Learning Design Centre which highlights folk arts and crafts of communities of Kutch. Overnight at Bhuj.

Bhuj. Breakfast at Hotel - Visit Aina Mahal and Prag Mahal - Visit Potters community - Visit antique shop: Post breakfast, visit the city of Bhuj. Visit the Aina Mahal and Prag Mahal. The beautiful Aina Mahal built in 1752 has an elaborately mirrored interior of European style with an inverted mirror of European Orientalism. The brilliant use of stain glass and chandeliers enhance the beauty of the palace. Built after Rao Pragmalji, the Prag Mahal is a 19th century beauty of indo saracenic architecture. The ornate Italian marble craftsmenship and Corinthian pillars are adorned with jali work around. Walk through the city markets. Visit the Khavda village to meet the potter’s community. The potters of Kutch specialize in making intricate clay design on the objects they make. Visit Mr Wazir at museum quality textiles to talk about the history and origins of different embroideries based of each community. Overnight at Bhuj.

Bhuj. Breakfast at Hotel - Meet weavers and rabari embroiderers - Meet artisans and see rogan work, lacquer work and copper bell work - Visit the picturesque white Rann (salt flatlands): Post breakfast, visit the weaver community at Sumrasar to learn about the traditions of the Vankar community, their signature weaves and the process of weaving. Each weaver has their own weaving style and materials they use to make scarves and shawls. Along with that, meet Rabari women to see their embroidery. The Dhebaria Rabaris are the pastoralists who wander with their cattle. They make one of the most intricate embroideries. Post lunch, depart for Nirona to meet the Rogan artisans. Rogan work is castor oil and vegetable colours mixed and heated in clay pot and then the paste is applied on fabric. Meet the family in Nirona who have kept the Rogan art alive. Meet the luhar community of copper bell makers and Lacquer work artisans from vadha community. Later for sunset proceed to the picturesque white desert created by millennia of deposition of salt crystals over it. The vast salt flat land is a sight to behold. Overnight at Bhuj.

Bhuj – Mumbai [ Flight / 2 hours] Early Morning flight to Mumbai - Dharavi slum walk - Marine Drive and Colaba causeway: Arrive by late morning in Mumbai and check in at the hotel. Post lunch, visit Asia’s largest Slum—Dharavi. The activity that goes on there is probably more than what a lot of Mumbai can boast of. Dharavi happens to be the go-to place for cheap housing and leather products. The leather industry alone is believed to be worth over 100 million US dollars. Pottery, papad-making, embroidery and soap-making are just a few of the other small-scale industries that give Dharavi a turnover exceeding 600 million US dollars. These thriving businesses (which export to countries around the globe) are often conducted in hovels with sheets of blue tarpaulin acting as walls. By then it will be dusk and you can have a panoramic view of the Queen’s Necklace along Marine Drive, the best known and iconic visual mnemonic for Mumbai. Drive down Marine Drive and along the Gateway of India for a view of the city by night. You have the evening to yourself to shop around a bit, or just chill over a glass of beer at Leopold Café on the Causeway. Overnight in Mumbai.

Mumbai. Breakfast at Hotel - Elephanta Caves -Khotachiwadi: Post breakfast, visit the Elephanta caves today. The origins of the UNESCO World Heritage Site that is the Elephanta Caves are shrouded in mystery, but what is undoubted is that it is one of the finest tributes to Lord Shiva that you can find. Originally called Gharapuri, the Portuguese rechristened it Elephanta in the 16th century after the huge elephant statue they found at its entrance. Your guide will walk you through a secret path to the cave complex on top of the hill. The complex has 2 main caves, which between them, are home to huge statues that are made with delicate detail. Perhaps the most breathtaking of all the statues is the Trimurti or the Maheshmurti–a 21 feet high depiction of Shiva as the Creator, Protector, and Destroyer. You will be taken through the hidden nuances of the other statues and see how viewing them from different positions brings different perspectives. Post lunch, visit Khotachiwadi, a historical part that shows how Bombay was back in the day. The narrow winding lanes of Khotachiwadi village are home to old Portuguese-style bungalows and a tiny church. A walk though Khotachiwadi village will transport you back in time to relive this part of Mumbai's history. Overnight in Mumbai.

Mumbai. Breakfast at hotel - Dhobi Ghaat and Dabba walla - Lalbaug Bazaar: Early morning visit Dhobi Ghaat at Cuffe Parade - a place that is unlike any laundry service you have ever seen. Washermen are hard at work beating the dirt out of clothes at stone cubicles, while others hang a kaleidoscope of clothes out to dry on makeshift lines quite ingeniously, without the help of clothes pins. Whether it is two thousand white sheets a day for the Four Seasons Hotel, or the saris of women from high-rises across the city, these dhobis get the job done cheerily and efficiently. Then visit the dabba wallas. The footpath outside Churchgate station serves as a reconnaissance point, where the men in Gandhi topis (caps) wade among rows of hundreds of dabbas, and take them to offices where hungry executives wait in earnest for their home cooked meal to arrive. Visit the local bazaars. Criss-crossing narrow lanes, tiny shops spilling with colourful wares and people haggling for a better deal. Have a mouth-watering line up of regional Stop over at Matunga for a South Indian Lunch at Madras Café. Go for a quick drive through the flower market of Matunga and enjoy a riot of colours before you. Spend your evening packing for the onwards journey.
Mumbai. Breakfast at hotel - Depart for onwards flight: Depart for your flight back home with fond memories!

tourName: Gujarat and Rajasthan holiday
generalInfo:
This 15-day immersive journey takes you through two of India’s most culturally and ecologically rich states: Gujarat and Rajasthan. You will experience a blend of vibrant cities, wildlife encounters, and ancient heritage. Starting in Ahmedabad, home to Mahatma Gandhi's legacy, you’ll traverse landscapes teeming with wildlife, explore historic cities, and relax in heritage properties. Indian Desert is a mix of dry scrub jungles, wild coastline, salt pans and sand dunes that host a plethora of rich wildlife that have adapted to these conditions. The search for water and pastures has led to the creation of many nomadic tribal cultures in the area too. In this comprehensive journey through western India we tracking the only Asiatic Lions left in the world - Explore the last true savannahs of India in search of wolves, hyenas and blackbuck, roam across the vast salt pans of Kutch. Deep dive into the lives of leopards and shepherds in Bera – walk around the old desert kingdom of Jodhpur - Stand among the largest crane congregation on the planet. Explore the dunes and sacred groves of the Thar desert around Jaisalmer from a tented camp.

Highlights include:
• A heritage walk through the historic streets of Ahmedabad.
• Incredible birding across the deserts and wetlands of Western India with over 400 species.
• Great opportunities for wildlife photography including some unique frames seen nowhere else in the planet.
• Jeep Safaris to look for Asiatic lions, leopards, hyenas, wolves and birds like raptors, large flamingo colonies and great Indian bustards across truly incredible habitats.
• A morning with 100000 migrating demoiselle cranes.
• Exploring the stunning salt flats of the Little Rann of Kutch.
• Visiting Mehrangarh Fort in Jodhpur, one of India's largest forts, and guided walk in old town.
• Experiencing the Golden City of Jaisalmer and its famed sand dunes.

dayInfo.description: Ahmedabad : Arrive into Ahmedabad Airport and transfer to the hotel near the Airport. (CP). Evening Heritage walk among the streets and markets of old town Ahmedabad.
Ahmedabad to Gir: Checkout early with packed breakfast and drive towards Gir (7 hrs). Arrive for a late lunch and a short guided walk of the property and the forests around.
Gir: Morning and afternoon safaris into the various zones of Gir National Park looking for lone male Asiatic lions and the large prides that Gir is famous for.
Gir to Velavadar : After another morning safari at Gir seeking lions, leopards and other wildlife, we head out towards Velavadar Blackbuck National Park (4 hrs), the next destination.

Velavadar: Morning and afternoon safaris in the Grasslands of Velavadar seeking Indian wolves, hyenas, herds of blackbuck and the many harriers, lesser kestrels and other birds that call this grassland world their home.

Velavadar to Little Rann of Kutch: After another morning safari at Velavadar, we head out with packed lunches towards the Kutch peninsula and the salt flats of the Little Rann (4 hrs). En-route if time permits, we will stop at the wetlands of Nalsarovar for specific birds that are found here. Dinner at hotel.

Little Rann of Kutch: Morning and afternoon jeep excursions into the wetlands, scrub jungles and the salt desert of the Little Rann seeking the endemic Asiatic wild ass, desert foxes, Houbara bustards, flamingoes and various species of raptors that winter in this habitat.

Little Rann of Kutch: Another day of safaris in the Little Rann’s vast 5000 sq km wilderness and the surrounding wetlands in search of pallid scops owls, short-eared owls, various species of cranes and other wildlife.

Kutch - Ahmedbad - Jodhpur: Checkout after breakfast and drive to Ahmedabad to catch the afternoon flight to Jodhpur- the heritage city at the edge of the desert. Transfer to the hotel for an evening of rest.
Jodhpur to Phalodi: We spend the first half exploring Jodhpur on a guided excursion. Post lunch we drive 3.5 hrs to the village of Phalodi for dinner and rest.

Phalodi to Jaisalmer: Witness the spectacle of Demoiselle Crane congregation in the village of Keechan near Phalodi followed by breakfast and transfer (3 hrs) to the desert dune landscape of Jaisalmer. Arrive and evening at leisure. Option to visit the Jaisalmer fort en-route

Jaisalmer: Head out for morning and afternoon guided safaris into the sand dunes, scrub jungles and sacred groves of Desert National Park to find the Great Indian bustard, 6 species of vultures and many raptors, sandgrouse, wheatears, hoopoe larks, hypocolius and trumpeter finches among many other bird and mammal species

Jaisalmer: Head out for morning and afternoon guided safaris into the sand dunes, scrub jungles and sacred groves of Desert National Park to find the Great Indian bustard, 6 species of vultures and many raptors, sandgrouse, wheatears, hoopoe larks, hypocolius and trumpeter finches among many other bird and mammal species

Jaisalmer - Jodhpur - Ahmedabad : Checkout post breakfast and transfer to Jodhpur Airport for the flight back to Ahmedabad. Transfer to hotel and repack. Evening heritage walk optional. Night at Ahmedabad
Departure

tourName: Gujarat cultural holiday, India
placesVisited: Ahmedabad, Poshina, Kutch Desert, visit Mir tribal settlements, visit tribal families in Hodka, Junagadh, Sasan Gir National Park, Palitana temple sites, ruined port of Lothal, Vadodara
generalInfo:
This Gujarat cultural holiday takes you to a state that played host to the early Indus Valley Civilization 4,000 years ago at Lothal & Dholavira. The region evolved from there into several princely states that made up the region of Saurashtra.

Saurashtra’s distinction was that it remained independent from colonial British India until independence, forming its distinct identity. From the powerful Hindu temple of Somnath, to Gujarat’s unique landscape and geography, to its distinct tribal communities and wildlife - including the migratory birdlife of the Great Kutch Desert and the majestic Asiatic Lion – Gujarat makes for a unique and fascinating holiday.

dayInfo.description: Ancient Stepwells and Mosques – step-wells and the unique and very traditional artisan technique of Patan Pataola Saree weaving; a tradition carried forward by generations of weaver families.

Indus Valley’s Lothal ruined city – Tracing your way back to Ahmedabad, we’ll explore the ruined port of Lothal. One of the most prominent citiies of the ancient Indus Valley Civilization which connected the ancient Harappan city in the Sindh to the Arabian Sea. You’ll proceed to spend the night in the city of Ahmedabad.

Colonial Vadodara & historic Champaner in a day – We’ll take you on a day trip south of Ahmedabad to the city of Vadodara to explore it’s colonial architectural glory and then contrast it with the historic Sultanate and Rajputana region of Champaner before you head back to Ahmedabad for the night and to cap your trip through this fascinating region.

tourName: Gujarat holiday and the Rann of Kutch, India
placesVisited: Ahmedabad, Rann of Kutch salt marsh and salt desert, Bhuj, Poshina, UNESCO heritage Champaner, Jain temples - Shatrunjaya, Sun temple at Modhera, Tribal villages, Arabian Sea shoreline, Gondal, Baroda, Indian textiles
generalInfo:
Gujarat is one of India's most dazzlingly diverse states, home to both a 1600km coastline and one of the world's largest salt deserts. Seasonal marshlands around the Little Rann are a wildlife beacon for wild ass and flamingos, while Gujarat is renowned for some of the finest textiles in India. Its large Jain community underpin both a stunning heritage of white marble temples plus exquisite vegetarian cuisine.

This village-focused tour opens up this wondrous state, from the surreal Rann of Kutch and the ancient town of Bhuj to tribal Poshina, the UNESCO World Heritage site of Champaner and the marvellous mountain top Jain temple complex at Shatrunjaya.

Kick off in the state capital Ahmedabad with visits to perhaps the world's finest textile museum plus Mahatma Gandhi’s ashram, as well as touring the atmospheric old city. Your rural odyssey begins with tribal villages of the Garacia, Adivacyi & Bharad en route to Poshina, plus the Kumbharia Jain Temples and a lakeside picnic lunch.

Following visits to the step-well at Patan and the 1000-year-old Sun temple at Modhera, you reach the eye-popping landscape of the Kutch – vast seasonal salt marshes that become giant salt deserts in the hottest months. Discover how indigenous people and wildlife thrive in both the Little Rann of Kutch and Great Rann.

The Arabian Sea beckons next, tracing the coast for several hours to Gondal, where you stay in one of three fabulous palaces here. Visit the town's famous market, temples plus grand houses – one boasting a fine vintage car collection, another the home of the royal family of Palitana.

You'll also visit the breathtaking Jain temple complex at Shatrunjaya, as well as Laxmi Vilas Palace, Fatehsingh Museum and UNESCO-listed Champaners ancient fort around Baroda.

Price includes all activities/equipment, tour leaders, local guides and drivers, meals, mineral water, all transport (excluding international flights) , all accommodation and all entrance fees as outlined in the itinerary.

dayInfo.description: Tour starts in Ahmedabad: Those on the group flights will arrive early afternoon. After some time to refresh and recuperate at the hotel our tour will begin early evening with our welcome meeting and first group dinner.

Ahmedabad: Gandhi Ashram and the Old City: After breakfast, we will do our best, for those that want to, visit the textile museum with its Calico collection and the Gandhi Ashram. Please note that places on the museum tour are limited, but we will do our best to secure these (please note the important information in the key aspects to consider section). In the afternoon we will have time to explore the city at our own leisure before an early dinner. After dinner we take stroll through the bustling evening streets to get a feel for life in the old city on our way back to the hotel.

Ahmedabad - Poshina: Havelis and Rudabai Stepwell: After breakfast we take a guided heritage walk taking us through some of the most ancient parts of the city through narrow streets, past old havelis and monuments. We then leave Ahmedabad behind us to see visit the beautiful ancient Rudabai Stepwell, located in the village of Adalaj before continuing our journey north into the tribal region of Poshina (approx. 4 hours driving). Once there we check into the palace home of the former ruling royal family where we will be staying for the next 2 nights.

Poshina: Local Tribes and Jain Temples: After breakfast we take jeeps to the surrounding area visiting the Bhil and Garasia tribe and make a stop to see the terracotta army of horses. We will head back to the hotel for lunch before visiting the nearby Kumbharia Jain Temples built in the 11th century and local market. We finish the day by the lake for sun downers before returning to hotel for some tribal music and dinner.

Poshina - Dasada: The Sun Temple: Today we drive west taking in the staggering step-well at Patan and a demonstration of Ikat textile weaving before a visit to the ancient temple at Modhera. Situated on the banks of the Pushpavati River, Modhera is famous for its millennium-old Sun temple. This temple, built in 1026 AD by Bhimadeva of the Solanki Rajput clan, is dedicated to Lord Surya, the sun god. It was destroyed by Muhammad Ghaznavi and rebuilt later. The temple was designed so that at the time of the equinoxes, the first rays of the sun fell on the image of Surya. The temple is partially in ruins now but, despite the passage of time, it is still considered an architectural wonder. After our visit we drive on to Dasada where we stay for the next two nights. Approx. 5 hours driving.

Little Rann of Kutch: Explore the Salt Marsh: Today we take an excursion into the Little Rann of Kutch. An extraordinary and unique landscape, this vast desiccated, unbroken surface of dark silt, encrusted with salt, transforms into a spectacular coastal wetland after it rains. Here we witness the indigenous wild ass and other wild animals, as well as watching the women of the Mir and Rabari tribes creating some of the most remarkable textiles in the country.

Dasada - Bhuj: The Living and Learning Design Centre: Today we head to the capital of the Kutch region, Bhuj. On our way, we will visit The Living and Learning Design Centre, an initiative by the Shrujan trust to promote and preserve the beautiful craft heritage of Kutch. After lunch we head north to where we will be staying and from where we will access local villages. Approx. 6.5 hours driving

Rann of Kutch: Banni and the White Sands: After breakfast we spend all day visiting the northern villages of this remote area. Though the Rann of Kutch is famed for its wildlife, there is much more to experience in this dry arid place. We will visit a Banni region community that are again famed for their handiwork and embroidery. We head further north towards the edge of the Great Rann to see the mirage of the salt flats on the horizon which is known as “White Sands”.

Bhuj - Mandvi: Indigo Masters and the Gujarati Coast: Today we leave early to head back to the capital of the Kutch region, Bhuj. Sadly much of Bhuj was destroyed during the earthquake of 2001, but the Aina Mahal is still well worth visiting. We also have the chance visit an Indigo masters workshop to see the process of block printing. Having done this we head on to the coast and the Arabian Sea (approx. 1.5 hours driving). Arriving early afternoon we check into our hotel and spend the rest of the day enjoying this relaxing setting. There is an optional visit to the summer palace and the town where there are more handicraft shops or you might prefer to spend some time relaxing on the beach.

Mandvi - Gondal: The Princely State: After breakfast there will be a chance to visit the incredible wooden dhow building industry before driving on to Gondal. The drive today will be long, about 8 hours dependent on the road conditions and the number of stops along the way. Gondal is a testimony to the great visionary ruler Sir Bhagwatsinhiji, who introduced social reforms, planned the development of Gondal town and created a model state of Saurashtra in late 19th and early 20th century. Gondal, the capital of the former princely State of Gondal, was ruled by the Jadeja Rajput clan, until the independence of India. It is a fortified town located on the river Gondali and is home to three fabulous palaces – one of which we stay in – and the Maharaja’s classic car collection. Here we see many of the amazing forts and palaces and the rather lovely old town: quiet and pretty, it puts one in mind of Bundi or Udaipur 20 years ago.

Gondal: From the Palace to the Markets: After breakfast we visit the famous city palace, with its owner’s classic & vintage car collection. We can also see some spinning and weaving of khadhi cloth. In the late afternoon will visit the local market and famous temple to participate in the evening aarti.

Gondal - Bhavnagar: To the Royal Palace: This morning we will visit the local Gondal market, before starting our journey to another heritage property and home to the royal family of Bhavnagar, an oasis within the hustle and bustle of the town. For those that wish to, there should be time this afternoon for us to do some exploring before dinner. Approx 4 hours driving.

Bhavnagar - Palitana - Bhavnagar: Sacred Mount Shertunjaya: We will have an early wake-up today to visit the amazing Jain temples: 3500 steps up Mount Shertunjaya. This extraordinary temple city is one of the highlights of any trip to India. After lunch we drive back to Bhavnagar, where we’ll have the afternoon to relax and recover from our morning’s exertions.

Bhavnagar - Vadodara: Laxmi Vilas Palace and Fatehsingh Museum: This morning we will drive to Vadodara. Along with Kashmir, Hyderabad, Gwalior and Mysore, in British time Vadodara was a ‘21 gun salute’ state. As such, it is fabulously wealthy with an exquisite palace. We arrive into Vadodara late morning and after a late lunch we visit the totally over the top Laxmi Vilas Palace and the Fatehsingh Museum. Approx. 4 hours driving

Vadodara - Champaner - Ahmedabad: Champaner UNSECO Site: Today we visit the UNESCO World Heritage site at Champaner. Champaner is an ancient fort located at the foothills of Pavagadh. Muhammad Begada decided to establish the new capital of Gujarat at this place in 1484 AD and changed the name of the town to Muhammadabad. It took 23 years to build the town and it had a meteoric rise to fame, attaining glory as a great town of western India. It also became a major trading centre producing fine silk, woven and dyed textiles and sword manufacturing. The entire landscape for miles around is scattered with remains of fort walls, ruined tombs, gardens, arches, pillars and wells and reminds one of other such great deserted towns of India: Mandu, Hampi, Orchha and Fatehpur Sikri. We will return to Vadodara for a late lunch before a transfer back to Ahmedabad where we have our farewell dinner.
Tour ends in Ahmedabad: The tour finishes this morning in Ahmedabad after breakfast.
