After being met in Delhi, you will be transferred to a hotel for the night before taking a domestic flight to Jabalpur to start your safari holiday. All domestic flights are included in the price of your holiday.

This tailor made holiday is designed by a wildlife watching specialist operator and, in particular, wild cat safaris. As well as Kanha National Park, we can organise tailor made safaris to other national parks in India where there are tiger populations, such as Bandhavgarh, Corbett or Ranthambore. You will be accompanied by an expert local guide and will take at least five safaris within a park to maximise viewing opportunities.

We also recommend a night time spotting safari, although this is only possible in Panna and Satpura National Parks, using night vision equipment to spot tigers at night. In Satpura National Park you can also go on a walking safari but whichever way you choose to go in search of tigers, we will ensure it is an ethical experience, as we are member of the Tour Operators for Tigers (TOFT) and follow their strict codes of practice. We also stay in TOFT approved lodges along the way.

We are proud of our 100% sighting rate and of course, you will also get a chance to see a wide array of other wildlife, not just tigers. Please note that we are very happy to organise this trip for a solo traveller as well as for groups. The minimum age is eighteen.

The best time to go tiger watching in India is mid January to mid May. This is the hot dry season with the hottest time from beginning March until mid May. This is when tigers come out to waterholes to find water, or prey on other wildlife doing the same.

dayInfo.description: Delhi – Arrival – On your arrival in Delhi you will be met at the airport by your local driver and transferred in a private vehicle to your accommodation. (Lunch and or Dinner included (depending on the time of arrival)).

Kanha National Park – Travelling– This morning after breakfast you will be transferred to the airport to catch the short internal flight to Jabalpur. Here you will be transferred to your accommodation close to Kanha National Park. Tonight it is best to get an early night as you will be exploring the park on the trail of tigers early tomorrow. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included)

Jabalpur – Sightseeing – This morning will see you have your 9th and final tiger safari into the park, if you have already seen tigers on the tour and wish to get better pictures of the other wildlife or want to try and find dhole we can accommodate different ideas today; but of course this is all up to you. Once you return to the accommodation you will have breakfast and pack your packs before being transferred back to Jabalpur. On arrival at the accommodation you can have lunch and in the afternoon you can take a cultural tour of Bhedaghat to see the Marble Rocks, Duandhar Falls and Chausath Yogini Temple as well as their being a river cruise of the Narmada River on offer. (Breakfast, Lunch & Dinner included)

Delhi – Sightseeing – Today after breakfast you will be taken to the domestic airport to catch the short internal flight back to Delhi. Once in Delhi you will be transferred back to the accommodation and you will have the rest of the day to relax, souvenir shop or sightsee around old and new Delhi. (Breakfasts, Lunches & Dinners included)
Home – Departure – This morning after breakfast you will be transferred to the airport in time to catch your return flight home. (Breakfast only)

tourName: Tribal and rural experience of India
generalInfo:
Dear future traveller :)

Welcome! This tour of tribes of Arunachal Pradesh can be customized according to your preference to include experiences like wildlife, history, village life, crafts, culinary and more. You can also choose to add other excursions like Kolkata, Meghalaya, Kaziranga national park, Majuli island, Delhi, Agra & Varanasi to this tour. Your preferences can be included the way you want and according to your budget.
**
Best time for Arunachal Pradesh: October - April
**

Arunachal Pradesh is one of the most densely forested states of India where a large number of tribes live. Some of the main tribes are Adi, Galo, Apatani, Nyishi, Hill Miri. Apart from these, there are many sub-tribes under each of these which have further clans under them. Each of these tribes live in harmony with nature and have their own unique dresses, cuisine, dances, songs, festivals, marriage rituals and customs. Some of these tribes like Apatani are primarily agrarian whereas others like Tagin and Adi have been fierce warriors. Their food, dances and songs are influenced by their lifestyle and history.

Although Arunachal Pradesh is connected to other parts of India and a lot of people now travel to other cities for jobs, the natives still live their traditional lives. This tour also provides access to alternate income for the locals which helps in preserving their culture. We will talk more about that in Responsible Travel section below.

This is not meant to be only a sightseeing tour. It is rather an immersive experience where you can participate in daily life of the tribes through various activities designed for you. We also recommend that you take this journey slow and spend ample leisure time soaking in the nature and life of Arunachal Pradesh.

About Us: We come from diverse background of travel writing, photography, social development sector and corporate experience. We are well travelled in India, and understand the villages, its people, and the grass root issues of our country well. Therefore the trips are designed to directly provide environmental, economic and social benefit to the local community. Hope to see you in India soon.

dayInfo.description: Today we start the journey from Guwahati after breakfast and drive through the smooth highways cutting across rice fields and tea gardens of Assam. Arrive at Nameri national park which is a gateway to both central as well as western Arunachal Pradesh. Check-in to your accommodation followed by late lunch in your private garden. Rest of the day will be available at leisure. Nameri national park is perfect place for unadulterated nature and bird lovers. You may also choose to go on a short excursion to Jia Bhoroli River or simply spend time soothing your senses in your luxury accommodation amidst nature.

After a leisurely stay at Nameri national park and a sumptuous breakfast, we depart for Itanagar, the capital city of Arunachal Pradesh. En-route you will also go through the border post for regular checking of your permits. Arrive at your hotel by noon followed by check-in. Rest of the day will be available at leisure. Or you may choose to visit the Buddhist temple and Ita fort. Your journey over next few days will take you back in time and into the hinterlands of mystic Arunachal Pradesh.

Depart for the fabled Ziro valley, the land of Apatani tribe. It is undeniably the most picturesque in Arunachal Pradesh. We drive through the smooth highways for another 60 km before embarking on a bumpy ride on old mountain roads that head to Ziro. Arunachal Pradesh is sparsely populated as compared to other states of North East or Northern India. Therefore you may often find yourself travelling through pristine rain forests without any sign of human habitation. Ziro valley is a sprawling expanse of green and golden rice fields. Accordingly to a local folklore, the mountain which lord Hanuman extracted for Sanjeevani plant once existed over Ziro valley. Locals say that Ziro valley was formed because a huge mountain was scooped off from the earth by Lord Hanuman. To prove this folklore, they insist that medicinal plants found in Ziro valley that got carried away with the mountain are found in southern Meghalaya also. This is because part of the mud and plants from the mountain which Lord Hanuman was carrying fell off in Meghalaya on its way to Sri Lanka. While you stay in Ziro, know about many such interesting stories. Spend the next few days in Ziro relaxing in your accommodation. Go with us on short trails of Apatani tribal villages and see how they live in harmony with nature. Taste local food and learn to cook it. You may also choose to participate in farming depending upon the season or visit the pisciculture farm. Discover the unique stories behind facial tattoos and wooden nose plugs of Apatani women. Apatani people are followers of Donyi-Polo religious practices, which is about worshipping Sun (Donyi) and the Moon (Polo). See how this is practiced in daily life. Apart from the activities, we also recommend that you spend ample leisure time soaking in the natural beauty of Ziro valley and talking to locals.

We drive further to Daporijo, which lies in the heart of Arunachal Pradesh. It is the home of Hill Miri and Tagin tribes. Over the centuries, the smaller Hill Miri tribe has merged with the more dominant Nyishi tribe. However, locals say that Tagin is the only tribe which has traditionally comprised of warriors, and are not afraid of Nyishi people. After a long drive from Ziro winding through the remote mountains, arrive at Daporijo by evening. Check-in your hotel and relax for the day. Spend the next full day exploring the small Tagin villages. Visit the houses of Tagin people and see how animals play an important part in their life. Pig and Gayal (Mithun) are integral parts of food and religious ceremonies and spend time with the Tagin community. You may also visit the local fruit, vegetable and meat markets that are mostly run by women. The vegetables and spices found in this part of India are very different. Walk with us into a friendly market with smiling faces where you can even sit and have a chat with anyone of the ladies.

Aalo is headquarters of the West Siang district which is surrounded by China on the north, East Siang and Upper Siang districts on east, and Assam on the south. It is home of tribes like Galo, Bori, Bokar, Memba and Ramos. You may visit the tribal villages or participate in traditional dances. Get involved in the all women dance which is done on auspicious occasions, especially during harvesting season. It has gentle hymns and rhythmic movements, and is done in groups. The dances by men on other hand comprise of aggressive and intimidating movements. Taste the traditional food of Adi and Galo tribes

After spending the days deep inside Arunachal, we now drive down to Pasighat which is on the foothills near Siang River. Arrive at you accommodation by evening and relax for the day with a soothing view of dense forests and Siang River. Spend the next full day participating in either of the following activities depending upon your preference. Trek to the remote villages of Galo and Minyong tribe (4-6 hrs of trekking). The duration of trekking can be adjusted based on your fitness level. Go for rafting on Siang river

It is time to say goodbye to mystic Arunachal Pradesh and enter Assam once again. Your journey from Pasighat to Dibrugarh will be a mix of road and ferry crossing as there is no bridge connecting Arunachal Pradesh with Assam in this region. The experience of crossing Brahmaputra River on a ferry is truly amazing as you travel with local villagers, fishermen and natives from both Assam and Arunachal Pradesh. You may choose to take onward flight from Dibrugarh or drive back to Guwahati.

tourName: West central India wildlife holiday
generalInfo:
Nestled in West-central India, the lure of the Tiger at Tadoba and the fascinating undulating landscape at Pench is what drew us here many years ago in the pursuit of our love of photographing the stunning diversity of wildlife and game in what has come to be among the list of India’s best managed wildlife reserves on the sub-continent.

The etymology of Tadoba comes from the amalgamation of the tribal God Taru and the Andhari river that serves as the reserve’s water vein, filling it’s fresh water lakes during the brutal summer months.

Situated in the western state of Maharashtra, Tadoba’s wildlife fringes the local Gond tribal settlements around the region of Chandrapur. Traditional farmers and basket weavers, these tribes dwell in traditional village homes. Over the years we’ve cultivated a support system with these communities where we share with travellers what they do and how they carry on their process of living. We attempt to give back for our footprint in the region by supporting these communities by sourcing their produce and enlightening travellers about their culture and heritage.

It’s important to not just understand the rich bio-diversity of the park but also be made aware of the social conservation that inherently exists amongst these villages and their efforts in establishing a stable co-existence, especially within such close proximity, between man and wildlife in this region.

Pench on the other hand is situated in slightly hillier terrain over the border of Maharashtra and into the state of Madhya Pradesh in Central India.

Serving as an inspiration for Rudyard Kipling’s Jungle Book as home to Mowgli, it’s easy to see why Sir David Attenborough described Pench as the most appropriate location for documenting the behavior of Tigers in the wild.

Spread over an area of 750 square kilometres, Pench’s undulating terrain makes for a fascinating mix of plant species, rock caves and a fantastic diversity in woodland bird species.

But again, Pench is not just about the Tiger. In fact the excitement in pursuing unique species such as the four-horned Antelopes, wild dog packs, the elusive Leopards and the rather sly Indian Jackals.

With some of the best managed and regulated game drives within national Parks in India, the experience in Pench is of anticipation, intrigue and the satisfaction of being amidst nature in it’s best preserved state.

dayInfo.description: Transition to Tadoba: Using Mumbai as the international gateway, we’ll have you take a short hop domestic flight to the city of Nagpur from where you’ll travel overland to the village of Pet and your eco lodge by the river. The rest of this day is designed to be at leisure to settle in and shake off the long travel.

The Gond settlement of Pet and the wetland Birds: Beginning the day gently pedaling away to the village of Pet, on the fringes of Tadoba’s wildlife reserve, we’ll spend a good part of the day with these reticent tribal folk, observing their farming techniques, spending time with the women who weave baskets from forest produce and engage in conversation with them about how they supplement their sustenance with forest produce around them. Over the course of the late afternoon, you’ll head out for a walk with a Naturalist to hopefully get up close with the unique wetland birds, both resident and migratory that make their way to these parts.
Transition to Pench National Park: Leaving the Gonds and tigers of Tadoba, we’ll head north to the undulating mountains of Pench National Park.
Return to Nagpur and a night in Mumbai: Heading south to Nagpur, you’ll return to Mumbai to spend the night in preparation for your flight back home.

tourName: Western Ghats wildlife tour in India
generalInfo:
Running along the western edge of the Deccan Plateau in the states of Karnataka and Kerala, the Western Ghats mountains separate the Deccan Plateau from the narrow coastal plain which runs along the Arabian Sea.

This is the setting for one of the 36 world’s designated “hottest biodiversity hotspots”. This region supports an astonishing 5,000 species of flowering plants, around 140 mammals, over 500 birds and nearly 180 amphibians, many of them threatened. More importantly, this hotspot is home to great endemism including about 20 endemic mammals. Among flagship mammals, the most prominent are the Lion-tailed Macaque, found in highly fragmented tropical rain forests of the Western Ghats and the endemic Nilgiri Tahr, which lives in the montane grasslands of the Western Ghats. Over 30 species of birds are endemic or near endemic to this region and this tour will also seek to see them all.

On this journey, you will also be sighting the other major wildlife like the Asian elephants, Sloth Bears, Dholes and possibly the big cats. Commencing at Thattekkad and circumventing the Western Ghats at Munnar, the Anamalai hills, the Nilgiri Hills, the dry deciduous and scrub forests at Bandipur and Chinnar and finally the magnificent forests of Nagarhole, you will be accompanied at all times by a knowledgeable local naturalist who knows where to find the most elusive species. Travelling by SUVs or mini buses, comfortable specialist accommodation throughout and memorable local cuisines, all add to the experience.

The journey also will take you through tribal lands of Indigenous people – like the Muduvans of Munnar area, the Malapulayas of Chinnar and the Kattunayakan of Mudumalai – and share their tribal way of life and closeness to nature.

dayInfo.description: Arrive Kochi International Airport & transfer to Thattekkad – an area with extensive lowland forests and several types of eco-systems – riverine, grasslands, evergreen, scrub, dry deciduous, lowland forest, enabling it to be one of the best wildlife and birding destinations in India and home to some of the endemic mammals of the Western Ghats. The wildlife includes Indian Flying Fox, Malabar Giant Squirrel, the elusive Slender Loris, Indian Giant Flying Squirrel, Travancore Flying squirrel and the Common Palm Civet. This is also a great place for endemic birds, butterflies & odonata. You should see White-bellied Treepie, Rufous Babbler, Crimson-backed Sunbird, White-bellied Blue Flycatcher, Wynaad Laughingthrush, Malabar Parakeet, Malabar Grey Hornbill and owls which could include Mottled Wood Owl, Oriental Bay Owl, Oriental Scops Owl, Brown Fish Owl and Spot-bellied Eagle Owl. Sri Lanka Frogmouth, Red Spurfowl, Grey Jungle Fowl, Indian Pitta, Black-throated Munia and the Grey-headed Fish Eagle are all likely.

Today you will be moving to the hill country at Munnar - the highest areas along the Western Ghats. Among its rolling grasslands and steep cliffs live the endemic and endangered Nilgiri Tahrs. Concerted efforts by the conservationists have brought this magnificent animal back from the brink of extinction. At present there are more than 700 Tahrs in the area. The highlights would be a visit to the Eravikulam National Park area in search of this mild natured animal and as well as a trip to the Pampadum Shola – to look for the endemic Nilgiri Marten, Nilgiri Langurs, Malabar Giant Squirrel and endemic birds like the Nilgiri Wood pigeon, Nilgiri Pipit, Painted Bush Quail, Nilgiri Wood Pigeon, Black-and-Orange Flycatcher, Nilgiri Flycatcher, White-bellied Shortwing and the Broad-tailed Grassbird.

A longish travel day today as we head downslope to Chinnar Wildlife Sanctuary. Here on your walk, look out for the endemic Grey Tufted Langur (or Madras Langur) and the near-threatened Grizzled Giant Squirrel, besides Star Tortoise. There are good chances of other wildlife like elephants and gaurs. Special birds to look out for include Yellow-legged Buttonquail and White-naped Woodpecker, Brown Fish owls and Spot-bellied Eagle Owls. After Chinnar you will be taking the 2 hour drive across the Tamil Nadu border to the forests of Valparai near Indira Gandhi national park - a place known for its great swathes of forests and wildlife. Elephants, sloth bears, leopards, gaurs, dholes (wild dogs) but the focus will be on the endemic Lion-tailed Macaques (on IUCN’s Red Data list for being a threatened species) which can be spotted in the high altitude rain forests here, their natural habitat.

Another long drive will take you to Ooty in the mountains. Here also there are chances of sighting of the Nilgiri Marten if missed earlier. The target birds here include the Nilgiri Thrush, the Nilgiri laughing Thrush, White-bellied Shortwing, Black-and-rufous, Rusty-tailed and Nilgiri Flycatchers. The century-old Botanical gardens and the Cairnhill Forest reserve are the other places visited during stay here.

You will be making your way to a tiger reserve sanctuary within the Nilgiri Biosphere Reserve – Bandipur, located between the Mudumalai Sanctuary on one hand and the Forests of Wayanad on the other. Devoted to conserving the endangered Tiger Habitat you also get to see endemics birds like Malabar Parakeet, Malabar Lark and Grey-headed Bulbul at the foothills of the Nilgiris. Seasonal streams along with the river Kabini are watering holes for the abundant wildlife of the region. You will also be going on two vehicle safaris into the Bandipur Tiger Reserve. Look out for the abundant wildlife here which includes large population of wildlife including Elephants, Sloth Bears, Four Horned Antelope, Hyena, Wild Dog, Common Langurs, Tigers, Leopards, Chital, Mouse Deer, Spotted Deer, Jackal, Porcupine and Mongoose and with some luck the big cats including the tiger and leopard. Accommodation would be at the Bandipur Safari Lodge belonging to the renowned Jungle Lodges & Resorts. (2 Jeep safaris)

Transfer to one of the best wildlife destination in South India – Nagarhole. The place derives its name from Kannada - "Naga" meaning snake and "hole" referring to streams. The area was an exclusive hunting reserve of the former rulers of Mysore. It was set up in 1955 and is one of the best-managed parks in the country. This park is located to the northwest of Bandipur National Park. Kabini reservoir separates this park from Bandipur National Park. The climate is tropical, summers are hot and winters are pleasant. The park boasts of a healthy Tiger-predator ratio. Tigers, gaurs (Indian Bison) and Elephants are much denser here than in other reserves in South India. In fact this National Park is the best destination for viewing tigers and Asiatic elephants in large numbers during the four vehicle safaris during your stay here. The amazing wildlife in this area also includes Hyenas, Dholes (Wild Dogs), Sloth bears, Common Langurs, Leopards, Mouse Deer and Spotted Deer.
After morning safari, transfer to Bangalore for your flight home.

tourName: Western India tour, Mumbai to New Delhi
generalInfo:
We all have heard about the Golden Triangle of India based in the Northern part; but have you heard about the Golden Triangle which is based in the Western Region of the country? In this tour, we would be covering the same along with the renowned Golden Triangle of Northern India.

Explore the City of Dreams – Mumbai and witness some spectacular sites. Meet the Bollywood Celebrities while visiting the Movie Sets and witness the craft getting unfolded in front of you. Take a boat ride and a toy train ride to reach the ancient Elephanta Caves and witness the beautiful structures carved in stones. Enjoy the famous Mumbai Street Food and gain some insights into cooking the same.

Visit one more site having such beautiful Cave Craft at Aurangabad. Visit Aurangabad and see the Mini Taj Mahal along with other beautiful sites.
Everyone loves to taste Wine once in their lifetime. Visit the beautiful Wine Capital of India – Nasik and taste some of the best wines in the country along with revisiting the times of Ramayana and Mahabharata the two most famous epics of history.

During the tour of the Northern Golden Triangle visit famous places like the Symbol of Love and one of the Seven Wonders in the World – The Taj Mahal. While experiencing the epic structures of New Delhi, Agra and Jaipur, also experience some of the best unknown activities which are happening at these places for a long time.

Following are the activities and sites you would be enjoying during this tour:

1. Guided tour of the dynamic, cosmopolitan city Bombay- Tour the city covering important places like the Gateway of India, Temple, Mosque, and Garden.
2. Experience the most beautiful caves of India - the ancient Ajanta & Ellora Caves in Aurangabad – also UNESCO World Heritage Sites
3. Visit the "The Wine Capital of India" the Nashik region reportedly produces 10,000 tons of grapes per year. Go on Wine tasting tours in various Vineyards of Nashik. Also, experience the heritage of the city visiting Ghats and temples.
4. Visit the UNESCO World Heritage Sites in Delhi and experience the imperial and Mughal architecture.
5. Visit one of the 7 wonders of the world Taj Mahal and discover the magic of white marble at Agra.
6. Energize yourself at Morning Taj Facing Yoga Session at Agra.
7. Enjoy a guided tour of the Pink City.
8. Heena Painting on Hands and Feet in Jaipur.
9. Visit the Largest Slum of Asia – Dharavi. (Optional)
10. Stop at Open Air Laundry- The Dhobi Ghat in Mumbai.
11. Enjoy Kebab and Curry Walk (Street Food) of Mumbai. (Optional)
12. Go on a Mughal Heritage Kachhpura Village Walk tour in Agra- an eye-opening experience.
13. Enjoy a Cycle Rickshaw ride in the narrow lanes of Chandni Chowk Bazaar of Delhi.
14. Tour of Bagru Village to meet local people and experience the unique style of woodblock prints.

dayInfo.description: Arrive at Mumbai International Airport and get a warm welcome from our representative and get transferred to the hotel. Check into the hotel and enjoy rest of the day at leisure.

• After breakfast, go for a sightseeing tour of Mumbai with your guide. • Visit Gateway of India- one of the most popular tourist hotspots of Mumbai. • Drive past the Afghan Church, • Drive past Secretariat of Government of Maharashtra. • Drive past or take a halt at Marine Drive which is fondly known as the 'Queen's Necklace'. • Visit Jain Temple • Visit the Hanging Garden offering a splendid view of the city, • Visit the Beach or as the locals say Chowpatty. • Visit the Kamala Nehru Park • Enjoy lunch at the local restaurant • Visit Mani Bhawan Museum • Drive past the Haji Ali Mosque - one of the most prestigious Islamic symbols situated in South Mumbai. • Stop at Open Air Laundry- the Dhobi Ghat • The Chhatrapati Shivaji Terminus (CST) – formerly known as Victoria Terminus. OPTIONAL TOURS : • Visit Elephanta Caves – A UNESCO World Heritage Site • Kebab and Curry Walk (Street Food) of Mumbai.

After breakfast, check out from hotel and get transferred to Mumbai Airport and fly to Aurangabad. On arrival meet our representative and get transferred to hotel. Check into the hotel and rest for a while. • Later, proceed on a guided visit to Ajanta Caves – UNESCO World Heritage Ancient Buddhist Caves.

• After breakfast, go on a full day sightseeing tour of Aurangabad with your guide. • Visit to Ellora Caves, also known as Verul – One of the most popular UNESCO World Heritage Sites in India. • Visit Bibi ka Maqbara- Taj Mahal Of The Deccan • You may visit Himroo Factory – The 150-year-old weaving factory. • You may also visit Daulatabad Fort – Often hailed as one of the 'Seven Wonders of Maharashtra'.

After breakfast, check out from hotel and travel to Nashik (200km. 4 hour drive). On arrival meet our representative and check into the hotel and rest for a while. Later, visit the prominent places like Sita Gufa (Cave), River Godavari Ghat (Bank), and few nearby but worthy of visit temples.

• After breakfast, visit the Sula Vineyards and enjoy a wine tour and tasting of Six different wines. • Later, visit Soma Winery. • Late afternoon, proceed towards York Winery and enjoy a wine tour along with wine tasting.
After breakfast, check out from hotel and travel to Mumbai (200Km, 4 hour drive). On arrival, check into the hotel and enjoy rest of the day at leisure.

After breakfast, check out from hotel and get transferred to Mumbai Airport and fly to New Delhi. On arrival receive a warm welcome from our representative and get transferred to the hotel. Check into the hotel and enjoy rest of the day at leisure.

• After breakfast, proceed for sightseeing tour of the city with your guide. • Drive past or if you wish you may visit Red Fort • Drive Past or if you wish you may take a stop at Raj Ghat – the cremation site of Mahatma Gandhi. • Visit Agrasen ki Baoli (ancient water reservoir) • Visit Jama Masjid • Visit Chandni Chowk – ‘the Moonlight Square and enjoy a Cycle Rickshaw Ride which takes you through the narrow streets of the Chandni Chowk. • Visit Lakshmi Narayan Temple • Drive Past India Gate – The All India War Memorial • Also pass by the Rashtrapati Bhavan (formerly the viceroy's residence) and the Parliament House. • Enjoy a special lunch at local restaurant. • Visit Humayun's Tomb • Visit Qutub Minar - A UNESCO World Heritage Site.

After hearty breakfast, travel to Agra (222Km, 5 hour drive). On arrival meet our representative and check into the hotel. Enjoy rest of the day at leisure. In the evening enjoy a Special Dinner at Taj Facing Rooftop Restaurant.

• Early morning visit Taj Mahal during Sunrise (As fuel based vehicles are not permitted in the vicinity of Taj Mahal, you will head to Taj Mahal gate by a Battery operated Bus. (Friday Closed). • After breakfast, visit Agra Fort - An Epitome of the Mughal Dynasty • Visit Itmad-Ud-Daulah’s Tomb • Late afternoon go for Mughal Heritage Kachhpura Village walk with high tea OPTIONAL TOURS : • Mohabbat the Taj Show- You can watch the famous Mohabbat the Taj show, presented by the Sanskritik Natyashala. It is a series of play depicting the saga of love.

Early morning, enjoy Taj Mahal facing Yoga session. After breakfast, check out from hotel and travel to Jaipur (240Km, 5 hour drive). En-route visit Fatehpur Sikri - A city predominantly made of red sandstone and a UNESCO World Heritage Site. On arrival meet our representative and check into the hotel and enjoy rest of the day at leisure.

• After breakfast, proceed for full day Jaipur sightseeing tour with your Guide. • Visit Amber Fort – One of the most magnificent palaces in India. (The Fort is perched on a hill, so to reach there; you may enjoy a Jeep ride in Amber fort. • Visit Jantar Mantar – largest stone astronomical observatory in the world. • Visit to City Palace and Museum– Built by Maharaja Sawai Jai Singh during the years 1729 to 1732. • Photo Stop Hawa Mahal – built by Maharaja Sawai Pratap Singh in the year 1799. • In the evening enjoy Heena Painting on hands and Feet.
After breakfast, check out from hotel and travel to New Delhi International Airport (280Km. 5 hour drive) to board the flight for your home town.

tourName: Wheelchair accessible Golden Triangle tour, India
generalInfo:
This journey to Accessible Indian Golden Triangle includes visit to main tourist cities Delhi - Agra & Jaipur. Visit includes to Wheelchair friendly UNESCO World Heritage sites / monuments, visit to local markets to witness local life, visit majestic forts and palaces, spend time with mighty elephant, different religious places to show different religions coexisting in harmony…

Highlights :
- Wheelchair Accessible monuments (partially or fully accessible)
- Explore UNESCO World heritage sites (partially or fully accessible)
- Accessible hotels with accessible / adapted rooms
- Accessible restaurants
- Experience the Taj Mahal at sunset or sunrise, widely considered to be one of the greatest architectural masterpieces in the world and is listed as one of the New Seven Wonders of World.
- Learn about Elephants in Elephant Conservation and Care centre
- Local markets
- Different religious places
- Local family for a meal
- Accompanying guide for whole tour

Important to note :
1. Hotels have only 1 or 2 rooms maximum which are wheelchair accessible rooms.
2. You have option of increasing the duration of this tour by adding nights at each destination.
3. If you love wildlife, we would suggest you to consider adding 2 nights at Ranthambore National Park which is famous for wildlife and Tigers. After knowing the mobility limitations, we will be able to decide if Ranthambore can be suggested or not.
4. Each person may have different disability, we request you to kindly share the details with us so that we can mutually discuss and work out ideal program for you.
5. We do not have Commercial vehicles with Hydraulic lift for wheelchair, so manual help is required to assist guest on wheelchair from transferring him from his wheelchair to the seat in our vehicle.
6. We expect guest to travel with foldable and manual wheelchair. Wheelchair will be folded and carried along with baggage in car boot.
7. If required, we will provide you a folding shower bench you can increase or decrease the hight.
8. In one vehicle we suggest 2 guests + guide along with the driver. However, if you have bigger family or travelling with friends and would need bigger vehicle, we would provide you vehicle with wheelchair ramp which would need pushing wheelchair inside the vehicle and transfer from wheelchair to our seat.
9. October to March are pleasant but December end to mid January could be cold, April to June are summer months and temperature could reach around 45 deg during day time, July to September are monsoon months but it does not main continuously.
10. If you have any specific questions, we would be happy to answer those.


Note : These prices are not valid during peak period i.e during festival time like Diwali and Holi festivals and between 20 December to 10 January. Some of the hotels charge higher prices during these dates.
If your travel is happening during this period, we will advise you prices based on your travel dates.

dayInfo.description: Arrive Delhi. Arrive Delhi and meet your local representative at airport. Transfer to hotel (check-in time 14h00). Overnight at hotel.

In Delhi. Morning start your day with orientation tour of New Delhi, the founda-tion stone of the city was laid by Emperor George V during the Delhi Durbar of 1911. It was designed by British architects, Sir Edwin Lutyens and Sir Herbert Baker. Your will drive pass President House, Indian Parliament, India Gate and Connaught Place. Continue to visit Wheelchair accessible Qutab Minar. It is a soaring, 73m high tower of victory, built in 1193 by Qutab-ud-din Aibak. The tower has five distinct storeys, each marked by a projecting balcony and tapers from a 15 m diameter at the base to just 2.5 m at the top. The first three storeys are made of red sandstone; the fourth and fifth storeys are of marble and sandstone. At the foot of the tower is the Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque, the first mosque to be built in India. Later proceed to Wheelchair accessible Gurudwara Bangla Sahib, one of the most prominent Sikh gurdwara or Sikh house of worship. Once inside the main building, you will be amazed with great interior, there is space to be seated on the floor and listen to “kirtan – the words’ being sung by the staff. Like in all Sikh Gurdwaras, the concept of langar is practiced here too, and all people, regardless of race or religion may eat in the Gurdwara kitchen (langar hall). The Langar (food) is prepared by volunteers who wish to help out and by gursikhs who work there. It is believed that everyday around 25000 people eat in this hall.

Delhi / Agra (4h drive). After check-out, drive to Agra, once a Mughal capital. Enroute stop to visit Elephant Conservation and Care center. In Agra proceed to wheelchair accessible Agra Fort, also called Red Fort, large 16th-century Fort of red sandstone located on the Yamuna river. It was established by the Mughal dynasty emperor Akbar and, in its ca-pacity as both a military base and a royal residence, served as the seat of government when the Mughal capital was in Agra. The fort complex was designated a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1983. Return back to hotel.

Agra / Jaipur (6h drive). Morning visit Wheelchair accessible The Taj Mahal (closed on Friday), an enormous mausoleum complex commissioned in 1632 by the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan to house the remains of his beloved wife. Constructed over a 20-year period on the southern bank of the Yamuna River in Agra, In-dia, the famed complex is one of the most outstanding examples of Mughal architecture, which combined Indian, Persian and Islamic influ-ences. At its center is the Taj Mahal itself, built of shimmering white marble that seems to change color depending on the daylight. Desig-nated a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1983, it remains one of the world’s most celebrated structures and a stunning symbol of India’s rich history. After check-out, drive to Jaipur with enroute stop at Wheelchair acces-sible UNESCO World Heritage site of Fatehpur Sikri to visit this ghost town. Built during the second half of the 16th century by the Emperor Akbar, Fatehpur Sikri (the City of Victory) was the capital of the Mughal Empire for only some 10 years. It has complex of monuments and temples, all in a uniform architectural style. Continue to Jaipur, an enthralling prolific “pink’ city and capital of Raja-sthan state. The city was painted in pink to welcome the Prince of Wales and Queen Victoria in 1876 since the colour is the mark of Hospi-tality. As a result, Jaipur started to be known as the Pink City.

In Jaipur. Morning drive to 16th century built yellow coloured Panna Meena ka Kund (stepwell, accessible for wheel chair) surrounded by beautiful temples. It was probably built so that the people of Amer could collect water, which was later used at many temples nearby. Women also came here to fill their water pots for household work. Continue to Amber Fort (partially accessible) constructed in the 16th century by Maan Singh, the trusted general of Emperor Akbar. The fort is known for its architectural splendour manifested in Sukh Mandir, the Hall of Public Audience, Sheesh Mahal and Kesar Kyari Later proceed to beautiful City Palace (Wheelchair accessible) came in-to existence with the establishment of the city of Jaipur. Built by Maha-raja Sawai Jai Singh II, the palace was the administrative and ceremoni-al seat of Jaipur Maharaja. Beautiful courtyards, gardens and buildings in the palace complex are worth exploring. Continue to visit 18th century astronomical observation site, the Jantar Mantar (wheelchair accessible). This UNESCO World Heritage site has collection of some 20 fixed astronomical instruments built by the Ma-haraja Sawai Jai Singh II. Designed for the observation of astronomical positions with the naked eye, they embody several architectural and in-strumental innovations.

Jaipur / Delhi (6h drive). Morning drive back to New Delhi. On arrival in Delhi, proceed for visit of Dilli Haat. Dilli Haat showcase traditional Indian culture - a forum where rural life and folk art are brought closer to an urban clientele. It is here that the crafts persons find an opportunity to demonstrate their artistic skills to thousands of visitors every day. Later transfer to hotel for dinner and wash and change (room for Day Use only till 21h00 only). In time, transfer to airport to connect flight to next destination
Connect flight to next destination.

tourName: Wheelchair accessible heritage tour of India
generalInfo:
This specially crafted itinerary takes you to Wheelchair friendly UNESCO World Heritage sites / monuments (fully or partly accessible for wheelchair users) in main Indian tourist cities, visit to colourful local markets to witness local life, visit majestic forts and palaces (partly accessible), spend time with in company of mighty elephant to learn more about them, relish delicious Indian food, visit different religious places to show different religions coexisting in harmony…

Highlights :
- English speaking accompanying Indian guide for whole tour
- Wheelchair Accessible monuments (partially or fully accessible)
- Explore UNESCO World heritage sites (partially or fully accessible)
- Accessible hotels with accessible / adapted rooms
- Accessible restaurants
- Experience the Taj Mahal at sunset or sunrise, widely considered to be one of the greatest architectural masterpieces in the world and is listed as one of the New Seven Wonders of World.
- Learn about Elephants in Elephant Conservation and Care centre
- Local markets
- Different religious places
- Visit local family for a meal
- Vegetarian Thali lunch

Important to note :
1. Hotels have only 1 or 2 rooms maximum which are wheelchair accessible rooms.
2. You have option of increasing the duration of this tour by adding nights at each destination.
3. If you love wildlife, we would suggest you to consider adding 2 nights at Ranthambore National Park which is famous for wildlife and Tigers. After knowing the mobility limitations, we will be able to decide if Ranthambore can be suggested or not.
4. Each person may have different disability, we request you to kindly share the details with us so that we can mutually discuss and work out ideal program for you.
5. We do not have Commercial vehicles with Hydraulic lift for wheelchair, so manual help is required to assist guest on wheelchair from transferring him from his wheelchair to the seat in our vehicle.
6. We expect guest to travel with foldable and manual wheelchair. Wheelchair will be folded and carried along with baggage in car boot.
7. If required, we will provide you a folding shower bench you can increase or decrease the hight.
8. In one vehicle we suggest 2 guests + guide along with the driver. However, if you have bigger family or travelling with friends and would need bigger vehicle, we would provide you vehicle with wheelchair ramp which would need pushing wheelchair inside the vehicle and transfer from wheelchair to our seat.
9. October to March are pleasant but December end to mid January could be cold, April to June are summer months and temperature could reach around 45 deg during day time, July to September are monsoon months but it does not main continuously.
10. If you have any specific questions, we would be happy to answer those.
11. Our cost includes 1 domestic flight within India. Free baggage allowance in domestic flights is 15 kg for check-in baggage and 7 kg for hand baggage. Incase your baggage will be more than this limit, you will have to pay for extra baggage at the airport. For each traveller, only 1 check-in baggage is allowed. You also have option of increasing the baggage limit at the time of issuing the tickets.


Note : These prices are not valid during peak period i.e during festival time like Diwali and Holi festivals and between 20 December to 10 January. Some of the hotels charge higher prices during these dates.
If your travel is happening during this period, we will advise you prices based on your travel dates.

dayInfo.description: Arrive Delhi. Arrive Delhi and meet your local representative at airport. Transfer to hotel (check-in time 14h00). Overnight at hotel.

In Delhi. Incase of late night arrival on Day 1, this morning will be free to relax at hotel. Later start your tour of India with orientation tour of New Delhi, the foundation stone of the city was laid by Emperor George V during the Delhi Durbar of 1911. It was designed by British architects, Sir Edwin Lutyens and Sir Herbert Baker. Your will drive pass President House, Indian Parliament, India Gate and Connaught Place. Continue to visit Wheelchair accessible Qutab Minar. It is a soaring, 73m high tower of victory, built in 1193 by Qutab-ud-din Aibak. The tower has five distinct storeys, each marked by a projecting balcony and tapers from a 15 m diameter at the base to just 2.5 m at the top. The first three storeys are made of red sandstone; the fourth and fifth storeys are of marble and sandstone. At the foot of the tower is the Quwwat-ul-Islam Mosque, the first mosque to be built in India

In Delhi Morning proceed to Wheelchair accessible Gurudwara Bangla Sahib, one of the most prominent Sikh gurdwara or Sikh house of worship. Once inside the main building, you will be amazed with great interior, there is space to be seated on the floor and listen to “kirtan – the words’ being sung by the staff. Like in all Sikh Gurdwaras, the concept of langar is practiced here too, and all people, regardless of race or religion may eat in the Gurdwara kitchen (langar hall). The Langar (food) is prepared by volunteers who wish to help out and by gursikhs who work there. It is believed that everyday around 25000 people eat in this hall. Continue to cremation site of Mahatma Gandhi, the Raj Ghat. Black marble square platform is inscribed with his last words Hai Ram (Oh God) is accessible on Wheelchair. Later in the evening, proceed to lush green Lodi Garden spread over 90 acres. Garden is beautifully dotted with well-preserved ruins of 15th century belonging to Lodhi and Mughal dynasties.

Delhi / Agra (4h drive). After check-out, drive to Agra, once a Mughal capital. Enroute stop to visit Elephant Conservation and Care center. In Agra proceed to wheelchair accessible Agra Fort, also called Red Fort, large 16th-century Fort of red sandstone located on the Yamuna river. It was established by the Mughal dynasty emperor Akbar and, in its ca-pacity as both a military base and a royal residence, served as the seat of government when the Mughal capital was in Agra. The fort complex was designated a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1983. Return back to hotel.

Agra / Jaipur (6h drive). Morning visit Wheelchair accessible The Taj Mahal (closed on Friday), an enormous mausoleum complex commissioned in 1632 by the Mughal emperor Shah Jahan to house the remains of his beloved wife. Constructed over a 20-year period on the southern bank of the Yamuna River in Agra, In-dia, the famed complex is one of the most outstanding examples of Mughal architecture, which combined Indian, Persian and Islamic influ-ences. At its center is the Taj Mahal itself, built of shimmering white marble that seems to change color depending on the daylight. Desig-nated a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1983, it remains one of the world’s most celebrated structures and a stunning symbol of India’s rich history. After check-out, drive to Jaipur with enroute stop at Wheelchair acces-sible UNESCO World Heritage site of Fatehpur Sikri to visit this ghost town. Built during the second half of the 16th century by the Emperor Akbar, Fatehpur Sikri (the City of Victory) was the capital of the Mughal Empire for only some 10 years. It has complex of monuments and temples, all in a uniform architectural style. Continue to Jaipur, an enthralling prolific “pink’ city and capital of Raja-sthan state. The city was painted in pink to welcome the Prince of Wales and Queen Victoria in 1876 since the colour is the mark of Hospi-tality. As a result, Jaipur started to be known as the Pink City.

In Jaipur. Morning drive to 16th century built yellow coloured Panna Meena ka Kund (stepwell, accessible for wheel chair) surrounded by beautiful temples. It was probably built so that the people of Amer could collect water, which was later used at many temples nearby. Women also came here to fill their water pots for household work. Continue to Amber Fort (partially accessible) constructed in the 16th century by Maan Singh, the trusted general of Emperor Akbar. The fort is known for its architectural splendour manifested in Sukh Mandir, the Hall of Public Audience, Sheesh Mahal and Kesar Kyari Afternoon free. In the evening, if interested, we will take you to a Hindu temple Govind Dev ji (wheelchair accessible) to witness high vibrating living spiritual atmosphere. ‘Aartis' and 'Bhog' are offered seven times a day, when the deity is unveiled for 'Darshan'. Thousands of devotees visit the temple daily..

In Jaipur Morning proceed to beautiful City Palace (Wheelchair accessible) came in-to existence with the establishment of the city of Jaipur. Built by Maha-raja Sawai Jai Singh II, the palace was the administrative and ceremoni-al seat of Jaipur Maharaja. Beautiful courtyards, gardens and buildings in the palace complex are worth exploring. Continue to visit 18th century astronomical observation site, the Jantar Mantar (wheelchair accessible). This UNESCO World Heritage site has collection of some 20 fixed astronomical instruments built by the Ma-haraja Sawai Jai Singh II. Designed for the observation of astronomical positions with the naked eye, they embody several architectural and in-strumental innovations. Afternoon free.

Jaipur / Pushkar / Jodhpur (7h drive) Morning drive to Jodhpur, founded in the year 1459 by Rao Jodha and the city earned its name after him. City is also known as Blue City, because Brahmins, used to paint their houses blue to deter insects and keep the houses cool during the summer. On the way, stop at Pushkar, a sacred Hindu site with hundreds of temples, including 14th-century temple dedicated to Lord Brahma who is considered as a “creator of Universe”. Its holy lake has 52 ghats (stone staircases) where pilgrims bathe to wash their sins and perform religious ceremonies. Annual Pushkar fair is one of India's largest camel, horse and cattle fairs. Apart from the trading of livestock, it is an important pilgrimage season for Hindus to the Pushkar lake.

In Jodhpur Spend morning in exploring Jodhpur city by first visiting Maharangarh Fort (partially accessible) which stands atop a rocky cliff 400 feet above the city. Entry to the fort through its huge, fortified gateways takes you to the museums and palaces. We will visit the areas which are accessible by wheelchair. After visit of fort, visit Jaswant Thada (visit from a distance) also known as “Taj Mahal of Marwar”. It is a beautiful memorial in marble was built in memory of Maharaja Jaswant Singh ji II of Jodhpur. Later explore the local market around historical clocktower. This market is crowded with locals, dressed in their colorful attire, who come to buy their daily needs. You will find anything and everything like bangles, imitation jewellery, vegetables, fruits, fabric, spices etc.

Jodhpur / Ranakpur / Udaipur (6h drive) After leisurely breakfast, drive through the Aravalli Hills to Udaipur. This drive will take you through small villages along the road and you will be able to see villagers working on their fields in colorful dresses. Enroute stop in Ranakpur for visit (visit from outside). Ranakpur is one of the important and sacred sites for Jain religion followers. Here you will visit 15th century temple carved out of marble, it has more than 1400 marble pillars and intricately carved interior domes

In Udaipur Morning visit City Palace Complex (partially accessible) by first visiting City Palace, known for its architecture, mosaic, mirror and miniature painting work. Inside the Palace you will also see a massive collection of paintings. Continue to car museum to see vintage car collection of Mewar Royal family. You will find different splendid vehicles, including the beautiful 1934 Rolls-Royce Phantom used in the Bond film Octopussy, and the Cadillac convertible used for Queen Elizabeth II to the airport in 1961. Enjoy vegetarian Thali lunch at restaurant next to Vintage car museum.

Udaipur / Delhi (flight) Morning free to relax. In time, transfer to airport to connect flight to Delhi. On arrival in Delhi, proceed for visit of Dilli Haat (subject to flight schedule). Dilli Haat showcase traditional Indian culture - a forum where rural life and folk art are brought closer to an urban clientele. It is here that the crafts persons find an opportunity to demonstrate their artistic skills to thousands of visitors every day. Later transfer to hotel for dinner and wash and change (room for Day Use only till 21h00 only). In time, transfer to airport to connect flight to next destination
Delhi / Fly to next destination

tourName: Wildlife and cultural holiday in India
generalInfo:
Discover India: Cultural Adventures and Ethical Wildlife Experiences

Welcome to India! If you’re passionate about authentic cultural experiences and ethical wildlife tours, this journey is designed for you. Explore the highlights of North-West India, from famous monuments and street food to immersive walking tours through vibrant cities.

What makes this tour special? You shall experience wildlife in both natural habitats and conservation projects that protect elephants, sloth bears, tigers, camels, reptiles, and antelopes.

Travel between September and March for the best weather and an unforgettable experience.

This tour is perfect if you enjoy:

1. Visiting wildlife conservation communities and understanding their work with rescued animals.
2. Learning how former poaching communities are now wildlife protectors.
3. Experiencing village life with traditional home-cooked meals and staying in comfortable homestays that directly support local families.
4. Combining heritage tours like textile, monument, and artisan experiences for a deeper cultural connection.

This is slow, flexible, and meaningful travel—crafted just for you.

With years of experience in creating story-rich, responsible travel in India, we bring deep local knowledge, transparency in pricing, and a passion for helping you explore India in a personal, thoughtful, and memorable way.

dayInfo.description: Arrive in Delhi. Spend rest of the day at leisure staying with a family where you begin to experience the amazing hospitality on the tour yet have your privacy. This day is available to settle down, recover from jetlag, or explore the neighborhood and warm up to the city. We begin the second day with a walking tour of Chandni Chowk (Old Delhi). This tour comprises of tasting 5-6 types of local delicacies along with storytelling on the bazaars, traditions, and customs. Thereafter, we do a tour of New Delhi which includes the British colonial heritage and artisan markets. Ps. The second half of the day is open for customisation if you have something on your list.

We spend the next two days with sloth bear, leopard, and elephant conservation communities. This includes understanding the daily life of the animal and their rescue and rehabilitation work. See how the animals can co-exist with the humans conserving the region's natural heritage, biodiversity, and forests. Learn how the communities are balancing human rights and lowering the human-animal conflict in the region. Visit the Taj Mahal and go for a guided tour of Agra city where you visit the artisan families that are into textiles and marble masonry.

Travel further to the land of the tiger where you spend two days at a wildlife lodge relaxing and going on a jeep safari. Learn how the tiger conservation efforts have borne fruit and have provided alternative source of income for the tribal community that once depended on poaching. The communities that once had severe human-animal conflict in the region are now building their livelihood from artisanal fair-trade.

Our next destination is Bundi where we spend a day exploring the city palace and numerous beautiful step wells. Our storytellers will reveal the hidden places and alleyways in the palace with medieval murals and the school of art. The evening will be available at leisure to explore this charming town on your own.

We drive further inland to spend the next three days with the nomads whose livelihood depends on camels. The animal is not only a source of their income but also a part of their family, and the way it works will leave you in awe. Along with the camel conservation story, we also involve you in daily village activities as per the day's schedule. This could include visiting local temples or homes or getting involved in a village ceremony. It is best to go with the flow with our storytellers as we take you from one pleasant surprise to the next.

The last few days of this tour is with the community of blackbuck conservationists. Your stay will be with the community in the charming villages with rustic homestays. During these few days, you not only learn the story of how the community works for protecting the antelope and blackbuck but also see how they earn their livelihood from weaving, pottery, and more.

On the last morning, we suggest a tour of the Jodhpur blue city where we take you through the maze of houses and charming shops that add to the beauty. Taste numerous local delicacies and spend time with a family conversing over homemade breakfast. Get the afternoon flight or train back to Delhi or Jaipur for onward journey.

tourName: Wildlife holiday in Central India
placesVisited: New Delhi, Bandhavgarh Tiger Reserve, Kanha Tiger Reserve, Pench Tiger Reserve, Satpura Tiger Reserve, Bhimbetka cave paintings, search for: giant squirrels, tigers, leopards, wild dogs, water birds and wetland wildlife
generalInfo:
India wildlife tours are an amazing treat for nature lovers and for anyone else with a passing interest in adventure as they conjure up an incredible variety of experiences, least of all the chance to spot tigers, leopards, sloth bears, bison and crocodiles within a range of stunning environments.

As this particular 12 day India wildlife tour is exclusive you'll be able to take advantage of an array of luxury safari camp accommodation, with the tiger reserves of Kanha, Bandhavgarh and Pench all providing some exquisite scenes to accompany a range of comfortable facilities.

Aside from the wildlife tours, India is blessed with a bounty of ancient sites of interest with the UNESCO listed Bhimbtka caves providing a fascinating finale to this fabulous India wildlife tour.

Below are just a few of the highlights that you can expect to find whilst undertaking this private India wildlife tour:

- Big cat safari tours in India's most prestigious tiger reserves with excellent chances of seeing sloth bears, leopards and other wildlife alongside the slinking figure of Shere Khan himself.
- Explore Central India's best regarded jungle regions which are known to be the inspiration behind Rudyard Kipling's Jungle Book.
- Take a guided tour of Satpura Tiger Reserve either on foot or by boat.
- Experience an array of chances to go bird watching and embark on nature photography trips.
- Find out more about the 30,000 year old cave paintings within the caves of Bhimbetka.
- Enjoy comfortable and well-equipped luxury safari camp accommodation.

dayInfo.description: New Delhi – Bandhavgarh Tiger Reserve: Arrive New Delhi and catch morning flight to Jabalpur. At Jabalpur airport you will be met by your driver and driven to Bandhavgarh. Five hour drive (200 km) through rural India will take you to the forest of Bandhavgarh. Check-in to your lodge which is nestled comfortably in the lap of nature just on the edge of Bandhavgarh. Drain the day’s exhaustion with hot and cold beverages. Retire early after dinner, gearing up for tomorrow’s adventure.

Bandhavgarh Tiger Reserve: World renowned Bandhavgarh is known for its high tiger density and thus offers the best chance to see tigers in the wild. Set out in search of world’s most elusive cat on 4x4 in morning and evening game safari.

Pench Tiger Reserve: Travel west from Kanha to Pench (200 km/5 hours). On arrival, check into your camp and relax amidst its natural setting. Designed in keeping with the local culture, the camp showcases a pastoral jungle theme. Named after the Pench river, the reserve is located in the southern reaches of the Satpura hill range. It also has some of the highest deer/antelope density in India attracting good numbers of carnivore such as tiger, leopard and wild dogs along with occasionally seen Indian wolf. Pench is the original setting which inspired Rudyard Kipling for his master piece ‘The Jungle Book’. BBC also brought Pench in international spot light after shooting award winning documentary ‘Spy in the Jungle’. Explore Pench in morning and evening game safari in search of wildlife.

New Delhi: Today after final morning jungle activity, bid farewell to Satpura and drive to Bhopal (150 km/3 hours). Pause 45 kms south of Bhopal to see the extraordinary cave paintings at Bhimbetka. The paintings at this UNESCO site are believed to be up to 30,000 years old. After Bhimbetka continue to Bhopal airport to catch flight to New Delhi/Mumbai for your onward journey.

tourName: Wildlife holiday in North East India
generalInfo:
Eastern India is one of the most biodiverse areas of the world; an area rich in forests, river systems and grasslands all bursting with wildlife. Some iconic and crictically endangered such as tigers, Asiatic elephants, Indian one-horned rhinos and others smaller and regionally endemic such as sunbirds, frogs and primates like Gee's golden langur and western Hoolock gibbon.

This tour explores some of the most famous and best wildlife watching locations in north-east India. These include the vast mangrove wetland ecosystms of the Sunderbans, the lush grasslands of Kaziranga and Manas as well as the seldom visited forests of Hoolongopar Gibbon Sanctuary.

For anyone interested in exploring some of India’s wildest and most remote national this is the tour for you.

Introduction:

We are specialists in tailoring wildlife watching tours and safari holidays all over the world, specialising in the Indian subcontinent and of course the wonderful and diverse country of India. Whilst most wildlife watchers who visit India spend time in the famous tiger reserves of the central plains or maybe the sub-Himalayan parks of the north west and Western Ghats in the south. But these ecosystems and incredible wildlife are just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the wildlife that India has to offer.

This tour explores some of the lesser known parks and takes you into the deepest parts of India’s north eastern rainforests, mangroves and grasslands . All of this whilst escorted by our very own expert zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) coupled with local guides. Of course there is one species in particular that dominates everyone’s thoughts and dreams when they think of an Indian safari and that is the beautiful tiger.

Whilst there are chances of seeing tigers here we take time to showcase the tiger’s ecosystem in full and try and find as many other animals that share the forests with tigers. We also offer a few different ways of exploring the parks, so however you like to travel through the tiger’s habitat we have the tour for you, whether you want to drive around in your own jeep, walk through the forests and grasslands tracking the elusive big cat or even via a boat or canoe in the water ways of the Sundarbans.

One of the reasons why our safaris of India are unique is that our background (as a company) is from a scientific and zoological standpoint and so have a great network of colleagues and contacts all over the world who are the people on the front line in search of the best new locations for wildlife watching in the wild. All of these reasons and many more make us experts in arranging and guiding safaris and are able to tailor a Indian safaris to any location to try to find them that you request. All you have to do is to get in touch with us and tell us your budget and your group size and where you would like to go on safari.

Price Includes:

Everything mentioned in the itinerary is included. Including three meals per day (breakfast, lunch and dinner - where mentioned in the itinerary). There will be bottled water (approx 1ltr) available for each guest each day. We have our own private air conditioned vehicles with an excellent local driver for all transfers. We include internal flights where ever possible on all our Indian safaris. We use two brilliant full time guides; first a professional zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) will escort you on all your excursions and also a very knowledgeable English speaking local guide at each national park. Your zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) escort is an expert in mammal biology, ecology and behaviour and will be able to help you identify the different species as well as interpret you what behaviours you are seeing. Your zoologist (- zoologists are not always available, if you wish to have a zoologist escort your trip, please inquire with us) escort has spent time studying and working with different species all over the world and he has years of experience guiding throughout most of India’s national parks. We also use local expert guides with decades of experience on all our Indian safaris. We also include all jeep safaris, guided walks, canoe safaris, boat-trips, park entrance fees and sightseeing entrance fees. We include more individual safaris into national parks per tour than any other tour operator around; only if you request to have a rest day will we not arrange a safari into the national parks to search for tigers and other wildlife. A comprehensive species list (which states the relative chances of seeing animals based on past tours) is included in the pre-departure pack. There is also a reference book library available for your use throughout the trip as well as some documentaries on tigers and other Indian wildlife which are available to watch throughout the tour.

Seasons:

March and April is the dry season and best for wildlife. For wildlife watching in southern India we recommend visiting during March and April (this is the best overall game viewing in the Indian Subcontinent’s main tiger reserves and national parks). This is towards the end of the hot dry season and offers the best chances of seeing wildlife as the hotter and drier it gets the more the wildlife aggregate around waterholes as well as there being less vegetation blocking the view.

Why Choose this Tour:

• All of our Indian safaris are guided by a local naturalist guides, drivers and also scientists or researchers where possible, this not only gives you numerous sets of trained eyes to find the animals but also gives you the chance to understand the behaviours and habits of the wildlife your watching.
• Our zoologist (where available - if you wish to have a zoologist please contact us and we can check availability - not all tours include a zoologist) that escorts tours (where available) has a great wealth of knowledge.
• We use camera traps (where available) which will increase the chances of getting close up pictures and movies of tigers and other rare nocturnal wildlife.
• During this tour we explore various national parks and wildlife sanctuaries (Sundarbans, Kaziranga, Manas and Hoolongapor Gibbon Sanctuary) which will give you a very good overview of the wild Eastern forests of India.
• Travel into wonderful and world's largest mangrove forest of the Sundarbans in search of tigers, river dolphins and enormous slat-water crocodiles.
• By joining one of our Indian safaris you will have an overall wildlife experience as we are determined to showcase all of the wildlife of the parks we visit (not just tigers), you will not feel like a passenger in a rally and bounce all over the place in pursuit of tigers; we make sure all our Indian safaris are relaxed and environmentally friendly experiences. In fact the majority of tiger sightings that we enjoy in India are of tigers that our jeep and guides have found (as opposed to other operators who wait for a tiger to be seen and then stake out the waterhole surrounded by dozens of other jeeps), we always investigate any suspicious behaviour exhibited by their prey and usually find tigers by watching the deer and monkey behaviour as they change from relaxed to agitated when a predator is spotted.
• We have explored all the areas we visit in depth and have found the best and most conveniently located accommodations to stay in whilst searching out wildlife in isolated and remote places. Including some of the best and most ecologically friendly lodges in all of India.
• We are a member of Tour Operators for Tigers (TOFT) and we make sure that all of our tiger safaris run by their code of practice and we also make sure that all the accommodation we use is audited by TOFT to make sure of sustainable practices.
• All the above reasons give this our tiger tours and general wildlife holidays of India a great success rate of seeing tigers (100% in Bandhavgarh and close to 50% for this tour, which is very good considering the dense forests and vastness of the protected areas).
• We have an unrivalled network of experts and guides throughout the India and are able to find and observe species that are difficult to find or overlooked sometimes such as Indian leopards, Asiatic elephants, water buffalo, sloth bears, jungle cats, dhole, gaur and hundreds other endangered, rare or endemic species throughout the tigers current distribution.
• Due to our greta network of guides and researchers throughout India we are able to organise tailor made safari to anywhere in India, whether it is Bandhavgarh, Kanha, Periyar, Kaziranga, Corbett, Ramthambore, Satpura, Tadoba, and many other wildlife watching locations you want to visit we can arrange it. Please inform us if you wish to receive more information about any of these locations and booking a safari holiday to India.
• Unlike many tour operators we are willing to run this tour for a single person (on request).

Locations:

This tour takes you to the eastern states of Bengal and Assam all from the city of Kolkata where you will enter and leave India. The parks visited include the Sundarbans, Kaziranga, Assam and Hoolongapor Gibbon Sanctuary.

Fitness Level:

The fitness level required for this safari holiday is not very high. The vast majority of the activities are conducted from vehicles so no fitness is required, but there is some walking involved. The walking is all done at a leisurely pace with regular breaks, anyone who is used to mild hiking will find this easy.

Equipment:

When you book onto the tour we will send you a comprehensive pre-departure pack which will include a full packing list of recommended equipment; the equipment list will vary from tour to tour and from location to location so it is best to contact us or wait until you receive the pre-departure pack after booking.

Minimum Age: 18 Years Old

dayInfo.description: Kolkata - Arrival & Birding On your arrivak into Kolkata you will be met by your local guide and driven to your hotel. Then after checking in and depending on your arrival time you will be taken to Chintamani Kar Bird Sanctuary. Here attractions include birds like Orange-breasted Green Pigeon, Emerald Dove, Streak-throated Woodpecker, Orange-headed Thrush, Lineated Barbet, Tickell’s Thrush, Greater Racket-tailed Drongo, Slaty-legged Crake, Little Spiderhunter and Blue-throated Flycatcher. The recently rediscovered Large-billed Reed Warbler was found at the edges of the Sanctuary. In addition, the sanctuary also hosts some small wildlife; namely Jungle cat, Indian Civet, Asiatic Jackal and a few other mammal species. (no meals included today)

Sunderbans - Travelling Early this morning, you will be transferred from Kolkata to Sunderbans and reaching the jetty in time for your afternoon cruise into the Sunderbans. Whilst we travel to the camp, located on an island in the mangroves we will be birding and watching for crocodiles and mammals throughout. On reaching the eco resort we will check in and relax for the rest of the day. (breakfast and dinner included)

Kolkata - Travelling Early this morning you will start your transfer back to Kolkata with the boat transfer back to the jetty from the resort. You will have breakfast onboard the boat. Once you arrive back at the jetty you will be transferred back to Kolkata and your hotel. The afternoon is free at your leisure. (breakfast is the only meal included).

Jorhat - Travelling Early this morning, you will be taken to a new birding location nearby Kolkata, here some range restricted species. From there you will be driven to the airport to connect to your flight to Assam (~2 hours). Upon arrival at Jorhat, you will be met by the driver and local guide and be taken to the tea estate for the next couple of nights. After checking in you will have the afternoon to enjoy the sylvan surrounds and a possible short walk in the estate. The estate has its share of wilderness; leopard, Asiatic elephant and jungle cat have been sighted here. Afterwards you will have your evening meal at the bungalow. (breakfast and dinner included only)

Hoolongapor Gibbon Sanctuary - Wildlife Watching After breakfast this morning you will be driven to the only dedicated primate sanctuary in the Indian Subcontinent for a walk with a local guide looking for the endangered Western Hoolock Gibbon, Malayan Giant Squirrel, Capped Langur, Stump Tailed Macaque, Pig Tailed Macaque and other animals and birds. The place is full of thick forests with creepers and undergrowth and here one might see the Red Headed Trogon, Snowy Browed Flycatcher, Ferruginous Flycatcher, Lesser Shortwing, Grey Bellied Tesia, Slaty Headed Tesia and many other species of birds. After the morning gibbon watching and birding you will be stopping at a place inside the sanctuary for the packed lunch. After lunch you will continue searching forest for wildlife, including one of the only ape known from the Subcontinent. We have a choice of accommodation whilst exploring the Hoolongapor Gibbon Sanctuary, firstly for anyone interested in seeing the rare and elusive Bengal slow loris there is a single government run guest house (Forest Rest House) in fairly livable condition inside the forest – those interested to see the Slow Loris will need to spend the night inside the sanctuary. Where after dinner a short walk for about an hour might reveal a Loris. However the decision regarding the stay has to be done prior to coming at Gibbon and the permission for the night walk has to be secured from the authorities – so we would need to know at the time of booking. The best time for the Loris is February – though it is sighted in other months too. For anyone not wanting to stay here we will leave the sanctuary towards sundown and drive back to other accommodation. (all meals included today)

Hoolongapor Gibbon Sanctuary / Kaziranga National Park - Wildlife Watching Early in the morning (by taking a picnic breakfast with us) we will leave and visit the sanctuary again to explore it on foot, once again our main targets are the Stump Tailed and Pig Tailed Macaques and the Western Hoolock Gibbon. Other species are Malayan Giant Squirrel, Hoary Bellied Squirrel, Slow Loris, Capped Langur, Asiatic Elephant, Wild Boar and with luck a Leopard Cat. There is a wealth of bird life from the reserve too, species of note include Longtailed Broadbill, Silver Eared Mesia, Speckled and Rufous Piculet and several species of hornbills and with a bit of luck even the Hooded Pitta. The resident herd of Asiatic Elephants usually starts moving around this section of the sanctuary by the afternoon; so to avoid a potentially dangerous encounter on foot in the dense forest we will be leaving the sanctuary by lunch time and then drive to the Kaziranga National Park (2.5 hours) in time for an afternoon jungle safari. You will check in quickly and then hop on to your jeeps for the safari. Kaziranga is one of the most popular national parks in the whole of India, there are more large mammal species found here than anywhere else in the Indian Subcontinent including huge numbers of Indian one-horned rhinos, Asiatic elephants and healthy populations of tigers, water buffalo and other rare species such as Gangetic river dolphins. After this afternoons safari you will return to the lodge for your evening meal. (breakfast and dinner included today)

Manas National Park - Travelling & Wildlife Watching After breakfast you will depart from Kaziranga National Park and drive to Manas National Park. On arrival at your new lodge you will check in and then in the afternoon enjoy a safari to the park. The ecosystem of Manas is spread between Bhutan and India with protected national parks on both sides of the border. The targets include some of India's most elusive and endangered mammals, birds and reptiles. These include Crab-eating Mongoose, Hog Badger, Fishing Cat, Himalayan Crestless Porcupine, Leopard Cat, , Wild Buffalo, Assamese Macaque, other mammals include the Malayan Giant Squirrel, Hoary Bellied Squirrel, Smooth Coated Otter and the Indian One Horned Rhinoceros and the Asiatic Elephant. Birds include Rufous Necked Hornbill, Swamp Francolin, Black Tailed Crake, Hodgson’s Bushchat and Bengal Florican and the reptiles include the rare Assam Roofed Turtle. You will return to the lodge for your evening meal in the evening. (breakfast and dinner only included today)

Kolkata - Wildlife Watching & Travelling This morning you will have one final morning safari in Manas National Park before returning to the lodge for breakfast and then traveling to Guwahati to catch your flight to Kolkata (2 hours) you will then be taken to your hotel for your final night in India. (breakfast is the only meal included today)
Home - Departure After breakfast you will be transferred to the international airport in time to catch your return flight home. (breakfast is the only meal included today)

tourName: Wildlife photography holiday in India
placesVisited: Delhi, Kanha National Park, 11 game drives, Expert wildlife photography guide
generalInfo:
A ten day wildlife photography where you will travel around Kanha National Park, in the Central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh, home to about a hundred of India’s tigers, as well as leopard, sambhar, chital, monkeys and the rare swamp deer. This itinerary includes eleven game drives in Kanha with an expert naturalist guide to accompany you, and one who has experience of leading internationally renowned wildlife photographers through these unique habitats. Habitats that range from large swathes of native sal tree forests, to open grasslands or bamboo bush. Making this the most perfect terrain for wildlife photography holidays with plenty of chances for magnificent sightings.

A large part of Kanha National Park has also been designated as Kanha Tiger Reserve, following pioneering conservation work known as Project Tiger in 1974. You will be staying in a luxury eco lodge, with all meals, game drives, park fees, guide fees and naturalist fees included.

Note: An extension to Agra is available to see Taj Mahal or Keoladeo National Park for some great Birding.

dayInfo.description: Arrive Delhi & transfer to hotel. Local sightseeing arranged on request if time permits. Overnight hotel.
Sightseeing in Delhi, the capital city of India. Afternoon train to Jabalpur by AC sleeper class. Overnight train.

Reach Jabalpur early morning. Transfer to hotel for breakfast, freshen up. Later we drive to Kanha National Park (3hrs drive), check-in at lodge. Evening game drive. Kanha is an amphitheater of extreme delights that is how naturalist writers often describe this magnificent tiger landscape in Central India. The habitat comprises of grasslands, dense mixed and pure Sal forests and bamboo. Intervening rivulets, big and small makes the landscape charismatic and a joy to experience. The land of the tiger is home to more than hundred and supports wide variety of fauna and floral diversity. It is the best place in the wild to see the majestic Bengal tigers. The reserve is ideal for bird watching as more than two hundred and fifty species can be seen during the various seasons.
Kanha NP. Morning & evening game drive
Return to Jabalpur. Today after breakfast we drive back to Jabalpur for lunch. Later we board a direct overnight train to New Delhi, packed dinner onboard.
Arrive Delhi. You reach Delhi early morning & transfer to airport for your onward journey or transfer to hotel if you have booked extra nights. OPTION OF FLIGHT AVAILABLE INSTEAD OF TRAINS

tourName: Wildlife tour of India
generalInfo:
India is one of the top 5 bio-diverse nations and also the only nation in the world to have both tigers and lions.
